675597.question: A 20-year-old woman with a history of von Hippel Lindau syndrome presents to the clinic for her annual well-visit. She denies any recent vision or hearing changes and had a normal audiology assessment 1 year ago. MRI of the brain performed a year ago showed no disease. She is sexually active with her boyfriend of 2 years' duration. The most appropriate next step in management includes

explanation.BottomLine: Patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome should have either their serum or urinary metanephrines checked annually starting at 2 years of age.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease is an inherited, autosomal dominant syndrome manifested by a variety of benign and malignant tumors. A VHL gene abnormality diagnostic for VHL syndrome is present in approximately 1 in 36,000 individuals. The initial manifestations of disease can occur in childhood, adolescence, or adulthood, with a mean age at initial presentation of approximately 26 years. The spectrum of VHL-associated tumors includes pheochromocytomas, clear cell renal cell carcinomas (RCCs), hemangioblastomas of the brain (cerebellum) and spine, retinal capillary hemangioblastomas (retinal angiomas), endolymphatic sac tumors of the middle ear, serous cystadenomas and neuroendocrine tumors of the pancreas, and papillary cystadenomas of the epididymis and broad ligament.

Morbidity and mortality in patients with VHL disease have decreased substantially due to an improved understanding of the natural history of the serious clinical manifestations of the disorder, better imaging techniques, and improvements in therapy. Surveillance is important not only to detect new lesions at an early stage but also to monitor small asymptomatic lesions for evidence of progression. Pheochromocytoma is an important association with VHL patients. It most commonly occurs in patients who are between 12-25 years of age. RCC most commonly occurs later between 25-50 years of age.

For individuals with VHL who are 10 years of age or older, the surveillance protocol is as follows:

VHL Surveillance Protocol
Annually Every 2 Years
  • Eye/retinal examination with indirect ophthalmoscopy using a dilated examination by an ophthalmologist informed about VHL disease
  • Quality ultrasound and MRI scan of the abdomen with and without contrast to assess the kidneys, pancreas, and adrenals at least yearly but not during pregnancy
  • Physical examination by a clinician informed about VHL disease
  • Test for plasma metanephrines or urinary metanephrines using a 24-hour urine test
  • MRI with contrast of brain, cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine with thin cuts through the posterior fossa, and attention to inner ear/petrous temporal bone to rule out both endolymphatic sac tumor and hemangioblastomas
  • Audiology assessment by an audiologist

answers_info.Explanation: Reassurance and annual follow-up is inappropriate. This patient needs indirect ophthalmoscopy, abdominal imaging, and either serum or urinary metanephrine testing.
A chest x-ray offers no screening benefit in VHL patients and should not be obtained routinely.
A routine ECG, even for a "baseline," is not indicated in asymptomatic adults at low risk of cardiovascular disease. VHL does not increase the risk of cardiac disease.
MRI of the brain and audiology assessments are performed every 2 years. As both exams were normal last year, the next ones should take place next year.

references.Name: Findeis-Hosey JJ, McMahon KQ, Findeis SK. Von Hippel-Lindau disease. J Pediatr Genet. 2016 Jun;5(2):116-123.
Clinical features, diagnosis, and management of von Hippel-Lindau disease: UpToDate
Preventive care in adults: recommendations: UpToDate

675597.hint: Consider the necessary surveillance tests associated with her condition. What are common hormonal or biochemical markers that should be monitored in patients with von Hippel Lindau syndrome?

937506.question: A 30-year-old carpenter is presenting with throbbing pain in the right third fingertip. Physical examination shows a tense, swollen, and exquisitely tender pulp of the fingertip, as shown below. What is the best treatment?
answers: Vertical incision in the middle and drainage
Local anesthesia at the finger tip is preferred over digital nerve block
Once the incision is made, sharp dissection should be carried out to break all the septa
A lateral incision to nail bed and drainage
There is no indication for antibiotics after appropriate drainage
937506.correct_answer: Vertical incision in the middle and drainage

explanation.BottomLine: Felon should be treated by incision and drainage followed by a course of antibiotics. Patients who are diagnosed early, without tense fingertip pulp, may receive antibiotics initially and be observed closely.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The fleshy mass (called the pulp) at the fingertips is divided into multiple compartments by fibrous bands. Infection or abscess of pulp space is called a felon. It can happen after puncture wounds or sequelae of acute paronychia. Patients with felons need incision and drainage as they can cause ischemic damage to structures due to excess pressure.

Vertical incision over the fingertip pulp is preferred over the lateral incision because the latter has a higher risk of injury to the neurovascular structures. It is important not to extend the vertical incision to the level of the distal interphalangeal joint to avoid tendon sheath injury and subsequent tenosynovitis.


Felon.

937506.modifier: Vertical Incision In The Middle And Drainage

answers_info.Text: Vertical incision in the middle and drainage
Local anesthesia at the finger tip is preferred over digital nerve block
answers_info.Explanation: Injection of local anesthetic at the finger pulp can be very painful and sometimes inadequate. Performing digital nerve block is preferred.

answers_info.Text: Once the incision is made, sharp dissection should be carried out to break all the septa
answers_info.Explanation: Once skin incision is made, blunt dissection should be used to avoid injury to the neurovascular structures or the tendon sheath.

answers_info.Text: A lateral incision to nail bed and drainage
answers_info.Explanation: Vertical incision over the fingertip pulp is preferred over the lateral incision because the latter has a higher risk of injury to the neurovascular structures. A lateral incision to nail bed and drainage is used for acute paronychia.

answers_info.Text: There is no indication for antibiotics after appropriate drainage
answers_info.Explanation: Antibiotics are indicated to treat the infection and prevent further complications. Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus are the most common micro-organisms associated with felon. Empirical antibiotics should cover these micro-organisms. Flagyl is mainly used for anaerobic infections.

references.Name: Netscher D, Murphy KD, Fiore NA. Chapter 69: Hand surgery. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 20th ed. Elsevier; 2017:1975-2026.
Image source: Wikimedia Commons

937506.hint: Consider how infections in small areas, like the fingertip, require special attention to avoid damage to underlying structures. Think about the safest incision technique for such a sensitive area.

933148.question: A 45-year-old woman with a long-standing history of systemic lupus erythematosus presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. On exploratory laparotomy, she is found to have a perforated duodenal ulcer and undergoes a Graham patch repair and extensive washout of the abdomen. Twenty-four hours after her surgery, she continues to have refractory hypotension that requires 2 vasopressors despite appropriate fluid resuscitation and antibiotics. She is afebrile. Which of the following electrolyte deficiency does the patient most likely have?

explanation.BottomLine: Adrenal insufficiency manifests as refractory hypotension despite appropriate resuscitation, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and generalized fatigue. Treatment consists of appropriate fluid/electrolyte resuscitation, vasopressors as needed, and empiric glucocorticoid supplementation without waiting for confirmatory testing (adrenocorticotropic hormone stimulation).
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient most likely has acute adrenal insufficiency given her long-standing history of systemic lupus erythematosus (chronic steroid use) and refractory hypotension despite source control and appropriate antibiotics. The most likely electrolyte abnormality she is experiencing is hyponatremia.

The signs and symptoms of acute adrenal insufficiency include refractory shock, nausea and vomiting, generalized weakness, abdominal pain, electrolyte abnormalities (hyponatremia and hyperkalemia), and sometimes hypoglycemia. It is most commonly seen in patients with autoimmune conditions who usually are on chronic steroids, which suppress the adrenal glands. Hyponatremia in adrenal insufficiency is caused by the lack of aldosterone and the release of excess antidiuretic hormone (ADH). Aldosterone's function is to increase sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the kidney. The hypotension seen in adrenal insufficiency stimulates the release of ADH, which in turn causes free water absorption and further worsens the hyponatremia.

Patients with suspected acute adrenal insufficiency (such as this patient with refractory hypotension requiring 2 vasopressors despite appropriate resuscitation and antibiotics) should be empirically supplemented with IV glucocorticoids (eg, hydrocortisone, dexamethasone). Confirmatory testing is not required nor should treatment be delayed in the acute setting.

answers_info.Explanation: Adrenal insufficiency is manifested as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia (not hypokalemia). The lack of aldosterone leads to decreased reabsorption of sodium and decreased excretion of potassium.
The adrenal gland does not regulate magnesium metabolism. Adrenal insufficiency is manifested as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.
The parathyroid glands regulate calcium metabolism, not the adrenal gland. Adrenal insufficiency manifests as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, not hypocalcemia.
The parathyroid glands regulate phosphate metabolism. Adrenal insufficiency manifests as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, not hypophosphatemia.

references.Name: Shaka H, Manz S, El-Amir Z, Wani F, Salim M, Kichloo A. Ten-year trends in adrenal insufficiency admissions. Proc (Bayl Univ Med Cent). 2022;35(3):297-300.
Chapter 40: The adrenal glands. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:964-997.
Diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency in adults: UpToDate

933148.hint: Consider how certain autoimmune conditions, particularly with chronic steroid use, may affect the body's ability to maintain blood pressure and electrolyte balance. Focus on the symptoms of adrenal insufficiency, particularly how they relate to electrolyte levels.

1058377.question: A female with a prolonged history of gastroesophageal reflux disease presents with worsening dysphagia and weight loss. She undergoes an EGD, which demonstrates a mid-esophageal mass shown in image A. She undergoes an EUS, which demonstrates the findings in image B. Fine-needle aspiration demonstrates adenocarcinoma. The remainder of her staging workup is negative. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.BottomLine: Esophageal adenocarcinoma spreads via submucosal lymphatic channels. The risk of nodal spread is related to the depth of invasion. Therefore, clinical T1 lesions diagnosed on EUS should next undergo a diagnostic endoscopic resection to determine the exact pathological depth/stage.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient is diagnosed with esophageal adenocarcinoma. The EUS demonstrates a T1 lesion (confined to the mucosa/submucosa). The next step is to perform a diagnostic endoscopic resection to determine the exact pathological stage (i.e. pTis, pT1a, superficial pT1b, pT1b), as this dictates further management.

Esophageal adenocarcinoma accounts for ~70% of esophageal cancer diagnoses in the United States. It is known to spread aggressively through the lymphatic channels. The likelihood of nodal invasion increases with the depth of the tumor.

T Staging of Esophageal Cancer by Depth of Tumor Invasion (AJCC 8th Edition)
  • T1: Tumor invades the lamina propria, muscularis mucosae, or submucosa
    • T1a Tumor invades the lamina propria or muscularis mucosae
    • T1b Tumor invades the submucosa
  • T2: Tumor invades the muscularis propria
  • T3: Tumor invades adventitia
  • T4: Tumor invades adjacent structures
    • T4a Tumor invades the pleura, pericardium, azygos vein, diaphragm, or peritoneum
    • T4b Tumor invades other adjacent structures, such as the aorta, vertebral body, or airway


Endoscopic evaluation of a mid-esophageal mass. A: a submucosal mass is seen at 3 o'clock of an EGD view. B: EUS demonstrating the tumor to be confined to the submucosa (SM); muscularis propria (MP) is the next outer layer, which is typically black due to the low echogenicity of the muscle fibers; the blue arrow indicates the adventitia, which appears as a white, echogenic line.

Clinical T1 lesions diagnosed on EUS should next undergo diagnostic endoscopic resection (ER) to obtain the pathological stage/depth.  

ER (with or without ablation) is recommended for patients with early-stage (Tis, T1a, or superficial T1b) tumors. Esophagectomy is the preferred primary treatment option for patients who are medically fit with T1b–T2, N0 low-risk lesions. For patients who are medically fit with locally advanced resectable tumors (T2, N0 high-risk lesions, T1b–T2, N+ and T3–T4a, any N tumors), primary treatment options include preoperative chemoradiation (category 1, preferred for adenocarcinoma), perioperative chemotherapy (only for adenocarcinoma) or definitive chemoradiation (only in nonsurgical candidates or patients who decline surgery). Definitive chemoradiation is the recommended treatment option for patients with T4b (unresectable) tumors, with chemotherapy alone reserved for the setting of invasion into the heart, vertebral body, trachea, or great vessels. Patients with unresectable or metastatic disease should be offered best supportive care and palliative management with or without systemic therapy, depending on performance status.

1058377.modifier: T1 Should Undergo Diagnostic Endoscopic Resection

answers_info.Explanation: Upfront esophagectomy is the preferred primary treatment option for patients who are medically fit with T1b–T2, N0 low-risk lesions. This patient with a clinical T1 lesion on EUS should first undergo a diagnostic ER to determine the pathological T stage (exact depth of invasion).
Neoadjuvant chemoradiation is indicated for patients who are medically fit with locally advanced resectable tumors (T2, N0 high-risk lesions, T1b–T2, N+ and T3–T4a, any N tumors).

Definitive chemoradiation is the recommended treatment option for patients with T4b (unresectable) tumors, with chemotherapy alone reserved for the setting of invasion into the heart, vertebral body, trachea, or great vessels.
The role of immunotherapy for esophageal cancer is evolving. Agents including nivolumab, ipilimumab, pembrolizumab, tremelimumab, and durvalumab are reserved for MSI-H/dMMR tumors.

references.Name: National Comprehensive Cancer Network. NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology. Esophageal and Esophagogastric Junction Cancers. Version 3.2023
Clinical manifestations, diagnosis, and staging of esophageal cancer - Uptodate
Watanabe, Masayuki, et al. "Recent progress in multidisciplinary treatment for patients with esophageal cancer." Surgery today 50 (2020): 12-20.

additional_image_sources.Name: Endoscopic Ultrasound of Esophageal Mass - Cureus

1058377.hint: Consider the characteristics of the lesions evaluated through EUS and how they might dictate the next steps. Focus on the significance of the T1 classification.

648122.question: Which of the following most accurately describes gastrin? Luminal acid inhibits the secretion of gastrin.
answers: Gastrin release is stimulated by adenosine
Gastrin release is inhibited by acetylcholine
Luminal acid inhibits the secretion of gastrin
Gastrin is produced by the parietal cells
Gastrin interacts with receptors on enterochromaffin-like cells to inhibit secretion of histamine
648122.correct_answer: Luminal acid inhibits the secretion of gastrin

explanation.BottomLine: Gastrin stimulates the release of gastric acid and mucosal growth. Its release is stimulated by food, acetylcholine, gastrin-releasing peptide, beta-2/beta-3 agonists, 5HT, calcium, amino acids, amines, capsaicin, and alcoholic beverages.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Gastrin is a gastrointestinal peptide that is produced by the G-cells of the gastric antrum. It is the main regulator of the gastric phase of acid secretion following food intake. Gastrin stimulates acid secretion via stimulation of the synthesis and release of histamine from enterochromaffin-like cells, which then induces acid secretion by binding to H2 receptors on parietal cells. Gastrin also stimulates acid secretion from parietal cells via cholecystokinin B receptor.

648122.modifier: Luminal Acid Inhibits The Secretion Of Gastrin

answers_info.Text: Gastrin release is stimulated by adenosine
answers_info.Explanation: Gastrin release is inhibited by adenosine.

answers_info.Text: Gastrin release is inhibited by acetylcholine
answers_info.Explanation: Gastrin release is stimulated by acetylcholine.

answers_info.Text: Luminal acid inhibits the secretion of gastrin
Gastrin is produced by the parietal cells
answers_info.Explanation: Gastrin is produced by the G-cells of the gastric antrum as well as, although in much smaller amounts, in the proximal small intestine, colon, and pancreas.

answers_info.Text: Gastrin interacts with receptors on enterochromaffin-like cells to inhibit secretion of histamine
answers_info.Explanation: Gastrin released from G-cells interacts with receptors on enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells and parietal cells to stimulate the release of histamine and hydrochloric acid. Acidification of the antral lumen results in the activation of D-cells. Somatostatin release from D-cells then causes a decrease of histamine and gastrin release from the ECL cells and G-cells, respectively. Somatostatin release also inhibits parietal cell secretion.

references.Name: Stomach. In: In: Townsend C et al., eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 20th Ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2017.
Small Intestine. In: Townsend C et al., eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 20th Ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2017.

648122.hint: Consider how luminal acid affects the secretion of gastrin. Think about the role of acid in the stomach and its feedback mechanisms.

734236.question: A 54-year-old woman presents to the office after noticing a lesion on her left cheek. On examination, there is a 1.5-cm pearly, pink lesion with rolled edges on her left cheek. There are no palpable lymph nodes. What is the best treatment option for this patient?
answers: excision with 2-cm margins and a sentinel lymph node biopsy
excision with 2-cm margins and an extended lymph node dissection

explanation.BottomLine: Basal cell carcinomas are treated with excision and a 0.5-cm margin.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The lesion on this patient’s cheek is a basal cell carcinoma and is treated with excision with 0.5-cm margins. The classic description of basal cell cancers are pearly lesions with rolled edges, that can be pink, brown, or black. Lymph node dissections are only indicated with clinically palpable nodes.


Nodular basal cell carcinoma.

answers_info.Explanation: The lesion on this patient’s cheek is a basal cell carcinoma and is treated with excision and a 0.5-cm margin. Wider margins can be considered if there is a high risk of recurrence lesions. High-risk factors for basal cell carcinoma include tumor size > 2 cm, poorly defined, recurrent lesion, and immunosuppressed patients.
Excision with 2-cm margins is not part of the treatment for basal cell carcinoma. Such a wide margin is considered for some melanomas.

answers_info.Text: excision with 2-cm margins and a sentinel lymph node biopsy
answers_info.Explanation: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is not indicated for basal cell cancers.

answers_info.Text: excision with 2-cm margins and an extended lymph node dissection
answers_info.Explanation: Lymphadenectomy is not part of the treatment for basal cell carcinoma in the absence of palpable nodes. Patients with advance (regional or metastatic) disease are treated with systemic therapy and surgery after multidisciplinary discussion.

references.Name: McMasters KM, Tyler DS, Egger ME. Chapter 31: Melanoma and Cutaneous Malignancies. In: Townsend C, Beauchamp RD, Evers BM, Mattox KL, eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:705-733.
Image source:
Basal cell carcinoma on the cheek: Wikimedia Commons

734236.hint: Consider the characteristics of the lesion and remember which surgical options are generally recommended for basal cell carcinomas. Think about the appropriate margin width that is typically used in such cases.

636942.question: A 66-year-old male has a femoral-popliteal bypass with a prosthetic graft for non-healing wounds. The patient returns 5 months later with drainage from the surgical site. What organism is most likely causing this late graft infection?

explanation.BottomLine: The most common pathogen causing late graft infection is S. epidermidis.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Late prosthetic graft infections (those occurring > 4 months postoperatively) are most commonly due to Staphylococcus epidermidis bacteria, which forms a biofilm over the implanted foreign body. The ability to form biofilms on plastic devices is a major virulence factor for S. epidermidis. It allows other bacteria to bind to the already existing biofilm, creating a multilayered biofilm. Such biofilms decrease the metabolic activity of bacteria within them. This decreased metabolism, in combination with impaired diffusion of antibiotics, makes it difficult for antibiotics to effectively clear this type of infection.

S. epidermidis strains are often resistant to antibiotics, including penicillin, amoxicillin, and methicillin. These infections usually require initiation of intravenous (iv) antibiotics and removal of the infected graft. Early graft infections are caused most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus.

answers_info.Explanation: Salmonella can sometimes be found in mycotic aneurysms.
Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of EARLY graft infection.
Escherichia coli can involve prosthetic grafts but is not the most common pathogen.
Streptococcus pneumoniae is a less common pathogen for graft infection.

references.Name: Back, R. Chapter 47: Graft Infections. In: Sidawy, AN, Perler BA. Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2018
Wilson, W. Vascular graft infections, mycotic aneurysms, and endovascular graft infections: a scientific statement from the American Heart Association. Circulation. 2016;134:e412–e460.

636942.hint: Consider the timing of the infection relative to the surgery. Think about which organisms are known to cause infections after a certain period post-operation. Look for clues in the types of graft infections and their typical pathogens.

346009.question: An otherwise healthy 15-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents, because he has a painless swelling of the hard palate for the past year. Physical examination shows a lesion that is solid, firm, fixed, non-compressible, non-tender, and covered with healthy palatal mucosa. Which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis?

explanation.BottomLine: Maxillary torus is a benign osteoblastic tumors. It arises from the hard palate. It is usually asymptomatic and requires no treatment unless symptoms develop. Treatment is surgical excision.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: In an otherwise healthy young patient with a solid asymptomatic lesion on the hard palate, the most likely diagnosis is a maxillary torus. Maxillary torus is a benign osteoblastic tumor that tends to be well encapsulated and submucosal. It expands gradually without invading adjacent structures. They occur on the midline of the hard palate and requires treatment only if it becomes symptomatic.

346009.modifier: Teenager Hard Palate Swelling Firm Non-tender Mass

answers_info.Explanation: Fibrous dysplasia is a benign tumor of bony origin that involves the upper facial skeleton. It may present as a component of McCune-Albright syndrome or as a localized condition of the craniofacial skeleton. An isolated palatal occurrence of fibrous dysplasia is highly unlikely.
Gliomas appear at or just lateral to the nasal root as reddish, firm, non-compressible, lobular lesions with cutaneous telangiectasia.
Squamous cell carcinoma is uncommon in a healthy fifteen year old boy with no risk factors.
Submucous cleft palates present with a triad of bifid uvula, a notch at the junction of hard and soft palate, and a zona pellucida, which is a thin layer of mucosa in the midline of the soft palate.

references.Name: Plastic Surgery, Elsevier, 2006.

346009.hint: Consider the characteristics of the swelling described. The lesion is asymptomatic and has specific physical properties (solid, firm, fixed) that are common with some benign conditions. Focus on the midline location and the description of the hard palate.

833660.question: A 55-year-old woman with no significant medical history and no family history of colorectal cancer undergoes a colonoscopy for a history of rectal bleeding. A single 4-mm villous adenomatous polyp is removed intact from the left colon. There is no evidence of dysplasia on the pathological examination. This is her first colonoscopy. What is the most appropriate endoscopic surveillance for this patient in the future?

explanation.BottomLine: Single adenomas that are large (> 1 cm), have villous features, or have high-grade dysplasia require repeat colonoscopy in 3 years.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient has a < 1-cm adenoma with villous features. Therefore, a 3-year screening interval would be appropriate.

The type and size of polyps as well as any high-risk features on pathology are important to determine the malignant potential of a polyp and therefore the colonoscopic surveillance strategy after polyp removal.

There are 4 main types of polyps. Hyperplastic polyps are non-neoplastic with a low risk of cancer, especially in small and distal lesions. Adenomas are neoplastic polyps with malignant potential and are precursor lesions for the majority of colorectal carcinomas. Hamartomas are benign, non-neoplastic polyps except when associated with hereditary disorders. Inflammatory pseudopolyps are not true polyps but are islands of normal mucosa surrounded by abnormal colonic mucosa. These typically occur in inflammatory bowel disease and colitis.

Recommendations for Post-Colonoscopy Follow-Up in Average-Risk Adults with Normal Colonoscopy or Adenomas
Type of Polyp Colonoscopic Surveillance
None 10 years 
Small distal hyperplastic polyps 10 years
1–2 small (< 1 cm) tubular adenomas 7–10 years
3–10 adenomas
OR 1 adenoma > 1 cm
OR adenoma with villous features
OR high-grade dysplasia		 3 years 
> 10 adenomas 1 year—may need to exclude polyposis syndrome
Adenomas removed piecemeal 6 months (to ensure complete excision)

answers_info.Explanation: A 3-month screening interval would be appropriate if the adenomatous polyp was removed in piecemeal in order to ensure that the lesion was removed in its entirety. However, as this polyp was removed intact, there is no need for a short-interval colonoscopy.
A 1-year screening interval would be appropriate if the patient had multiple (> 10) adenomatous polyps. However, in the setting of a single polyp, this screening interval would be too frequent.

A 5-year screening interval would be appropriate if the adenomatous polyp was < 1 cm and without villous features, but the patient had clinical factors that would make the provider consider a shorter screening interval than 10 years. These include patient preference or a strong family history of colorectal cancer.

A 10-year screening interval would be appropriate if the adenomatous polyp was < 1 cm but without villous features, especially because the patient does not have any family history of colorectal cancer.

references.Name: Galandiuk S, Netz U, Morpurgo E, Tosato SM, Abu-Freha N, Ellis CT. Chapter 52: Colon and rectum. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:1320-1400.

Garrett KA, Lee SW. Chapter 5: Endoscopic management of polyps, polypectomy, and combined endoscopic and laparoscopic surgery. In: Steele SR, ed. The ASCRS Textbook of Colon and Rectal Surgery. 3rd ed. Springer; 2016:79-91.
Overview of colon polyps: UpToDate
Endoscopic removal of large colon polyps: UpToDate

833660.hint: Consider the size and characteristics of the polyp removed, especially focusing on whether it has any villous features. Think about the guidelines for follow-up colonoscopy based on these findings.

1007682.question: Which of the following is true regarding small-bowel hemangiomas?
answers: They require surgical resection when detected
CT imaging is not sufficient for diagnosis
They are a common cause of gastrointestinal bleeding
Needle biopsy is performed for accurate diagnosis
Endoscopic management is a therapeutic option
1007682.correct_answer: Endoscopic management is a therapeutic option

explanation.BottomLine: Small bowel hemangiomas are rare benign small bowel tumors that present as occult gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding (and are a rare cause of GI bleeding). They are easily diagnosed on imaging and can be frequently managed with endoscopic interventions alone. Surgical resection should be reserved for resection of large lesions not amenable to endoscopic therapy or angioembolization.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Hemangiomas are rare benign tumors that present along the length of the small bowel and mostly present as gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. They mostly present with occult GI bleeding and iron deficiency anemia. Because of their rarity, hemangiomas are not considered a common cause of GI bleeding. The only reason for operative management of a benign small bowel lesion is to control symptoms. Mass effect causing intussusception or obstruction, hemorrhage, or a suspicion of malignancy generates the need for local resection of the lesion. The diagnostic dilemma is the most common reason for resection of an incidentally found mass on contrast study or endoscopy.

Although the hemangiomas may be present along the entire length of the small bowel, endoscopy can be therapeutic for proximal or distal lesions as there is a lot of small bowel that endoscopy can't reach. Most of the jejunal and some ileal lesions can be managed successfully with endoscopic intervention alone. Thus, endoscopic management is a viable therapeutic option.

Hemangiomatous lesions can be resected or managed with angiographic embolization. According to a recent review of literature, 91.9% of the lesions were diagnosed preoperatively by capsule endoscopy and/or balloon-assisted endoscopy, and 45.9% of them were treated endoscopically.



Laparoscopic view of the jejunal hemangioma. (Image from Jones AE, Ainsworth BH, Desai A, Tsang TT. Small bowel hemangioma diagnosed with laparoscopy: Report of two pediatric cases. J Minim Access Surg. 2007;3(1):29-31. Used with permission.)

answers_info.Text: They require surgical resection when detected
answers_info.Explanation: Surgical resection is warranted for symptomatic lesions and those where malignancy cannot be ruled out. Surgical resection is certainly an option, though it is by no means "required" in all presentations as this answer choice suggests. That makes this answer an incorrect option, even though surgical resection may be considered a standard procedure for symptomatic presentations.

answers_info.Text: CT imaging is not sufficient for diagnosis
answers_info.Explanation: Hemangiomas are easily differentiated on CT with IV contrast or magnetic resonance (MR) enterography.

answers_info.Text: They are a common cause of gastrointestinal bleeding
answers_info.Explanation: These tumors of the small bowel are exceedingly rare (account for only 0.05% of all GI neoplasms) and, although they present most commonly as occult GI bleeding, they are a very rare cause of GI bleeding.

answers_info.Text: Needle biopsy is performed for accurate diagnosis
answers_info.Explanation: CT with IV contrast or MR enterography obviate the need for biopsy.

answers_info.Text: Endoscopic management is a therapeutic option

references.Name: DiBrito SR, Duncan MD. Management of small bowel tumors. In: Cameron AM, Cameron JL, eds. Current Surgical Therapy. 13th ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2020:138-142.
Leeds SG, Fleshman JW. Chapter 51: Small bowel tumors. In: Mulholland MW, ed. Greenfield's Surgery: Scientific Principles and Practice. 6th ed. Philadelphia: Wolters Kluwer; 2016:827-839.
Jones AE, Ainsworth BH, Desai A, Tsang TT. Small bowel hemangioma diagnosed with laparoscopy: report of two pediatric cases. J Minim Access Surg. 2007;3(1):29-31.

1007682.hint: Consider how small-bowel hemangiomas are typically managed in a clinical setting, especially regarding interventions that are less invasive.

722434.question: A 50-year-old woman with a strong family history of breast cancer, including 3 first-degree female relatives, presents to the clinic inquiring about the association of nipple discharge with breast cancer. Which of the following scenarios is most concerning for breast cancer?
answers: nonspontaneous bilateral clear nipple discharge in pregnancy

explanation.BottomLine: The distinction between benign and pathologic nipple discharge is important because nipple discharge is the presenting symptom in approximately 5% of new breast cancer diagnoses. Pathologic nipple discharge is often unilateral, single duct, and spontaneous.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Pathologic nipple discharge is often unilateral, single duct, and spontaneous. Causes of pathologic nipple discharge include the following:
  • Intraductal papilloma
  • Breast carcinoma
Benign nipple discharge, however, is typically bilateral, nonspontaneous, and involves multiple ducts. Causes of benign nipple discharge include the following:
  • Galactorrhea
  • Physiologic stimulation
  • Glandular secretions
  • Pregnancy
  • Medications
The distinction between benign and pathologic discharge is important because nipple discharge is the presenting symptom in approximately 5% of new breast cancer diagnoses. In the setting of a pathologic nipple discharge, breast imaging is warranted, starting with a mammogram. 

Symptoms of breast cancer include breast lumps, nipple discharge, and mastitis or a breast infection. The majority of women with breast cancer are asymptomatic at the time of presentation, and the diagnosis is usually made after an abnormality has been identified on a screening mammogram.

answers_info.Text: nonspontaneous bilateral clear nipple discharge in pregnancy
answers_info.Explanation: In pregnancy, bilateral, nonspontaneous, multi duct, bilateral clear nipple discharge is benign and does not require further workup. With prolactin levels surging during early pregnancy, colostrum starts filling the breasts and may be associated with some discharge.

Nonspontaneous nipple discharge is not pathologic. Brown or cheese-like nipple discharge is most likely a mammary duct ectasia. Mammary duct ectasia most often occurs in women during perimenopause, around 45-55 years of age. It is a benign breast condition caused by normal breast changes that happen with age.
Bilateral multi duct secretion is typically benign regardless of color. Spontaneous bilateral milky nipple discharge could be medication-induced, physiologic, or could represent early pregnancy.
Purulent discharge is more consistent with an infection than invasive cancer.

references.Name: Klimberg VS, Hunt KK, Chapter 35: Diseases of the breast. In: Townsend C, Beauchamp RD, Evers BM, Mattox KL, eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2021:809-855.
Sajadi-Ernazarova KR, Sugumar K, Adigun R. Breast nipple discharge. 2020. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2021 Jan–.
Panzironi G, Pediconi F, Sardanelli F. Nipple discharge: The state of the art. BJR Open. 2018;1(1):20180016.

722434.hint: Consider the characteristics of different types of nipple discharge. Pay attention to whether the discharge is unilateral or bilateral and whether it is spontaneous or nonspontaneous, as these factors can differentiate benign from pathologic conditions.

835735.question: A 30-year-old man presents with intermittent dysphagia, particularly after eating steak. The dysphagia is in the lower chest and is worse with solids than liquids.  The patient notes a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease but has no other major medical history and is otherwise healthy. He undergoes a workup, including a barium esophagogram, which is shown below. Which of the following statements is correct about the patient's underlying diagnosis?
answers: This entity is not associated with a hiatal hernia
This pathology is symptomatic in a majority of patients
Workup is initiated with CT scan
This patient has a decreased chance of getting Barrett esophagus
835735.correct_answer: This patient has a decreased chance of getting Barrett esophagus

explanation.BottomLine: A Schatzki's ring is a circular membrane of mucosa and submucosa at the squamocolumnar junction in the distal esophagus that causes intermittent dysphagia to solids with discomfort in the lower chest and can also cause food impactions. It is associated with a hiatal hernia. It is managed with esophageal dilation or 4-quadrant biopsies to disrupt the ring, as well as acid-reducing therapy.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The patient above has a Schatzki's ring, which is a circular membrane of mucosa and submucosa at the squamocolumnar junction in the distal esophagus.  The upper surface is covered with squamous mucosa and the lower surface is covered with columnar mucosa. Schatzki's ring is thought to be caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is always associated with a hiatal hernia. Interestingly, Barrett esophagus is less common in those with a Schatzki's ring, so the theory is that it helps protect against Barrett. 

Schatzki's ring causes narrowing of the esophageal lumen, which can result in dysphagia and food impaction, although a majority of patients are actually asymptomatic. Those with symptoms commonly present with dysphagia, particularly after eating poorly chewed meat, with a feeling of discomfort in the lower chest.  

The initial workup of a patient with a suspected Schatzki's ring is a barium esophagram, which should show any significant luminal ring. Endoscopy should follow the esophagogram to rule out any other causes of stricture or dysphagia. For symptomatic patients with narrower rings, standard treatment options include esophageal dilation with tapered or balloon dilators or 4-quadrant biopsies with jumbo forceps, which can often obliterate the ring. This is typically followed by a regimen of acid-reducing medication. For patients with less narrow rings and only mild symptoms, a course of acid-reducing medications could be tried alone.

Although there are other differentials for a patient with dysphagia, such as stricture, malignancy, motility disorders (achalasia, scleroderma, etc), in this young otherwise healthy patient, they would be less likely.


Barium esophagogram showing a Schatzki's ring in the distal esophagus.

answers_info.Explanation: Schatzki's rings are the most common cause of episodic dysphagia and food impaction in adults. They are found in 6–14% of barium esophagograms.

answers_info.Text: This entity is not associated with a hiatal hernia
answers_info.Explanation: Schatzki's rings are always associated with a hiatal hernia.

answers_info.Text: This pathology is symptomatic in a majority of patients
answers_info.Explanation: The majority of people with Schatzki's ring are not symptomatic. Symptoms are usually related to the size of the ring, with rings < 13 mm typically symptomatic, whereas rings > 25 mm are typically asymptomatic.

answers_info.Text: Workup is initiated with CT scan
answers_info.Explanation: The first step in the workup of a suspected Schatzki's ring is a barium esophagogram. Endoscopy is eventually needed to rule out malignant causes of dysphagia or stricture.  If a cancer is identified, CT scans would be used for staging.

answers_info.Text: This patient has a decreased chance of getting Barrett esophagus

references.Name: Yates RB, Oelschlager BK. Gastroesophageal reflux disease and hiatal hernia. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:1056-1078.
Müller M, Gockel I, Hedwig P, et al. Is the Schatzki ring a unique esophageal entity? World J Gastroenterol. 2011;17(23):2838-2843.
Approach to the evaluation of dysphagia in adults: UpToDate
Schatzki ring: StatPearls
Image source:
Schatzki ring:  Wikimedia Commons

835735.hint: Consider the connection between the patient's history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and the nature of his dysphagia. What does a Schatzki's ring signify in terms of its potential impact on the esophagus?

765961.question: What is the most common presentation of ductal carcinoma in situ?

explanation.BottomLine: Clustered microcalcifications on a mammogram are the most frequent presentation of ductal carcinoma in situ.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a premalignant lesion and noninvasive breast cancer that is characterized by a proliferation of abnormal malignant epithelial cells that are confined within the basement membrane of the mammary ductal-lobular system. Ductal carcinoma in situ has a variety of clinical presentations, but clustered microcalcifications on a mammogram are the most frequent.

answers_info.Explanation: Breast pain is a relatively uncommon presentations of DCIS.
A palpable mass is a relatively uncommon presentations of DCIS.
Most often the calcifications are clustered on mammogram.
Nipple discharge is an uncommon presentation of DCIS.

references.Name: Klimberg VS, Hunt KK. Chapter 35: Diseases of the breast. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:809-855.
Barbie TU, Gillanders WE. Chapter 74. Breast Disease. In: Mulholland MW, ed. Greenfield's Surgery: Scientific Principles & Practice. 6th ed. Wolters Kluwer; 2016:1291-1339.

765961.hint: Think about the findings seen on a mammogram that can indicate the presence of abnormal breast tissue. Specific patterns of calcifications are often key indicators.

1037999.question: A 45-year-old woman with longstanding hypertension refractory to 4 antihypertensive medications is diagnosed with a right adrenal aldosterone-secreting tumor. She is taken to the OR for a laparoscopic right adrenalectomy, is positioned in a left lateral decubitus position, and trocars are placed. What is the most appropriate next step in performing the operation? The first key step in performing a transabdominal laparoscopic right adrenalectomy is to mobilize the right lobe of the liver at the right triangular ligament to allow retraction of the liver and exposure of the retroperitoneum.
answers: exposing the cephalad border of the adrenal gland and dividing the phrenic artery branches
exposing the inferior vena cava and ligating the right adrenal vein
dividing the right triangular ligament to mobilize the right lobe of the liver
1037999.correct_answer: dividing the right triangular ligament to mobilize the right lobe of the liver

explanation.BottomLine: The first key step in performing a transabdominal laparoscopic right adrenalectomy is the mobilization of the right lobe of the liver at the right triangular ligament to allow retraction of the liver and exposure of the retroperitoneum.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Laparoscopic adrenalectomy can be performed from an anterior approach, lateral approach, or a posterior retroperitoneal approach. Several factors, including the underlying pathology, the size of the lesion, and the expertise of the surgeon, determine the choice of the approach. 

The first step in performing laparoscopic right adrenalectomy from a lateral approach (as in this case) is to divide the right triangular ligament to mobilize the right lobe of the liver, which allows retraction of the liver and exposure of the retroperitoneum. Mobilization of the hepatic flexure of the colon may also be needed.




Division of the right triangular ligament to mobilize the right lobe of the liver.

1037999.modifier: Mobilization Of The Right Lobe Of The Liver

answers_info.Explanation: Mobilization of the spleen is part of a left, not right, adrenalectomy.

answers_info.Text: exposing the cephalad border of the adrenal gland and dividing the phrenic artery branches
answers_info.Explanation: Exposure of the cephalad border of the adrenal gland and division of the inferior phrenic arterial branches to the adrenal gland is generally done after mobilizing the right lobe of the liver.
Kocherization of the duodenum is rarely required for right adrenalectomy, as the right adrenal gland is located superior to this area.

answers_info.Text: exposing the inferior vena cava and ligating the right adrenal vein
answers_info.Explanation: Once the right lobe of the liver is mobilized and retracted superiorly and medially, the hepatic flexure retracted inferiorly (and mobilized, if necessary), and the plane between the right adrenal gland and the inferior vena cava dissected, the ideal next step would be to completely expose the right adrenal vein and ligate it.

answers_info.Text: dividing the right triangular ligament to mobilize the right lobe of the liver

references.Name: Chapter 40: The adrenal glands. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:964-997.
Laparoscopic adrenalectomy abdominal approach. In: Lomanto D, ed. Mastering Endo-Laparoscopic and Thoracoscopic Surgery. Springer; 2023.
Laparoscopic adrenalectomy: SAGES Minimally Invasive Surgery Videos

additional_image_sources.Name: Division of the right triangular ligament: Mastering Endo-Laparoscopic and Thoracoscopic Surgery

1037999.hint: Consider which structure needs to be mobilized to access the adrenal gland effectively. Think about the anatomical relationships in the abdominal cavity to identify the best mobilization strategy.

1046467.question: A 50-year-old woman is diagnosed with acute cholecystitis and undergoes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The critical view of safety is successfully obtained, and a tubular structure is identified medial to the cystic duct in the hepatocystic triangle. What is the typical anatomic course of this structure?
answers: branch off of the common hepatic artery, originating posterior to the common hepatic duct
branch off of the left hepatic artery, originating posterior to the common hepatic duct
branch off of the right hepatic artery, originating anterior to the common hepatic duct
branch off of the right hepatic artery, originating posterior to the common hepatic duct
branch off of the gastroduodenal artery, originating posterior to the common hepatic duct
1046467.correct_answer: branch off of the right hepatic artery, originating posterior to the common hepatic duct

explanation.BottomLine: The cystic artery is most commonly a branch off of the right hepatic artery that originates posterior to the common hepatic duct.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The cystic artery most commonly branches off of the right hepatic artery and originates posterior to the common hepatic duct. Because of the anatomic variability of the hepatocystic triangle, it is important to obtain the critical view of safety before clipping or dividing structures in this area.

Intraoperatively, the classic laparoscopic injury involves the misidentification of the common duct for the cystic duct. This injury occurs from excessive cephalad retraction of the gallbladder fundus, insufficient lateral retraction on the infundibulum, or both—the common bile duct is then mistaken for the cystic duct, with subsequent ligation and transection. 

Biliary injuries can occur in combination with vascular injuries. For example, the right hepatic artery may be erroneously misidentified as the cystic artery, resulting in the most common type of injury.

Arterial injuries usually happen most commonly from transection, followed by occlusion by clips, and thrombosis of the vessel. The vessel is often damaged while attempting to control bleeding during the dissection; hence, it is important to address hemorrhage with tamponade rather than by blind application of clips or considering converting to an open operation.


Hepatocystic triangle and triangle of Calot. Hepatocystic triangle (blue): Upper boundary, inferior border of liver; lateral, the cystic duct; medial, the common hepatic duct. Triangle of Calot (yellow): Upper boundary, cystic artery; lateral, the cystic duct; medial, the common hepatic duct. 

The Critical View of Safety 
The hepatocystic triangle is dissected free of fibrous and fatty tissue
The lower one-third of the gallbladder has been dissected off the cystic plate
Only 2 structures (ie, cystic duct and artery) are seen to be entering the gallbladder

1046467.modifier: Right Hepatic Artery, Posterior To Hepatic Duct

answers_info.Text: branch off of the common hepatic artery, originating posterior to the common hepatic duct
answers_info.Explanation: The cystic artery is typically a branch off of the right hepatic artery, not the common hepatic artery.

answers_info.Text: branch off of the left hepatic artery, originating posterior to the common hepatic duct
answers_info.Explanation: The cystic artery is typically a branch off of the right hepatic artery, not the left hepatic artery.

answers_info.Text: branch off of the right hepatic artery, originating anterior to the common hepatic duct
answers_info.Explanation: The cystic artery is a branch off of the right hepatic artery but typically originates posterior (not anterior) to the common hepatic duct because the hepatic artery is typically posterior to the hepatic duct.

answers_info.Text: branch off of the right hepatic artery, originating posterior to the common hepatic duct
branch off of the gastroduodenal artery, originating posterior to the common hepatic duct
answers_info.Explanation: The cystic artery is typically a branch off of the right hepatic artery, not the gastroduodenal artery.

references.Name: Manatakis DK, Antonopoulou MI, Tasis N, et al. Critical view of safety in laparoscopic cholecystectomy: a systematic review of current evidence and future perspectives. World J Surg. 2023;47(3):640-648.
Ibrarullah M, Mohanty L, Mishra A, et al. Anatomical appraisal of safe cholecystectomy: a prospective study. ANZ J Surg. 2023;93(5):1329-1334.
Gallbladder and biliary tree. In: Cameron JL, Cameron AM, eds. Current Surgical Therapy. 14th ed. Elsevier; 2023.

1046467.hint: Consider where the cystic artery commonly originates in relation to the hepatic ducts. Pay attention to the relationship between the hepatic artery and its branches, especially in the context of the hepatocystic triangle.

647377.question: A male patient with gastroparesis comes to the office with persistent complaints of bloating and inability to tolerate a diet. He is normoglycemic and has tried dietary modifications as well as medical therapy with metoclopramide and erythromycin. The most appropriate next step in management is
answers: add cisapride to the medical management

explanation.BottomLine: Pyloroplasty is a surgical option for gastroparesis.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Patients with gastroparesis that is refractory to dietary modifications and medical management can be offered several surgical options. The most common and effective procedures thus far are insertion of gastric pacemaker and pyloroplasty.

Other options that have been tried include endoscopy with botox injections or stent placement, but these have not been shown to be effective. As a last resort, some patients may need to have a surgical feeding tube placed or started on total parenteral nutrition if their nutritional state is critical, but it should be used only once all other options have failed.

answers_info.Explanation: Metoclopramide can have serious side effects such as tardive dyskinesia and should be used with caution.
Stent placement has not been shown to be an effective treatment.
A feeding tube is a last resort once all other options have been exhausted.

answers_info.Text: add cisapride to the medical management
answers_info.Explanation: Cisapride use has been discontinued due to its side effect profile which includes prolonged QT syndrome and sudden cardiac arrest.

references.Name: The Stomach. In: Cameron JL, Cameron AM, eds. Current Surgical Therapy. 12th Ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2017.

647377.hint: Consider the surgical options for managing symptoms that have not improved with dietary or medical interventions. Which procedure specifically addresses the outlet of the stomach?

1042974.question: A 55-year-old man comes to the clinic with a 3-month history of abdominal pain, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue. He reports subjective fever and chills. Physical examination is unremarkable. CT scan shows an 8-cm homogenous pancreatic head mass with extensive peripancreatic lymphadenopathy and without significant pancreatic or biliary ductal dilations. CA 19-9 is normal. Liver function tests and bilirubin are normal. The mass is biopsied under endoscopic ultrasound guidance and demonstrates aberrant B-cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
answers: main duct intraductal papillary ductal neoplasm

explanation.BottomLine: Primary pancreatic lymphoma typically presents with constitutional symptoms, a palpable abdominal mass, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (and beta-2 microglobulin), and a normal serum CA 19-9.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient presents with a large pancreatic head mass and constitutional symptoms, most consistent with primary pancreatic lymphoma. Typical symptoms, as seen in this patient, include abdominal pain and constitutional symptoms associated, with other B-cell lymphomas (weight loss, fever, and night sweats). Jaundice is uncommon. Labs suggestive of the diagnosis include elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), elevated beta-2 microglobulin level, and a normal serum CA 19–9. CT imaging will show a large poorly enhancing homogenous mass with peripancreatic lymphadenopathy. Pancreatic ductal dilation is uncommon, as is vascular invasion. Extensive lymphadenopathy distant from the pancreas or in the mediastinum should raise suspicion for lymphoma secondarily involving the pancreas. Formal diagnosis is typically made with flow cytometric analysis of aspirate specimens obtained by endoscopic US with fine needle aspiration or by CT-guided biopsy. 

Primary pancreatic lymphoma is a rare pancreatic tumor accounting for < 1% of primary pancreatic tumors and < 2% of extranodal lymphomas. They are typically diffuse, large B cell lymphomas. Risk factors include immunosuppression from HIV or transplantation. Primary pancreatic lymphomas are typically large and located in the head where more lymphatic tissue is present, and surrounding lymphadenopathy is common. It can occur at any age, but typically presents in the fifth or sixth decade and has a slight male predilection. 


Pancreatic lymphoma. CT of the abdomen, showing a well-defined, homogeneous, hypovascular focal mass at the head of the pancreas (arrow).

Treatment of primary pancreatic lymphoma is with chemotherapy. The typical regimens are CHOP (cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin hydrochloride (hydroxydaunorubicin), vincristine sulfate (Oncovin), and prednisone) or R-CHOP (addition of rituximab). Surgery is reserved most typically for nondiagnostic biopsies and should be avoided. The 5-year overall survival is 36-61% with younger patients generally outliving older patients.

1042974.modifier: Weight Loss, Fatigue, Chills, Abdominal Mass

answers_info.Explanation: Walled-off pancreatic necrosis can present with fever, abdominal pain, and vague constitutional symptoms but would be a heterogenous thick-walled collection on axial imaging, not a homogenous solid mass, and would not typically present with an indolent 3-month course, but rather follow an episode of severe acute pancreatitis.

answers_info.Text: main duct intraductal papillary ductal neoplasm
answers_info.Explanation: Imaging typical of main duct intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN) would be a poorly demarcated, lobular, polycystic neoplasm with significant pancreatic ductal dilation, not a large homogenous mass. Constitutional symptoms are also not consistent with IPMN. Main duct IPMNs should typically be resected.

Pancreatic adenocarcinoma of the head of the pancreas typically presents with jaundice and/or pancreatic ductal dilation and elevated levels of CA 19-9. Large masses are typically heterogeneous with areas of necrosis. Note that CA 19-9 requires the presence of the Lewis blood group antigen and 5-10% of the population will not express this and, therefore, CA 19-9 will not be useful in these individuals.

Mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCNs) typically are thick-walled macrocyst that may or may not have a solid component, not homogenous solid masses. Constitutional symptoms are also not consistent with MCNs. They are most commonly present in the body or tail and have a strong female predilection (10:1).

references.Name: Dunphy L, Abbas SH, Al Shoek I, et al. Primary Pancreatic lymphoma: a rare clinical entity. BMJ Case Rep. 2020;13(1):e231292.
Li Z, Zhang S, Vasdani N, Castillo E. Clues for diagnosing primary pancreatic lymphoma. Case Rep Gastroenterol. 2012;6(2):438-445.
Clinical manifestations, diagnosis, and staging of exocrine pancreatic cancer: UpToDate
Image source:
CT of pancreatic lymphoma: Open-i

1042974.hint: Consider the patient's significant constitutional symptoms and the findings from the CT scan. Look for a diagnosis that is characteristic of a large pancreatic mass with associated lymphadenopathy and normal CA 19-9 levels.

908544.question: A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency department after an unhelmeted motorcycle collision at 60 miles per hour. The primary and secondary surveys reveal a pulse rate of 120/min, blood pressure of 80/30 mm Hg, Glasgow Coma Score of 6, gross deformity of the bilateral thigh, and Morel-Lavallee lesion of the left flank. The e-FAST is inconclusive. The patient is intubated, and a massive transfusion protocol is initiated. Subsequent CT scans show multicompartmental intracranial hemorrhage without shift or herniation and trace free fluid intra-abdominally. Labs reveal the following: WBC is 11,000 L, hemoglobin is 9 g/dL, and platelets are 240 x 109/L. The basic metabolic panel is within normal limits. What is the most important principle in the acute management of this patient's injuries?
answers: maintain cerebral perfusion pressure at or above 50 mm Hg
maintain systolic blood pressure at or above 110 mm Hg
allow for permissive hypotension with a mean arterial pressure goal of 50 mm Hg
utilize a liberal transfusion strategy with a hemoglobin goal of 10 g/dL
employ hyperventilation techniques to achieve a PaCO<sub>2</sub> < 35 mm Hg
908544.correct_answer: maintain systolic blood pressure at or above 110 mm Hg

explanation.BottomLine: In patients with traumatic brain injury and intracranial hemorrhage, maintaining arterial perfusion and avoiding hypoxia and hypotension is critical, including during interventions for extracranial hemorrhage.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient presents with polytrauma, intracranial hemorrhage, and hemorrhagic shock after a motorcycle collision. Precise and early control of hemorrhage is a priority. However, in the presence of concurrent traumatic brain injury (TBI), it is imperative to avoid and minimize secondary brain insults, such as hypoxia and arterial hypotension. 

According to guidelines from the Brain Trauma Foundation, systolic blood pressure should be maintained at ≥ 100 mm Hg for patients 50–69 years or ≥ 110 mm Hg for patients 15–49 years and those > 70 years. The traditional threshold of hypotension at 90 mm Hg may be too low according to observational studies.

answers_info.Text: maintain cerebral perfusion pressure at or above 50 mm Hg
answers_info.Explanation: Cerebral perfusion pressure should be maintained above 60 mm Hg.

answers_info.Text: maintain systolic blood pressure at or above 110 mm Hg
allow for permissive hypotension with a mean arterial pressure goal of 50 mm Hg
answers_info.Explanation: In patients without TBI, permissive hypotension may be beneficial in a setting of hemorrhagic shock. However, arterial hypotension is detrimental in the setting of TBI.

answers_info.Text: utilize a liberal transfusion strategy with a hemoglobin goal of 10 g/dL
answers_info.Explanation: There is no significant survival benefit or improvement in neurological recovery with the use of a liberal transfusion strategy compared to a restrictive strategy (threshold hemoglobin < 7 g/dL) in patients with TBI. The use of a transfusion threshold of 10 g/dL is actually associated with a higher incidence of adverse events. However, a threshold > 7 g/dL may be considered in patients with other risk factors (eg, cardiovascular disease).

answers_info.Text: employ hyperventilation techniques to achieve a PaCO<sub>2</sub> < 35 mm Hg
answers_info.Explanation: This patient does not have herniation or shift suggestive of risk for herniation; therefore, acute strategies for brain herniation are unnecessary at the moment. Hypocapnia, induced by hyperventilation, is also known to be associated with the risk of development of cerebral ischemia and worsened neurological outcomes after TBI.

references.Name: Picetti E, Rossi S, Abu-Zidan FM, et al. WSES consensus conference guidelines: monitoring and management of severe adult traumatic brain injury patients with polytrauma in the first 24 hours. World J Emerg Surg. 2019;14:53.
Carney N, Totten AM, O'Reilly C, et al. Guidelines for the Management of Severe Traumatic Brain Injury, Fourth Edition. Neurosurgery. 2017;80(1):6-15.

908544.hint: Consider how you would prioritize the management of a patient with head trauma and signs of shock. Focus on maintaining stability in vital signs, especially blood pressure, in the context of potential brain injury.

698305.question: A 44-year-old woman who is 4 years after laparoscopic adjustable gastric band presents with erythema and tenderness at the abdominal port site. Abdominal x-ray shows the gastric band positioned from left lateral superior to right medial inferior, and a phi angle of 40. Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
answers: prolapse of the proximal stomach above the band

explanation.BottomLine: Erosion of a gastric band into the stomach is rare and may present with erythema surrounding the subcutaneous port.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
When patients with laparoscopic adjustable gastric bands present with erythema and tenderness around their port site, an underlying inflammatory process must be suspected. Band erosion should be high on the differential and can be easily diagnosed by upper endoscopy. If confirmed, treatment involves removal of the band and closure of the gastric defect.

The described abdominal x-ray findings show a normal port position with an oblique angle from the left lateral superior position to the right medial inferior position. Additionally, phi angles between 4-58° are considered normal.

698305.modifier: Erythema And Tenderness Around Port Site

answers_info.Explanation: Patients who receive laparoscopic adjustable gastric bands are not at risk for marginal ulceration.

Band slippage can compromise blood supply to the proximal segment and warrants emergent reduction. This should not cause cellulitis or erythema over the port site. Additionally, this would show an abnormal phi angle.
Kinks in the tubing from the port to the band may occur. They will not normally present with symptoms of infections.

answers_info.Text: prolapse of the proximal stomach above the band
answers_info.Explanation: Gastric prolapse can compromise the blood supply to the proximal segment and warrants emergent reduction. This should not cause cellulitis or erythema over the port site. Additionally, the kidney, ureter, and bladder x-ray would not show a normal phi angle but rather distension of the proximal stomach.

references.Name: Courcoulas AP, Schauer PR. Chapter 27: The Surgical Management of Obesity. In: Brunicardi FC, Andersen DK, Billiar TR, Dunn DL, Kao LS, Hunter JG, Matthews JB, Pollock RE, eds. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery. 11th ed. McGraw Hill; 2019:1167-1219.
Sonavane SK, Menias CO, Kantawala KP, et al. Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding: what radiologists need to know. Radiographics. 2012;32(4):1161-78.

698305.hint: Consider the relationship between the symptoms at the port site and the potential complications associated with adjustable gastric bands. What could cause erythema and tenderness in this context?

462701.question: What is the primary source of bilirubin in the body?

explanation.BottomLine: The primary source of bilirubin is senescent red blood cells.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: The primary source of bilirubin in the body is from breakdown of red blood cells. Whether due to aged cells or active hemolysis, hemoglobin is broken down into bilirubin and ultimately secreted into bile.

answers_info.Explanation: The entero-hepatic circulation is the secretion of bile salts by the liver into the intestine, followed by absorption by the ileum, and return of the bile salts to the liver via the portal vein. The entero-hepatic circulation is not a primary source of bilirubin.

Cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid are the primary bile acids. They are conjugated with either taurine or glycine and function to digest fats and oils. Conjugated bile acids are not a source of bilirubin.
Enzymatic breakdown of leukocytes adds little to the stores of bilirubin.
Bacterial conjugation of hemoglobin occurs in the colon, but it is not the primary source of bilirubin.

references.Name: The Liver. In: Townsend C et al., eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 20th Ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2017.

462701.hint: Consider what happens to red blood cells as they age. Which type of cells would be involved in the process that leads to the formation of bilirubin?

986561.question: A 3-year-old male weighing 15 kg presents to the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. An extensive workup reveals a bowel obstruction secondary to Meckel diverticulum. The patient is resuscitated and taken to the OR, where an exploratory laparotomy and small bowel resection are performed. In the postoperative period, he appears euvolemic but requires maintenance fluid administration because of inadequate oral intake. He has normal renal function, and his serum potassium level is 4.0 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate choice of maintenance fluid for this patient?
answers: 0.45% saline with 20 mEq/L of potassium and 5% dextrose at 50 mL/hr
0.9% saline with 20 mEq/L of potassium and 5% dextrose at 50 mL/hr
986561.correct_answer: 0.9% saline with 20 mEq/L of potassium and 5% dextrose at 50 mL/hr

explanation.BottomLine: Isotonic fluids (typically 0.9% saline) with the addition of potassium and dextrose should be the initial maintenance fluid choice in the euvolemic pediatric population. The "4-2-1 rule" is the easiest way to estimate the desired infusion rate.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The goal of maintenance fluid therapy is to preserve water and electrolyte balance in euvolemic pediatric patients and to avoid hypoglycemia by providing sufficient glucose.

Noting the high variability in fluid prescribing practices and a lack of guidelines for fluid composition administration and electrolyte monitoring, the American Academy of Pediatrics released an evidence-based guideline in 2018 that suggests patients 28 days to 18 years of age requiring maintenance IV fluids should receive isotonic solutions with potassium and dextrose, which significantly decreases the risk of developing hyponatremia. Hospitalized children are at higher risk of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone release, which can lead to hyponatremia. Hypotonic fluid resuscitation can exacerbate this process.

The easiest way to determine the rate for maintenance fluids is the classic "4-2-1 rule": 4 mL/hr for the first 10 kg of body weight; 2 mL/hr for each kg of body weight from 11–20 kg; 1 mL/hr for each additional kg of body weight over 20 kg. For example, this 15-kg child would require (4 mL/hr x 10) + (2 mL/hr x 5) = 50 mL/hr.

986561.modifier: Isotonic Fluids With Potassium And Dextrose

answers_info.Explanation: Isotonic maintenance fluids should be used in euvolemic pediatric patients. In hypovolemic patients with water losses such as intractable diarrhea, there is a net negative water balance and increased serum sodium. In these cases, hypotonic saline and a more rapid rate of fluid resuscitation should be used. In addition, potassium should be supplemented to avoid the development of hypokalemia.

answers_info.Text: 0.45% saline with 20 mEq/L of potassium and 5% dextrose at 50 mL/hr
answers_info.Explanation: Isotonic maintenance fluids should be used in the pediatric population, with 50 mL/hr being the correct rate for this patient.
Guidelines recommend the addition of appropriate potassium chloride to maintenance fluids in the pediatric population, and 45 mL/hr is the incorrect rate for this patient.

answers_info.Text: 0.9% saline with 20 mEq/L of potassium and 5% dextrose at 50 mL/hr

answers_info.Explanation: Lactated Ringer's is an isotonic solution but does not adequately address the electrolyte requirements of the euvolemic pediatric population. Dextrose should be added as well to prevent hypoglycemia.

references.Name: Chapter 39: Pediatric surgery. In: Brunicardi FC, ed. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery. 11th ed. McGraw-Hill; 2019.
Feld LG, Neuspiel DR, Foster BA, et al. Clinical practice guideline: maintenance intravenous fluids in children. Pediatrics. 2018;142(6):e20183083.
Maintenance intravenous fluid therapy in children: UpToDate
Pediatric fluid management: StatPearls

986561.hint: Consider the child's current condition and requirements for maintenance fluids. Pay attention to the electrolyte balance and the need for glucose in the maintenance fluid. Remember the guidelines for isotonic fluids in the pediatric population.

1036827.question: A 65-year-old, otherwise healthy man undergoes a pancreaticoduodenectomy for pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Despite the return of bowel function by postoperative day 6, he has persistent nausea and vomiting. He also complains of mild abdominal pain. His vitals are a temperature of 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse rate of 105/min, blood pressure of 130/65 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation of 95% on a 2 L nasal cannula. His WBC count is 14.1 x 109/L. Prolonged passage of contrast past the gastrojejunostomy is demonstrated in an upper GI study. What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's management?

explanation.BottomLine: Delayed gastric emptying is the most common complication after pancreaticoduodenectomy. However, it is important to consider other complications, such as a leak or abscess, which may present with subtle signs. Once other suspected complications are ruled out, treatment is mainly supportive, consisting of nutritional support and prokinetics.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient has undergone a Whipple procedure for pancreatic adenocarcinoma and presents with symptoms (persistent nausea/vomiting despite the return of bowel function) and upper GI study findings suggestive of delayed gastric emptying, a common postoperative phenomenon after pancreaticoduodenectomy.
He is also displaying signs of sepsis (fever, mild tachycardia, and leukocytosis). Whether a leak or an abscess is present, the most appropriate next step is to obtain a contrast-enhanced CT scan to look for the source. 

Once sepsis is ruled out or has been controlled, management of delayed gastric emptying is mainly supportive, consisting of nasogastric decompression, distal enteric nutrition (nasojejunal tube or intraoperatively placed surgical J-tube) or parenteral nutrition if enteric access is unavailable, and the use of prokinetic agents. Prokinetic agents such as erythromycin and metoclopramide can increase the rate of gastric emptying and, as such, improve gastric emptying. The majority of cases are resolved with supportive care alone.

Surgery is rarely indicated in patients with delayed gastric emptying; however, chronic, refractory cases may require revision by completion or subtotal gastrectomy.

1036827.modifier: CT With Contrast Is The Best Study

answers_info.Explanation: Ambulation and chewing gum are treatments for postoperative ileus. Early ambulation, while commonly recommended, is actually not supported by strong evidence. Of note, chewing gum has been demonstrated by a few randomized controlled trials to be beneficial. A septic workup including a CT scan is the most appropriate next step for this patient.

Nutritional support should be considered in the setting of prolonged delayed gastric emptying. This can be in the form of enteral nutrition via nasojejunostomy/surgical jejunostomy tube (ideally placed at the time of index surgery) or total parenteral nutrition. However, sepsis should be ruled out first.
Prokinetics may help in the management of delayed gastric emptying. However, the source of sepsis should be assessed in this patient first.
Reexploration in the OR is too aggressive at this point. The patient is hemodynamically stable; thus, the next step is to work up the patient for a source of sepsis.

references.Name: Busquets J, Martín S, Secanella L, et al. Delayed gastric emptying after classical Whipple or pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy: a randomized clinical trial (QUANUPAD). Langenbecks Arch Surg. 2022;407(6):2247-2258.
Simon R. Complications after pancreaticoduodenectomy. Surg Clin North Am. 2021;101(5):865-874.
Glowka TR, Webler M, Matthaei H, et al. Delayed gastric emptying following pancreatoduodenectomy with alimentary reconstruction according to Roux-en-Y or Billroth-II. BMC Surg. 2017;17(1):24.
Liu N, Abell T. Gastroparesis updates on pathogenesis and management. Gut Liver. 2017;11(5):579-589.

1036827.hint: Consider the patient's vital signs and lab results. High white blood cell count and fever can indicate potential complications that need to be addressed. What imaging study could help identify the source?

682271.question: What is the most common cause of jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis?

explanation.BottomLine: If a patient presents with a history of pharyngitis, recurrent fever, and septic pulmonary embolism, jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis should be suspected.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis is frequently caused by pharyngitis, especially in association with tonsil or peritonsillar infections. If a patient has unrelenting fever, septic pulmonary emboli, and a history of pharyngitis, jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis should be suspected.

answers_info.Explanation: Intravenous drug use is commonly associated with peripheral vein suppurative thrombophlebitis.
Septic pulmonary embolus can result from jugular vein suppurative thrombophlebitis, but is not the cause.
Deep vein thrombosis may cause pulmonary embolus, but it is very unlikely that the embolus will travel to the jugular vein.
Peripheral blood draws and placement of lines can cause peripheral vein suppurative thrombophlebitis, but will not cause jugular vein involvement.

references.Name: Suppurative (septic) thrombophlebitis: UpToDate

682271.hint: Consider conditions that commonly affect the throat and lead to complications involving blood vessels.

997901.question: Which of the following is the most common etiology of end-stage renal disease that leads to a renal transplant in the United States?

explanation.BottomLine: The most common indication for renal transplantation in the United States is diabetes mellitus, followed by hypertension, cystic kidney disease, and renal carcinoma.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: The indications for renal transplantation include end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and renal tumors. It is well-documented that renal transplantation prolongs a patient's lifespan compared with dialysis. Even still, only 25% of adult patients on dialysis are being referred for transplant evaluation, and the number of potential candidates has resulted in growing waitlists and longer waiting times for patients in need of kidney transplants.

answers_info.Explanation: Glomerulonephritis is not the most common cause of ESRD that leads to a renal transplant in the United States.
AIDS is not the most common cause of ESRD that leads to renal transplant in the United States.
Urolithiasis is not the most common cause of ESRD that leads to renal transplant in the United States.
While essential hypertension is a close second, the most common cause of ESRD that leads to renal transplant is diabetes mellitus.

references.Name: Becker Y, Witkowski P. Chapter 26: Kidney and Pancreas Transplantation. In: Townsend C, Beauchamp RD, Evers BM, Mattox KL, eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 20th ed. Elsevier; 2017:649-665.

997901.hint: Consider the major chronic conditions that can lead to serious complications, including kidney issues. One common condition is especially pervasive in adults and is often linked with metabolic changes.

875401.question: A 45-year-old man with poorly differentiated laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma secondary to human papillomavirus is scheduled to undergo radiation therapy. On CT imaging, the tumor is large, outgrowing the limits of its blood supply. After several weeks of radiotherapy, there is minimal response, and the tumor appears to have grown in size. Which of the following best explains the tumor's resistance to radiotherapy in this patient?
answers: low levels of oxygen free radicals
location in the larynx vs the oral cavity
presence of poorly differentiated tumor cells
875401.correct_answer: low levels of oxygen free radicals

explanation.BottomLine: Hypoxia resulting from low oxygen tension in tumors is associated with increased resistance to radiation and is a predictor of poor outcomes. Radiation is enhanced by the presence of oxygen as ionization leads to the formation of free oxygen radicals that results in DNA damage and cell death. Well-oxygenated cells are up to 3 times more radiosensitive than hypoxic cells.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
