This patient has advanced head and neck cancer with a tumor outgrowing the limits of its blood supply, rendering it hypoxic with low intratumor oxygen tension, and therefore resistant to radiation therapy due to low levels of oxygen free radical formation. Multiple studies have demonstrated that tumor hypoxia is strongly associated with radioresistance, thus a predictor of poor clinical outcomes.  

The mechanism linking hypoxia to tumor radioresistance is related to the oxygen enhancement effect. Damage to DNA is induced by direct ionization or from oxygen free radicals that are formed by the ionization of water surrounding the DNA. DNA strands that break and that are unrepaired result in cell death. In the absence of oxygen, DNA damage is more readily repairable. This is because oxygen can interact with the broken ends of DNA, creating organic peroxides that are not easily repaired by the cell. Additionally, oxygen prolongs the life span of highly reactive free radicals. Well-oxygenated cells are up to 3 times more radiosensitive than hypoxic cells. Intratumor hypoxia may be chronic when the tumor outgrows the limits of its blood supply, or acute resulting from a disruption of microregional blood flow. 

Factors Associated With Radiation Resistance
Hypoxia
Smoking status
Inherent tumor cell characteristics
Repopulation
Tumor location
Tumor grade


OER: Oxygen enhancement ratio
Dhypox: Dose in hypoxia
Dnormox: Dose in normal oxygen tension
ROS: Reactive oxygen species

answers_info.Explanation: This patient likely has decreased intratumor oxygen tension as a result of his large tumor that has outgrown its blood supply, not increased intratumor oxygen tension; therefore, this answer is incorrect. Additionally, it is decreased intratumor oxygen tension that leads to radiation resistance, not increased oxygen tension.

This patient has human papillomavirus (HPV)-positive head and neck cancer, which is associated with enhanced sensitivity to radiation; therefore, this answer is incorrect. Being HPV-positive is associated with improved prognosis due to their enhanced sensitivity to chemotherapy and radiation.

answers_info.Text: low levels of oxygen free radicals
location in the larynx vs the oral cavity
answers_info.Explanation: This patient has a laryngeal squamous cell cancer, which is associated with a better response to radiation therapy compared to oropharyngeal cancers; therefore, this answer is incorrect.

answers_info.Text: presence of poorly differentiated tumor cells
answers_info.Explanation: This patient has a poorly differentiated tumor laryngeal cancer, which is more radiosensitive than well-differentiated cancers. This is because well-differentiated cancer cells retain their ability to accelerate repopulation during radiation therapy, making them more radioresistant than their poorly differentiated counterparts.

references.Name: Moeller BJ, Richardson RA, Dewhirst MW. Hypoxia and radiotherapy: opportunities for improved outcomes in cancer treatment. Cancer Metastasis Rev. 2007;26(2):241-248.
Head and neck cancers: NCCN
Methods to overcome radiation resistance in head and neck cancer: UpToDate

875401.hint: Consider the effects of tumor oxygen levels on radiation therapy effectiveness. Remember that lower oxygen levels can lead to resistance by reducing the formation of DNA-damaging free radicals.

723463.question: A 50-year-old man presents to the hospital for elective endovascular repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. On the day of discharge, it is discovered that he has developed a sudden onset of atrial fibrillation. His past medical history is only significant for a remote episode of spontaneous deep vein thrombosis many years ago. The patient is discharged home with long-term anticoagulation on warfarin. After 3 days, he presents with large areas of necrotic skin across his chest, bilateral buttocks, and thighs. Which of the following conditions is the most likely underlying etiology of his current presentation?

explanation.BottomLine: Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is more frequently seen in individuals diagnosed with protein C deficiency.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Warfarin therapy is one of the most commonly used regimens for anticoagulation due to its ability to be monitored and readily reversed. Other than bleeding, one of the known major complications of warfarin therapy is full-thickness skin necrosis and sloughing over fatty areas, such as the buttocks, the breast, and the thigh.

Warfarin-induced skin necrosis occurs because warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist and among the vitamin K-dependent factors, proteins C and S have relatively short half-lives of 8 and 30 hours compared to 48-72 hours for factors II, XI, and X. Consequently, this phenomenon is known to occur more frequently in individuals with hereditary protein C deficiency. This can usually be avoided by using a heparin or low-molecular-weight heparin "bridge" until the warfarin level is therapeutic.

answers_info.Explanation: Warfarin interferes with the gamma carboxylation of the vitamin K-dependent clotting factors such as II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S. Protein C deficiency is more common than protein S and, therefore, is the more likely answer.

Warfarin interferes with the gamma carboxylation of the vitamin K-dependent clotting factors such as II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S. Protein S will be inhibited, but that does not cause the presentation seen in this patient.
Warfarin interferes with the gamma carboxylation of the vitamin K-dependent clotting factors such as II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S.
Warfarin interferes with the gamma carboxylation of the vitamin K-dependent clotting factors such as II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S. Factor I deficiency should not be affected by warfarin.

references.Name: Henke P, Wakefield T. Chapter 6: Hemostasis. In: Mulholland MW, Lillemoe KD, Doherty GM, Upchurch Jr GR, Alam H, Pawlik TM, eds. Greenfield's Surgery: Scientific Principles and Practice. 6th ed. Wolters Kluwer; 2017:69-85.

723463.hint: Consider the relationship between skin necrosis and anticoagulation, particularly with warfarin. What factors are dependent on vitamin K, and which of them have shorter half-lives? This information may help you identify the underlying condition.

1025642.question: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He is treated with sublingual nitroglycerin and oxygen, and his pain improves. During his subsequent workup, he has a cardiac catheterization performed. A request is made to evaluate the patient for a possible coronary artery bypass grafting procedure. Based on the information obtained from the consultant cardiologist and the catheterization procedure, for which of the following conditions should non-operative management be recommended?
answers: acute coronary occlusion after percutaneous coronary intervention
hemodynamically significant lesions in the proximal circumflex and left anterior descending arteries
severe calcifications involving the right coronary artery, left anterior descending artery, and the circumflex artery

explanation.BottomLine: Cardiogenic shock can be treated with a combination of non-surgical means until the patient is stabilized and the cause is identified. If the cause is severe coronary artery disease amenable to bypass, surgical revascularization is indicated.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Cardiogenic shock alone does not necessitate surgical revascularization, and workup should be aimed at identifying an underlying cause. Initial management of cardiogenic shock consists of a combination of fluid resuscitation, inotropic support, percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), and mechanical support using devices such as the intra-arterial balloon pump or the Impella heart pump. These measures are temporizing and will need to be followed by definitive treatment once the patient is more stable.

Revascularization for patients with ischemic cardiac disease can be performed operatively (coronary artery bypass grafting [CABG]) or non-operatively (PCI).

Current clinical indications for PCI include high-risk lesions identified during cardiac stress testing, stable angina unresponsive to medical therapy, acute coronary syndrome (unstable angina, ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction, and non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction), and congestive heart failure with viable myocardium.

Current clinical indications for CABG include left main coronary artery stenosis > 50%, left anterior descending and circumflex artery stenosis > 70%, left anterior descending artery stenosis > 70% with ejection fraction < 50% or stress-induced ischemic changes, 3-vessel disease in stable or unstable patients, and failure to achieve or maintain revascularization after PCI.

answers_info.Text: acute coronary occlusion after percutaneous coronary intervention
answers_info.Explanation: Acute coronary occlusion after a failed PCI is an indication for emergency surgical revascularization. This suggests that the PCI (angioplasty with or without stenting) was not sufficient to maintain patency in the vessel.

answers_info.Text: hemodynamically significant lesions in the proximal circumflex and left anterior descending arteries
answers_info.Explanation: High-risk lesions in the major left-sided vessels (proximal circumflex and left anterior descending arteries) are unlikely to be treated successfully with PCI alone.

Left main coronary artery stenosis > 50%, with or without additional coronary artery disease, is an indication for surgical revascularization as having such a lesion increases the failure rate of PCI.

answers_info.Text: severe calcifications involving the right coronary artery, left anterior descending artery, and the circumflex artery
answers_info.Explanation: Three-vessel disease increases the failure rate of PCI and is an indication for surgical revascularization.

references.Name: Alvarez Villela M, Clark R, William P, Sims DB, Jorde UP. Systems of care in cardiogenic shock. Front Cardiovasc Med. 2021;8:712594.
van Diepen S, Katz JN, Albert NM, et al. Contemporary management of cardiogenic shock: a scientific statement from the American Heart Association. Circulation. 2017;136(16):e232-e268.

Mäkikallio T, Holm NR, Lindsay M, et al. Percutaneous coronary angioplasty versus coronary artery bypass grafting in treatment of unprotected left main stenosis (NOBLE): a prospective, randomised, open-label, non-inferiority trial. Lancet. 2016;388(10061):2743-2752.

1025642.hint: Consider the state of the patient's heart function and the immediate need for intervention. Think about conditions where the heart might be unable to pump effectively, and non-surgical means could be sufficient initially.

573179.question: A 57-year-old man presents to your clinic with a 2 cm retro-areolar mass in the right breast. He has a positive family history of breast cancer in his sister and ovarian cancer in his mother. He undergoes an ultrasound, mammogram, and a core-needle biopsy. This confirms the diagnosis of invasive breast cancer (ER/PR+, HER2neu-). His metastatic workup is negative and axilla is without lymphadenopathy. What is the next step in management?
answers: lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy

explanation.BottomLine: Male breast cancer with a strong family history of malignancy should undergo genetic testing for BRCA mutation and be treated with mastectomy.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Male breast cancer is a rare disease for which there are no current randomized control trials. The current National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines recommend consideration of genetic testing for all men with breast cancer. BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene mutations have been associated with male breast cancers. Men with a strong family history of malignancy should undergo genetic testing for BRCA mutation. Surgical treatment for early stage/resectable disease includes mastectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy in men rather than breast conservation surgery.

If a patient has a known BRCA mutation, then prophylactic bilateral mastectomy can be considered. Thus, of the choices given, BRCA testing for surgical planning is the most appropriate next step. Indications for systemic chemotherapy are the same as in women. Indications for adjuvant hormonal therapy with tamoxifen and adjuvant trastuzumab are for ER+ and HER2neu+ patients but would be given after surgical resection of the tumor.

answers_info.Text: lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy
answers_info.Explanation: Most men with breast cancer are recommended to undergo mastectomy compared to breast conservation therapy and can be appropriately offered sentinel node biopsy instead of axillary lymph node dissection upfront. As is the case in female breast cancer, axillary staging is pivotal to prognosis. While breast conservation, partial mastectomy, and radiation is a viable option for some patients, it is technically challenging for patients with retro-areolar masses and should be reserved for patients with multiple comorbidities in addition to patients that are eligible for a nipple-sparing surgery. This is not the case as this patient has a retro-areolar mass and would likely need a mastectomy.

According to the NCCN guidelines, adjuvant (after surgery) chemotherapy is the standard of care for patients with tumors >0.5 cm, pathologically involved lymph nodes, or triple-negative tumors. Chemotherapy with or without HER2neu-targeted therapy should be recommended to men with breast cancer according to the guidelines stipulated for women. Preoperative systemic therapy is indicated in patients with locally advanced or inoperable breast cancers. For example, inflammatory breast cancer, Stage IIIA and IIIB (N2 or N3 lymph node nodal disease and T4 tumors).

Furthermore, randomized control trials have shown no significant difference in long-term outcomes when systemic chemotherapy is given before (neoadjuvant) or after surgery. Current guidelines recommend the use of a gene expression profile (Oncotype Dx) to determine the 10-year risk of recurrent and potential benefit of chemotherapy and/or tamoxifen.

It has been proposed that male breast cancer is similar to postmenopausal female breast cancer. While tamoxifen has been considered the standard of care for premenopausal women, randomized control trials have shown that aromatase inhibitors are superior to tamoxifen in an adjuvant role for postmenopausal women. Approximately 20% of male patients may discontinue tamoxifen due to side effects of hot flashes, decreased libido, mood changes, or venous thrombosis.

Male breast cancer patients are often hormone receptor positive with often higher rates of hormone receptor expression than female breast cancer patients. Estrogen receptor positivity as in women corresponds to a better prognosis. Patients that do not express hormone HER2neu receptors are not eligible for anti-HER2 therapy. For patients that are hormone positive, they should undergo adjuvant endocrine therapy.

references.Name: NCCN clinical practice guidelines in oncology. Breast cancer screening and diagnosis (version 3.2019). Ft. Washington, PA: National Comprehensive Cancer Network; 2019.
Fentiman IS. Surgical options for male breast cancer. Breast Cancer Res Treat. 2018;172(3):539-544.
Freedmam RA, Partridge AH. Emerging data and current challenges for young, old, obese, or male patients with breast cancer. Clin Cancer Res. 2017;23(11):2647-2654.
Block WD, Muradali D. Breast cancer in men. CMAJ. 2013;185(14):1247.
Sarmiento S, McColl M, Habibi M. Management of male breast cancer. In: Cameron JL, Cameron AM, eds. Current Surgical Therapy. 13th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:710-711.

573179.hint: Consider the significance of the patient's family history of cancers and the genetic implications that might arise from it. What kind of testing could help in understanding risk factors associated with his diagnosis?

774929.question: A 19-year-old man presents with an anterior shoulder dislocation that occurred while playing in a a football game. What nerve injury is most commonly associated with this type of injury?

explanation.BottomLine: Axillary nerve is the most commonly injured nerve associated with anterior shoulder dislocations.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Anterior shoulder dislocations, as in this patient, typically involve the head of the humerus moving anterior and inferior from the glenoid fossa. The most commonly injured nerve secondary to anterior shoulder dislocations is axillary nerve injury. They commonly occur from a fall onto an abducted and externally rotated upper extremity. In the management of an acute shoulder dislocation, it is important to examine the patient carefully for evidence of neurovascular injury before reduction is attempted, and also after reduction has been achieved. Based on clinical diagnosis alone, the reported incidence of nerve injuries ranged from 3-21%, while using electromyography (EMG), the incidence ranged from 19-65%. Factors that have been associated with higher risks of nerve injuries include being in an older age group (above 50 years), a higher degree of trauma that resulted in the dislocation, and the duration of the dislocation.

The axillary nerve supplies 3 muscle groups: deltoid, teres minor, and triceps brachii (long head). It also supplies sensory innervation to the shoulder joint and the skin covering the inferior deltoid.

answers_info.Explanation: Ulnar nerve injuries can occur with anterior shoulder dislocations, but they are not the most common nerve injury. Ulnar nerve injuries are more commonly seen with elbow fractures. Symptoms include decreased sensation of the ring and little finger, decreased strength of the intrinsic muscles of the hand—reduced grip, and inability to flex the 4th and 5th fingers.

Median nerve injuries can occur with anterior shoulder dislocations, but they are not the most common nerve injury. A median nerve injury is more commonly injured in cases of supracondylar humerus fractures. Symptoms of median nerve injury include the inability to abduct the thumb (move the thumb across the palm) and flex the 2nd and 3rd fingers.

Radial nerve injuries can occur with anterior shoulder dislocations, but they are not the most common nerve injury. A radial nerve injury is more commonly injured in cases of supracondylar humerus fractures. It leads to an inability to extend the wrist.

Musculocutaneous nerve injuries can occur with anterior shoulder dislocations, but they are not the most common nerve injury. This nerve controls the biceps, brachialis and coracobrachialis muscles (injury leads to reduced elbow flexion), and provides sensation to the radial side of the forearm.

references.Name: Dawson J, Atassi O, Sun D, Sheth M. Chapter 19: Emergency Care of Musculoskeletal Injuries. In: Townsend C, Beauchamp RD, Evers BM, Mattox KL, eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:440-483.
Yeap JS, Lee DJ, Fazir M, et al. Nerve injuries in anterior shoulder dislocations. Med J Malaysia. 2004;59(4):450-4.

774929.hint: Think about the nerve that primarily affects the muscles around the shoulder, particularly those involved in arm movement. It is often related to injuries that occur when the shoulder is dislocated forward.

985455.question: A 38-year-old woman presents to the surgery clinic complaining of several days of right breast pain. Past medical history significant for one miscarriage and no familial history of cancer. She reports no past surgical history. Physical examination reveals a tender, subcutaneous cord in the lateral aspect of the breast. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?

explanation.BottomLine: Mondor disease is benign and self-limited. This condition should be treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Thrombophlebitis of the lateral thoracic or superior thoracoepigastric vein (also known as Mondor disease) is characterized by the presence of a tender, subcutaneous cord in the breast tissue. Mondor disease is commonly associated with history of hypercoagulable state, trauma, surgical procedures or biopsy of the breast, or breast irradiation. However, at least half of cases are idiopathic.

The condition is benign and self-limited. Treatment is symptomatic with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and warm compresses. Further investigation with imaging may be required if the condition fails to resolve by around 4 to 6 weeks. Occasionally, Mondor disease is associated with an underlying breast cancer.
Arrows indicate tender, subcutaneous cord in the breast tissue.

answers_info.Explanation: Mondor disease resolves spontaneously and requires no specific therapy except reassurance and sometimes anti-inflammatory agents for pain relief. Surgical treatment is not usually required unless the condition persists despite conservative management.

Mondor disease resolves spontaneously and should be treated with anti-inflammatory agents for pain relief. A mammogram should be considered if the condition is persistent despite conservative management, or other clinical features cause concern for underlying breast cancer. Thrombophlebitis causes pain due to the local inflammatory reaction that occurs at the site of the vessel. While acetaminophen is useful for pain relief, the anti-inflammatory effects of NSAIDs at the local, immunologic level, are more potent.
Tamoxifen is used to treat women with mastalgia but does not have a role in the treatment of Mondor disease.

Anticoagulation is not indicated for treatment of Mondor disease. It should be noted, however, that occasionally Mondor disease can be a manifestation of a hypercoagulability disorder such as Factor V Leiden.

references.Name: Dixon JM, Macaskill EJ. Chapter 3: Benign breast conditions. In: Dixon JM, Barber MD, eds. Breast Surgery: A Companion to Specialist Surgical Practice. 6th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2019:27-45.
Breast Cellulitis and Other Skin Disorders of the Breast on UpToDate
Image source: Indian J Plast Surg

985455.hint: Consider the typical management approach for conditions characterized by local inflammation and pain. Look for the type of medication that alleviates pain and has anti-inflammatory effects.

711778.question: Which of the following most accurately describes dopamine?
answers: a DA1/DA2 agonist at low doses, a β-agonist at moderate doses, and an α-agonist at high doses
a DA1/DA2 agonist at low doses, an α-agonist at moderate doses, and a β-agonist at high doses
711778.correct_answer: a DA1/DA2 agonist at low doses, a β-agonist at moderate doses, and an α-agonist at high doses

explanation.BottomLine: Dopamine is a DA1/DA2 agonist at low doses, a β-agonist at moderate doses, and an α-agonist at high doses.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Dopamine is a broad-spectrum endogenous, sympathetic amine that functions as a central and peripheral neurotransmitter. At low doses (1-3 mg/kg/min), dopamine increases renal blood flow and maintains diuresis through DA1//DA2 receptor stimulation in the renal vasculature. At moderate doses (5-10 mg/kg/min), it increases contractility and cardiac output via stimulation of cardiac β-receptors. At higher doses (> 10 mg/kg/min), peripheral vasoconstriction from increasing α-activity becomes more prominent, resulting in elevation of systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure.

711778.modifier: DA1 DA2 Agonist At Low Doses; Agonist At High

answers_info.Text: a DA1/DA2 agonist at low doses, a β-agonist at moderate doses, and an α-agonist at high doses

answers_info.Explanation: Dobutamine has β-adrenergic effects without any α-activity. The predominant effect is an increase in cardiac contractility with little increase in heart rate from β1-stimulation. Dobutamine also has a peripheral vasodilating effect resulting from β2-receptor activation.

Norepinephrine exerts both α- and β1-adrenergic effects. At lower doses, the β1-adrenergic effects are most prominent leading to increases in heart rate and contractility. With higher doses, the α-adrenergic effect becomes evident and is responsible for increases in systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure.

Epinephrine stimulates β-adrenergic receptors, leading to an increase in heart rate and contractility (β1-effect), in conjunction with peripheral vasodilation (β2-effect) when given at low doses. At a higher dose, α-effects predominate, leading to an increase in systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure.

answers_info.Text: a DA1/DA2 agonist at low doses, an α-agonist at moderate doses, and a β-agonist at high doses
answers_info.Explanation: Dopamine has its effect as an α-agonist at high doses and as a β-agonist at moderate doses.

references.Name: Chapter 23: Adrenergic Mechanisms and Drugs. In: Brown M, Sharma P, Mir F, Bennett P. Clinical Pharmacology. 12th ed. Elsevier; 2019:403-414.

711778.hint: Consider the different receptor activities of dopamine at varying doses. Low doses tend to selectively affect certain receptors, while higher doses interact with different ones. What classes of agonists would apply at these doses?

884373.question: A 70-year-old man presents to the surgery clinic for follow-up after undergoing neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy for stage II rectal cancer located 3 cm from the anal verge. He has opted for a watch-and-wait approach because he would like to avoid an abdominoperineal resection. He asks when his chance of tumor recurrence is greatest during his post-treatment surveillance
answers: tumor recurrence is negligible in a watch-and-wait approach

explanation.BottomLine: A watch-and-wait approach involves a patient with rectal cancer receiving neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy and assessing clinical tumor response. If there is no evidence of cancer on physical exam, endoscopy, and MRI, then the patient can avoid undergoing rectal resection.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
About 10–25% of patients with rectal cancer who undergo neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy are found to have a complete pathologic response (no evidence of tumor in the surgical specimen) after resection of their tumor. From this information, the idea arose that in a subset of well-selected patients, neoadjuvant chemoradiation alone could be used to treat rectal cancer. 

A watch-and-wait approach involves a patient with rectal cancer receiving neoadjuvant chemoradiation therapy and assessing clinical tumor response. If there is no evidence of cancer on physical exam, endoscopy, and MRI, then the patient can avoid undergoing rectal resection. This approach is not standard of care at this time but is increasingly being trialed.

The advantages of a watch-and-wait approach are that it avoids the complications of abdominoperineal resection (APR) or low anterior resection (LAR), such as permanent ostomy (in the case of an APR), sexual dysfunction, urinary dysfunction, and increased postoperative mortality (2–30%). The disadvantages of this approach are that the rectum and surrounding tissue have not been definitively excised; therefore, there is a risk that tumor-positive lymph nodes are still present after treatment.

About 30% of patients with a complete clinical response after neoadjuvant chemoradiation will have local recurrence of their tumor within 2 years, which is why an aggressive tumor surveillance strategy with a combination of physical exam, endoscopy, and MRI is used in these patients every 3 months. If a recurrence is found, then the patient undergoes salvage rectal resection and total mesorectal excision.

answers_info.Explanation: While there is no accepted standard for follow-up, surveillance typically begins 3 months after completion of chemoradiation. Surveillance examination/imaging would not have begun at this point.
The majority of recurrences of rectal cancer in the watch-and-wait approach are found within 2 years after completion of chemoradiation.
The majority of recurrences of rectal cancer in the watch-and-wait approach are found within 2 years after completion of chemoradiation.

answers_info.Text: tumor recurrence is negligible in a watch-and-wait approach
answers_info.Explanation: Tumor recurrence does occur in 30% of rectal cancer patients who achieved a clinical complete response (which is a minority of patients) after neoadjuvant chemoradiation; thus, tumor recurrence is significant and, therefore, patients following a watch-and-wait protocol require frequent surveillance.

references.Name: Zhang X, Ding R, Li J, et al. Efficacy and safety of the “watch-and-wait” approach for rectal cancer with clinical complete response after neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy: a meta-analysis. Surg Endosc. 2022;36:2233-2244.
López-Campos F, Martín-Martín M, Fornell-Pérez R, et al. Watch and wait approach in rectal cancer: current controversies and future directions. World J Gastroenterol. 2020;26(29):4218-4239.

884373.hint: Consider the time frame in which most recurrences occur for patients who had neoadjuvant chemoradiation and chose a watch-and-wait approach. Focus on the first couple of years following treatment.

474533.question:
A 45-year-old male is brought to the emergency room by his family due to altered mental status, fever, chills and weakness for the last 2 days.  His vital signs are as follows: Temperature 102oF, HR 115 bpm, BP 90/65 mmHg, and RR 24 breaths per minute.  His white blood cell count is elevated with a left shift.  His medical history is significant for a car accident one year ago for which he underwent exploratory laparotomy with splenectomy.  He did not follow-up after leaving the hospital.

Which of the following is true?
answers: Blood cultures will most likely grow Streptococcus pyogenes
A CT of the abdomen will most likely be diagnostic
A lumbar puncture should be performed prior to starting antibiotics
Mortality rate for this disease is 15%
Intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone should be started
474533.correct_answer: Intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone should be started

explanation.BottomLine: OPSI is an uncommon condition with a very high mortality rate after splenectomy.  Broad spectrum antibiotics should be initiated immediately.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The patient in the question stem is exhibiting signs and symptoms concerning for overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI).  OPSI is an uncommon late complication of splenectomy, but is fatal in 50-70% of patients who present for medical attention for this indication. Routine post-splenectomy vaccination against encapsulated organisms can reduce the risk of this complication. Most infections occur more than 2 years after splenectomy, although infection may occur at any time. OPSI is characterized by fevers, rigors, chills, and other nonspecific symptoms, and is rapidly progressive. Many patients do not have an identifiable septic source, and only high-grade bacteremia is found on workup. Pneumonia, primary bacteremia, and meningitis are the most common septic sources in OPSI.

The most common causative organism is Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is implicated in at least 40-60% of OPSI cases. Haemophilus influenzae type b, Neisseria meningitidis, Capnocytophaga species, Bordetella holmesii, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli are other potential causative organisms.

Empiric treatment for suspected OPSI is a combination of vancomycin and ceftriaxone or cefotaxime. Antibiotics should be initiated immediately, and not delayed for diagnostic testing.

answers_info.Text: Blood cultures will most likely grow Streptococcus pyogenes
answers_info.Explanation: The most common infectious organisms in overwhelming post splenectomy infection is Streptococcus pneumoniae, which is implicated in 50-90% of OPSI cases. Other frequent causative organisms are Meningococcus, Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli.

answers_info.Text: A CT of the abdomen will most likely be diagnostic
answers_info.Explanation: The most common septic sources in OPSI are pneumonia, primary bacteremia, and meningitis. Therefore, a CT of the abdomen is unlikely to be diagnostic.

answers_info.Text: A lumbar puncture should be performed prior to starting antibiotics
answers_info.Explanation: Broad spectrum antibiotics should be started immediately if OPSI is suspected, and should not be delayed for diagnostic testing.

answers_info.Text: Mortality rate for this disease is 15%
answers_info.Explanation: Mortality rate for patients seeking medical attention for OPSI approaches 50%, and may be as high as 70%.

answers_info.Text: Intravenous vancomycin and ceftriaxone should be started

references.Name: Pasternack M. UpToDate: Clinical features, evaluation, and management of fever in patients with impaired splenic function. Updated Oct 5, 2018. Accessed Dec 11, 2018.
Poulose B and Holzman M. The Spleen. In Townsend C, Ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 20th edition. Elsevier: 2017, Chapter 56, 1556-1571.

474533.hint: Consider the potential complications that can arise after a splenectomy, particularly infections. Look for answers that address immediate treatment in case of septic conditions.

815493.question: A 34-year-old woman is brought into the emergency department by her roommate for lethargy and muscle spasms. The roommate reports the patient had been "binge-drinking." Her comprehensive metabolic panel is significant for a calcium level of 6.8 mg/dL and albumin of 3.2 g/dL. The patient receives 2 g of IV calcium gluconate, and the repeat calcium level is 6.9 mg/dL. What is the next best step in her management?
answers: change the calcium gluconate to calcium chloride

explanation.BottomLine: Hypomagnesaemia impairs parathyroid hormone secretion and may induce hypocalcemia refractory to calcium supplementation unless the hypomagnesemia is corrected.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient likely has hypomagnesemia, which is contributing to her refractory hypocalcemia.

Hypomagnesemia may occur because of poor nutritional intake, malabsorption, or increased renal excretion due to diuretics. Hypomagnesemia is common in patients abusing alcohol (as in this patient). In this population, the effect is caused by both dietary deficiency and the diuretic effect of alcohol. The signs and symptoms of hypomagnesemia are characterized by neuromuscular and CNS irritability and in this respect are similar to those seen with hypocalcemia such as fatigue, muscle spasms, weakness, or abnormal eye movements. Low serum magnesium levels appear to impair parathyroid hormone secretion and may induce hypocalcemia refractory to calcium supplementation unless the hypomagnesemia is corrected.

Common Causes of Hypocalcemia
Blood transfusion (formation of calcium citrate)
Hungry bone syndrome
Hypomagnesemia
Hypoparathyroidism
Medications (eg, furosemide, bisphosphonates)
Phosphate infusion (formation of calcium phosphate)
Pseudohypoparathyroidism
Renal disease
Vitamin D deficiency/altered metabolism

answers_info.Explanation: Hypophosphatemia is associated with diplopia, dysphagia, confusion, cardiac arrhythmias, and respiratory muscle weakness, not hypocalcemia.
Hypokalemia is associated with constipation, fatigue, and abnormal heart rhythms, not hypocalcemia. However, hypomagnesemia is often associated with hypokalemia due to urinary potassium wasting.

answers_info.Text: change the calcium gluconate to calcium chloride
answers_info.Explanation: Her hypocalcemia is refractory to IV repletion due to her hypomagnesemia, which should be confirmed by serum testing and replenished.
While this patient could have hypovolemic hyponatremia owing to her alcohol abuse, her symptoms and refractory hypocalcemia are more consistent with hypomagnesemia.

references.Name: Smith SG, Schreiber MA. Chapter 4: Shock, electrolytes, and fluid. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:44-94.
Treatment of hypocalcemia: UpToDate
Hypomagnesemia: Clinical manifestations of magnesium depletion: UpToDate

815493.hint: Consider the possibility of a deficiency related to mechanisms of calcium regulation. Look for the role of magnesium in influencing calcium levels, particularly in patients with a history of alcohol use.

730567.question: A 56-year-old woman is undergoing complete axillary lymphadenectomy (levels I–III) for malignant melanoma. During the surgery, the surgeon inadvertently transects the long thoracic nerve. What is the most likely result of this injury?
answers: winging of the scapula, shoulder pain, and inability to raise the arm above shoulder level
numbness and pain of the upper inner arm
pectoralis major muscle atrophy and limitation of shoulder motion
winging of the scapula, shoulder numbness, and inability to adduct the arm
730567.correct_answer: winging of the scapula, shoulder pain, and inability to raise the arm above shoulder level

explanation.BottomLine: Damage to the long thoracic nerve causes winging of the scapula, shoulder pain, and inability to raise the arm above shoulder level.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The long thoracic nerve is a pure motor nerve that innervates the serratus anterior. Damage to this nerve causes winging of the scapula, and due to the destabilization of the shoulder with loss of the function of the serratus anterior, causes musculoskeletal shoulder pain and inability to raise the arm above shoulder level.


The anatomical course of the long thoracic nerve in the neck and chest innervating the serratus anterior.

The long thoracic nerve typically courses longitudinally along the investing fascia of the lateral chest wall. It should be identified and preserved. The use of cautery should be limited in the axilla because it can transmit and cause damage to these nerves. Use clips and ties as necessary. Typically, there is no repair for a long thoracic nerve injury. However, some improvement may occur over time.


Right-sided "winging of scapula," a feature of long thoracic nerve palsy.

730567.modifier: Winging Scapula, Shoulder Pain, Can't Raise Arm

answers_info.Text: winging of the scapula, shoulder pain, and inability to raise the arm above shoulder level

answers_info.Explanation: Weakened arm pull-ups and adduction are caused by damage of the thoracodorsal nerve, which innervates the latissimus dorsi muscle.

answers_info.Text: numbness and pain of the upper inner arm
answers_info.Explanation: Numbness and pain of the upper inner arm are caused by damage of the intercostobrachial nerve.

answers_info.Text: pectoralis major muscle atrophy and limitation of shoulder motion
answers_info.Explanation: Pectoralis major muscle atrophy and limitation of shoulder motion are caused by damage to the lateral pectoral nerve.

answers_info.Text: winging of the scapula, shoulder numbness, and inability to adduct the arm
answers_info.Explanation: The scapula will exhibit winging but will also experience pain. The patient will have the inability to abduct the arm above shoulder level.

references.Name: Bloom S, Manasseh D-M. Chapter 45: Axillary surgery. In: Evans SRT, ed. Surgical Pitfalls: Prevention and Management. Elsevier; 2009:465-473.
Martin RM, Fish DE. Scapular winging: anatomical review, diagnosis, and treatments. Curr Rev Musculoskelet Med. 2008;1(1):1-11.
Image sources:
Winging of scapula: Wikipedia
Long thoracic nerve: Wikipedia

730567.hint: Consider the functions of the long thoracic nerve and the muscles it innervates. Think about what happens when this nerve is damaged and how it might affect shoulder movement.

663186.question: Which of the following immunoglobulins are found in the highest concentration in human breast milk?

explanation.BottomLine: Immunoglobulin A is present in secretions from mucosal surfaces such as saliva, tears, breast milk, and respiratory secretions.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Secretory immunoglobulin A (IgA) is produced by B cells located in mucosal linings of the body. It is the predominant antibody in saliva, tears, breast milk, and respiratory secretions. It is thought to protect against infection and neutralize toxins. Patients with IgA deficiency are found to have increased infections of the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

answers_info.Explanation: Immunoglobulin D has an unknown response in humoral immunity.
Immunoglobulin E is associated with immune response and allergic reactions due to its ability to degranulate mast cells and basophils.
Immunoglobulin G is the most common antibody found in serum and is the only maternal antibody found in a developing fetus.
Immunoglobulin M is the first antibody secreted in response to infection. It is a potent activator of the classic compliment cascade.

references.Name: Chapter 14: B cells. In: Firestein G, ed. Kelley’s Textbook of Rheumatology. 9th ed. Elsevier; 2012.

663186.hint: Consider which immunoglobulin is crucial for mucosal immunity and is known to be abundant in secretions like breast milk.

1058361.question: A 37-year-old man undergoes an elective laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair. During the dissection of the myopectineal orifice, a small venous bleeding is cauterized at the deep inguinal ring at the level of the iliopubic tract. Which of the following nerves is most likely at risk of injury?

explanation.BottomLine: The most common nerve injuries associated with laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair are to the genitofemoral and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves. The genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve enters the deep inguinal ring along with the cord structures.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The described anatomical location of cauterization puts the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve at risk for injury as it enters the deep inguinal ring along with the cord structures at the level of the iliopubic tract.

Nerve injuries during inguinal hernia repair can occur for several different reasons including transection, electrocautery, and entrapment. The most commonly injured nerves with laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair are the genitofemoral and lateral femoral cutaneous nerves.


Illustration of “5 triangles”: (A) Illustration of the iliopubic tract crossing the inverted Y and formation of the 5 triangles; (B) anatomical scheme of the inverted Y formed by inferior epigastric vessels, vas deferens, and spermatic vessels. The figure also illustrates, in a didactic way, the representation of 5 triangles, clockwise: indirect hernias (I), pain (P), doom (D), femoral (F), and direct (D) hernias.

answers_info.Explanation: The ilioinguinal nerve is encountered during an open repair as opposed to a laparoscopic repair because it courses between the transverse abdominis and the internal oblique muscles and emerges superficially by passing through the superficial inguinal ring anterior to the spermatic cord.

The iliohypogastric nerve is usually not encountered or at risk of injury during a laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair because it courses between the transverse abdominis and the internal oblique muscles like the ilioinguinal nerve.
The obturator nerve is inferior and medial to the deep inguinal ring. It enters the obturator canal.
The femoral nerve runs inferior to the level of the iliopubic tract and lateral to the femoral vessels. It does not enter the deep inguinal ring of the inguinal canal.

references.Name: Chapter 45: Hernias. In: Townsend C, Beauchamp RD, Evers BM, Mattox KL, eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:1105-1133.
Miller HJ. Inguinal hernia: mastering the anatomy. Surg Clin North Am. 2018;98(3):607-621.
Daes J, Felix E. Critical view of the myopectineal orifice. Ann Surg. 2017;266(1):e1-e2.

additional_image_sources.Name: Laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair (Figures 4 and 5): Arq Bras Cir Dig

1058361.hint: Consider the anatomical structures involved in the surgical procedure. Focus on the location of the cauterization and which nerves enter the inguinal region near the deep inguinal ring.

453783.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding tensile strength and wound healing?At 6 weeks, the wound is about 60% of its final tensile strength?
answers: The maximum tensile strength of a healed wound is equal to the skin's original strength
The maximum tensile strength is reached at about 6 weeks
At 8 weeks, the tensile strength is about 60% of its pre-wound strength
At 6 weeks, the wound is about 60% of its final tensile strength
The final tensile strength is dependent upon Type III collagen deposition
453783.correct_answer: At 6 weeks, the wound is about 60% of its final tensile strength

explanation.BottomLine: A wound has achieved its greatest tensile strength at 8 weeks.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: At 6 weeks the wound is 60% of its final tensile strength. Wound healing proceeds in a linear fashion. It begins immediately after a wound is created and lasts for about a year until the final scar contraction finishes.

453783.modifier: Greatest Tensile Strength Of Wound At 8 Weeks

answers_info.Text: The maximum tensile strength of a healed wound is equal to the skin's original strength
answers_info.Explanation: The maximum tensile strength of a healed wound is never as strong as the skin's pre-wound strength.

answers_info.Text: The maximum tensile strength is reached at about 6 weeks
answers_info.Explanation: At 8 weeks the wound has achieved its greatest tensile strength

answers_info.Text: At 8 weeks, the tensile strength is about 60% of its pre-wound strength
answers_info.Explanation: At 8 weeks, the wound is 100% of its final tensile strength, which correlates to about 80% of its pre-wound tensile strength.

answers_info.Text: At 6 weeks, the wound is about 60% of its final tensile strength
The final tensile strength is dependent upon Type III collagen deposition
answers_info.Explanation: Type III collagen is initially present in healing wounds but becomes replaced with type I collagen. A wound's final tensile strength is dependent on the type I collagen.

references.Name: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 18th Edition, Chapter 8, Electronic Publication.

453783.hint: Consider how the tensile strength of a wound progresses over time, and remember that measurements at specific intervals, such as 6 weeks, often reveal important milestones in healing.

500019.question:
An 85-year-old female is brought to the emergency department due to worsening chest pain, shortness of breath, and syncope. She has been a poorly compliant diabetic for 25 years and just recently was started on hemodialysis due to chronic renal failure. Her past medical history is also significant for COPD and coronary artery disease that required coronary artery bypass grafting with aortic valve replacement 10 years ago. After medical workup is performed an acute myocardial infarction is diagnosed, and an intra-aortic balloon pump is placed due to refractory cardiogenic shock. She is scheduled for an emergent coronary artery bypass grafting.

Which of the following variables is associated with the most significant increase in operative mortality?
answers: use of an intra-aortic balloon pump

explanation.BottomLine: In general, the strongest predictors of operative mortality after coronary artery bypass grafting include nonelective surgery, low ejection fraction, and prior heart surgery.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: A number of large single-and multicenter cardiac surgery databases have been used to develop risk models for predicting operative mortality in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). The Society of Thoracic Surgeons database provides the most comprehensive assessment of the variables associated with operative mortality after CABG. The variables with the greatest predictive power are related to urgency of operation, age, and re-operative surgery, while variables that described coronary anatomy had the least predictive power. Chronic comorbidities have also been found to be associated with an increased operative mortality after coronary bypass, including treated diabetes, peripheral vascular occlusive disease, chronic renal insufficiency, and COPD.

500019.mainTopic: Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting - Predicting Tools

answers_info.Explanation: Septic shock is not a known associated risk factor when considering postoperative mortality after CABG.

answers_info.Text: use of an intra-aortic balloon pump
answers_info.Explanation: Use of an intra-aortic balloon pump is associated with an odds ratio of 1.46, confidence interval (CI) 1.37–1.55.
The presence of COPD is associated with an odds ratio of 1.41, CI 1.35–1.48.
The presence of chronic renal failure is associated with an odds ratio of 1.88, CI 1.80–1.96.

references.Name: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice, 20th Edition, 2017. Chapter 241. Measuring Outcomes of Surgery.

500019.hint: Consider the patient's previous surgeries and the urgency of this operation. Think about the implications of undergoing surgery again for someone with a history of heart surgery.

1006407.question: A 25-year-old man with a severe allergy to iodinated contrast arrives in the trauma bay after a stab wound to the right upper quadrant. He is hypotensive and tachycardic. He undergoes exploratory laparotomy and a liver laceration with active bleeding is identified. Packing and hemostatic agents fail to control the hemorrhage. A Pringle maneuver is successful in controlling the bleeding, but the maneuver must be performed repeatedly to allow the surgeon to control the bleeding vessel, with a total required clamp time of 2 hours. Which of the following complications is likely in this patient?
answers: hepatic ischemia and subsequent tissue necrosis and abscess formation
embolic debris, pseudoaneurysm, and vascular dissection
1006407.correct_answer: hepatic ischemia and subsequent tissue necrosis and abscess formation

explanation.BottomLine: A Pringle maneuver occludes the inflow to the liver via manual clamping of the hepatoduodenal ligament and, therefore, occlusion of the portal vein and proper hepatic artery.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Liver lacerations may lead to exsanguinating hemorrhage. Immediately after entering the abdomen, laparotomy pads should be placed for temporary hemorrhage control, allowing anesthesia to catch up with resuscitative efforts. Packs should not be placed directly into the liver laceration, as this may potentially worsen the situation.  

Other techniques include the Pringle maneuver, which occludes the inflow to the liver via manual clamping of the hepatoduodenal ligament and, therefore, occlusion of the portal vein and proper hepatic artery. This should be done in an atraumatic fashion, either with fingers, atraumatic vascular clamps, Rummel tourniquet, or a Penrose drain. If bleeding decreases after this maneuver, bleeding is likely from a branch of the hepatic artery or portal vein. If brisk bleeding continues despite this effort, the source of bleeding is likely from the hepatic veins, which are posterior to the liver and empty into the inferior vena cava (IVC).  

While the Pringle maneuver is being performed, exploration of the laceration can take place with ligation of bleeding vessels and cauterization of the parenchyma. Individual hepatic vessels may be visualized by finger fracture of the liver tissue. The points of bleeding can then be controlled with electrocautery, stapling of liver tissue, individual suture ligatures, placement of omentum into the laceration, etc. The Pringle maneuver should only be performed for 15–20 minutes at a time, followed by a period of unclamping for 5 minutes to prevent liver ischemia and potential abscess formation. Prolonged clamp time, as in this patient, can lead to liver ischemia, tissue necrosis, and possible abscess formation. Any devitalized tissue should be excised.  


Hepatoduodenal ligament clamping procedure (Pringle maneuver).

answers_info.Explanation: Hepatic veins are found posterior to the liver and are directly associated with the IVC. It is very difficult to access these veins, and mobilization of the liver is required. It would be very rare to have a hepatic vein injury without an associated injury to the IVC. Hepatic congestion is more likely to occur in the setting of outflow obstruction, such as thrombus, congestive heart failure, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and pulmonary hypertension leading to right-sided heart failure. In this patient, bleeding decreased with the Pringle maneuver, demonstrating that the injury is unlikely to involve the IVC/hepatic veins.

answers_info.Text: hepatic ischemia and subsequent tissue necrosis and abscess formation

answers_info.Explanation: The Pringle maneuver entails encircling the hepatoduodenal ligament, which contains the common bile duct, portal vein, and proper hepatic artery. The gastroduodenal artery is unlikely to be clamped during a Pringle maneuver; therefore, the risk of duodenal ischemia with perforation is rare.

The Pringle maneuver is a temporary means to obtain hemostasis during a massive hepatic hemorrhage. It should be achieved with atraumatic occlusion, either with fingers, atraumatic vascular clamps, Rummel tourniquet, or Penrose drain. Prolonged use of the Pringle maneuver, such as in this patient, can lead to complications that include hepatic ischemia with possible necrosis and abscess formation.

answers_info.Text: embolic debris, pseudoaneurysm, and vascular dissection
answers_info.Explanation: Angioembolization is a potential treatment option for patients with hepatic lacerations; however, it is contraindicated in this patient with a severe allergic reaction to contrast dye. If the patient was a candidate for angioembolization, complications could include embolic debris, pseudoaneurysm, and vascular dissection.

references.Name: Management of traumatic liver injury. In: Cameron JL, Cameron AM, eds. Current Surgical Therapy. 14th ed. Elsevier; 2023.

Silverberg J, Clements TW, Hashmi S, Kirkpatrick AW, Sutherland FR, Ball CG. Is the Pringle manoeuvre becoming a lost art? Contemporary use for both severe liver trauma with ongoing hemorrhage and elective partial hepatectomy. Can J Surg. 2022;65(2):E266-E268.
Coccolini F, Coimbra R, Ordonez C, et al. Liver trauma: WSES 2020 guidelines. World J Emerg Surg. 2020;15(1):24.
Liver trauma: StatPearls

1006407.hint: Consider the potential effects of prolonged hepatic inflow occlusion on liver health and function. What can happen if blood supply is significantly restricted for an extended period?

1034956.question: A 37-year-old man with a history of total abdominal proctocolectomy and ileoanal anastomosis for familial adenomatous polyposis presents to the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past month. A CT scan demonstrates a mesenteric mass at the root of the mesentery that is kinking a portion of the small bowel, resulting in a partial obstruction. He is taken for a diagnostic laparoscopy with a biopsy of the lesion and lysis of adhesions. His obstruction resolves, and the biopsy demonstrates fibroblastic proliferation and bundles of spindle cells in an abundant fibrous stroma. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
answers: repeat CT scan in a year
neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgical resection of root of the mesentery

explanation.BottomLine: The first-line therapy for symptomatic desmoid tumors is an NSAID and tamoxifen and active surveillance with MRI every 3–6 months. Surgery is reserved for medically refractive cases or complete bowel obstruction that does not improve with conservative management. This is because tissue manipulation can precipitate additional tumor formation. Radiation can be an effective modality for poor surgical candidates.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient's presentation is most consistent with a desmoid tumor, which is strongly associated with familial adenomatous polyposis. While technically considered benign, these tumors can grow rapidly within the mesentery and cause intestinal obstruction. First-line therapy for mild cases consists of an NSAID such as sulindac and tamoxifen and active surveillance with contrast-enhanced MRI in 3- to 6-month intervals. Tyrosine kinase inhibitors, such as sorafenib, pazopanib, or sunitinib have also recently gained popularity.

Because tissue manipulation can precipitate the formation of additional desmoid tumors, surgery is generally reserved for medically refractory cases or for bowel obstruction that does not respond to nasogastric decompression and resuscitation. Recurrence rates are high even after resection with negative margins.

answers_info.Text: repeat CT scan in a year
answers_info.Explanation: Active surveillance alone is inappropriate for this symptomatic patient. Furthermore, surveillance should be with contrast-enhanced MRI and in shorter intervals (every 3–6 months).

answers_info.Text: neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgical resection of root of the mesentery
answers_info.Explanation: Chemotherapy for desmoid tumors is a relatively new concept that is under investigation and is not a first-line therapy. Surgery should be avoided if possible because tissue manipulation can precipitate the formation of additional desmoid tumors.
Surgical intervention is not the first-line treatment because tissue injury can precipitate the formation of additional desmoid tumors.

While radiation therapy is an effective therapeutic option for patients who are poor surgical candidates, less morbid therapy (ie, NSAIDs/tamoxifen) should be trialed in this patient whose bowel obstruction has resolved.

references.Name: Kasper B, Raut CP, Gronchi A. Desmoid tumors: to treat or not to treat, that is the question. Cancer. 2020;126(24):5213-5221.
Desmoid tumors: systemic therapy: UpToDate

1034956.hint: Consider the potential treatments for desmoid tumors, especially those that address both the tumor properties and the patient's specific history and symptoms.

309123.question:
Shortly after aggressive resuscitation for cardiac arrest, a patient is found to have a severe acidosis.  He is treated and then becomes lethargic and begins having a seizure.

Which of the following medications administered during the resuscitation is MOST likely contributing to his seizures?

explanation.BottomLine: An acute hyperosmolar state secondary to hypernatremia can result in serious neurological sequelae, including seizures.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Aggressive resuscitation during cardiac arrest involves many components. Repeated administration of sodium bicarbonate boluses can produce a hyperosmolar state secondary to acute hypernatremia. Hypernatremia in the acute setting may result in restlessness, irritability, ataxia, fever, tonic spasms, seizures, and subarachnoid hemorrhage. Correction is based upon total body water and water deficit calculations. Sodium levels should not be corrected faster than 7 mEq/L/h to avoid significant risk of cerebral edema and brain herniation.

answers_info.Explanation: Repeated administration of sodium bicarbonate boluses can produce a hyperosmolar state secondary to acute hypernatremia.
Epinephrine is unlikely to cause seizures.
Vasopressin is unlikely to cause seizures.
Potassium administration is unlikely to cause seizures, it can cause cardiac arrhythmias.

references.Name: Greenfield's Surgery: Scientific Principles and Practice, Chapter 10: Fluids, Electrolytes, and Acid-Base Balance, Electronic Publication.

309123.hint: Consider the medications used during resuscitation, especially those that might lead to altered electrolyte balances or changes in osmolarity, such as sodium levels.

828277.question: A 45-year-old patient is seen in the HIV clinic for blood testing. The peripheral smear demonstrates cells that stain positive for CD3 as well as their ability to recognize HLA-I molecules. Which of the following is the primary function of the isolated cells from the patient's blood?
answers: surveys for defective or infected cells, expresses CD8<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-I, destroys cells via perforins or programmed cell death
activates CD8<sup>+</sup> cells, releases cytokines, expresses CD4<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-II, destroys cells indirectly via activation of other cascades
surveys for defective or infected cells, expresses CD8<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-II, destroys cells via perforins or programmed cell death
activates CD8<sup>+</sup> cells, releases cytokines, expresses CD4<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-I, destroys cells indirectly via activation of other cascades
surveys for defective or infected cells, expresses CD4<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-I, destroys cells via programmed cell death only
828277.correct_answer: surveys for defective or infected cells, expresses CD8<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-I, destroys cells via perforins or programmed cell death

explanation.BottomLine: Cytotoxic T-cells survey the body for infected cells and destroy them via lysis or apoptosis. They stain positive for CD3 as they are of T-cell lineage, express CD8, and recognize human leukocyte antigen (HLA-I, major histocompatibility complex-I) bound antigens.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The cell type in question is a CD8+ cytotoxic T-cell.

Cytotoxic T-cells are lymphocytes that survey the body for defective or infected cells. They express CD3 as do all cells of T-cell lineage. All nucleated cells express the major histocompatibility complex (MHC-I), also known as human leukocyte antigen (HLA-I). When a foreign piece of material is presented by this complex, such as in a sick or virus-infected cell, the cytotoxic T-cell binds via its CD8+ receptor. Through a calcium-dependent mechanism, it causes the release of lysosomal granules containing perforin, which are enzymes that form holes in cell membranes. Once this occurs, granzymes are responsible for cell lysis. In a calcium-independent fashion, cytotoxic T-cells can promote apoptosis through the CD95 (Fas) surface receptor.


Antigen presentation stimulates T-cells to become either "cytotoxic" CD8+ cells or "helper" CD4+ cells. TCR, T-cell receptor; MHC-I or -II, major histocompatibility complex.

828277.modifier: Surveys For Defective Or Infected Cells

answers_info.Text: surveys for defective or infected cells, expresses CD8<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-I, destroys cells via perforins or programmed cell death
activates CD8<sup>+</sup> cells, releases cytokines, expresses CD4<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-II, destroys cells indirectly via activation of other cascades
answers_info.Explanation: This is the description of a CD4+ cell. CD4+ cells or helper T-cells recognize antigens and then regulate the immune reaction to these antigens. Major histocompatibility complex-II is found only on antigen presenting cells, such as macrophages.

answers_info.Text: surveys for defective or infected cells, expresses CD8<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-II, destroys cells via perforins or programmed cell death
answers_info.Explanation:
Cytotoxic T-cells survey for defective or infected cells, express CD8+, bind MHC-I (not MHC-II), and destroy cells via perforins or programmed cell death.
Major histocompatibility complex-I is found on all nucleated cells and helps differentiate between self (normal) and non-self (abnormal) antigens.

answers_info.Text: activates CD8<sup>+</sup> cells, releases cytokines, expresses CD4<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-I, destroys cells indirectly via activation of other cascades
answers_info.Explanation: Helper T-cells activate CD8<sup>+</sup> cytotoxic T-cells, release cytokines (interferon by type 1 helper T-cells, interleukin-4 by type 2 helper T-cells). Helper T-cells bind major histocompatibility complex-II.

answers_info.Text: surveys for defective or infected cells, expresses CD4<sup>+</sup>, binds major histocompatibility complex-I, destroys cells via programmed cell death only
answers_info.Explanation: Cytotoxic T-cells survey for defective or infected cells, express CD8<sup>+</sup>, bind MHC-I, and destroy cells via perforins or programmed cell death.

references.Name: Badell IR, Adams AB, Larsen CP. Chapter 25: Transplantation immunobiology and immunosuppression. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:572-613.
Alberts B, Johnson A, Lewis J, et al. T cells and MHC proteins. In: Molecular Biology of the Cell. 4th ed. Garland Science; 2002.
Image source:
T cells: Wikipedia Commons

828277.hint: Consider the role of T-cells and their interaction with major histocompatibility complex. Focus on which type of T-cell is involved in recognizing and destroying infected cells.

864037.question: A 42-year-old man undergoes split-thickness skin graft from his right thigh to his right arm after suffering a burn injury. A hydrocolloid dressing is placed over the donor site. On follow-up 14 days later, the dressing over the donor site is removed and the area appears to be completely healed. What is the most likely mechanism of donor site re-epithelialization?
answers: multipotent stem cells from hair follicles
864037.correct_answer: multipotent stem cells from hair follicles

explanation.BottomLine: Split-thickness skin grafts involve the epidermis and any part of the dermis. Dressings over split-thickness skin grafts donor sites should promote a moist environment and minimize pain until re-epithelialization. Stem cells residing in hair follicles are the most common source of re-epithelialization of skin graft donor sites.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient underwent a split-thickness skin graft (STSG) from his right thigh to his right arm with complete re-epithelialization of his donor site after 14 days. The most likely source of re-epithelialization of the donor site of an STSG is from multipotent stem cells that primarily reside in hair follicles. 

STSGs are grafts involving the epidermis and any part of the dermis and range in thickness from 0.005-0.030 inches. Depending on the amount of dermis included, they are classified as thin (0.005-0.012 inches), medium (0.012-0.018 inches), or thick (0.018-0.030 inches). In contrast, a full-thickness skin graft (FTSG) is composed of the epidermis and the entire dermis. 

The size of the graft needed is an important consideration, with regard to donor site morbidity. An STSG donor site heals by secondary intention with minimal morbidity; however, the donor site of an FTSG necessitates primary closure to mitigate donor site morbidity. Dressings over STSG donor sites that promote a moist environment until re-epithelialization (at least 7 days) are most optimal. Common donor-site dressings include semipermeable films, gauze dressing (Adaptic), alginate, hydrocolloid, or silicone dressing. Meticulous care of the donor site is important since the regenerated skin from the donor site may need to be re-harvested. Studies have shown that time to complete re-epithelialization is shorter with hydrocolloid dressings than with any other dressing, while gauze dressings had the highest infection rates.

Split-thickness Skin Graft Donor Site Dressing Characteristics
Encourages rapid re-epithelialization
Minimizes pain
Decreases risk of infection
Minimizes scarring

answers_info.Explanation: Imbibition is a mechanism of healing a skin graft, not a donor site. It involves passive absorption of oxygen and nutrients from the wound bed.
Angiogenic vessel outgrowth is a process of revascularization and a mechanism of healing a skin graft, not a donor site.

Granulation tissue occurs in a healthy, ungrafted wound bed and is a part of healing through secondary intention. Granulation tissue is not a source of multipotent stem cells responsible for re-epithelialization.

answers_info.Text: multipotent stem cells from hair follicles

answers_info.Explanation: Secondary contracture is a myofibroblast-mediated process that occurs during skin graft healing. It is not associated with donor site re-epithelialization.

references.Name: Pavri SN, Hsia HC. Chapter 6: Concepts of Skin Grafts and Skin Substitutes. In Chung KC, eds. Grabb and Smith's Plastic Surgery. 8th ed. Wolters Kluwer; 2019:48-55.
Lau K, Paus R, Tiede S, et al. Exploring the role of stem cells in cutaneous wound healing. Exp Dermatol. 2009;18(11):921-33.

864037.hint: Think about the regeneration of skin at the donor site and the role of cells that are typically involved in hair follicles. These cells play an essential role in the healing process.

1054565.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with acute right lower quadrant pain. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates inflammatory changes around a dilated appendix. The patient is taken to the OR for a laparoscopic appendectomy. The appendix is removed uneventfully, but a small peritoneal implant is noted and biopsied. The final pathology report returns several days later demonstrating frank infiltrative invasion with abundant extracellular mucin from both specimens. The most appropriate surgical management includes
answers: total abdominal colectomy, cytoreductive debulking, and ileal pouch-anal anastomosis reconstruction

explanation.BottomLine: Patients with mucinous adenocarcinoma and peritoneal implants are best managed surgically with a right hemicolectomy and cytoreductive debulking of the implants, followed by hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Surgical management of mucinous adenocarcinoma and peritoneal implants of the appendix involves a right hemicolectomy and cytoreductive debulking.

Appendiceal mucinous neoplasms are rare, with only about 3500 cases diagnosed annually in the United States. Patients with complicated appendicitis have a higher incidence compared with the general population.

Upon tissue diagnosis, staging should follow, including obtaining tumor markers, imaging, and further surgery (if indicated). The management is summarized in the table below.

Staging and Management of Mucinous Adenocarcinoma of the Appendix
Staging
  • Tumor markers
    • CEA
    • CA 19-9
    • CA-125
  • Imaging
    • CT chest/abdomen/pelvis
  • Colonoscopy
 Management
  • Right hemicolectomy
  • Cytoreductive debulking to deposits < 2.5 mm*
  • HIPEC*

*Cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy should be performed by experienced centers.

answers_info.Explanation: It is inappropriate for no further surgical resection to be offered for this patient. While an appendectomy alone is appropriate for low-grade appendiceal mucinous neoplasms that do not involve the base, mucinous adenocarcinomas, particularly those with peritoneal spread, should undergo a right hemicolectomy with cytoreductive debulking of the peritoneal disease.
Right hemicolectomy alone is insufficient for this patient who has peritoneal spread. Cytoreductive surgery should be included in this patient's surgical therapy.

Ileocecectomy is not an appropriate oncologic resection. A right hemicolectomy with high ligation of the ileocolic pedicle at its origin is the standard of care for appendiceal mucinous adenocarcinomas.

answers_info.Text: total abdominal colectomy, cytoreductive debulking, and ileal pouch-anal anastomosis reconstruction
answers_info.Explanation: A total abdominal colectomy is unnecessarily morbid and would not offer additional survival benefits compared with a right hemicolectomy.

references.Name: Chapter 51: The appendix. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:1301-1319.
Shaib WL, Assi R, Shamseddine A, et al. Appendiceal mucinous neoplasms: diagnosis and management [published correction appears in Oncologist. 2018 Jan;23 (1):137]. Oncologist. 2017;22(9):1107-1116.
Appendiceal mucinous lesions: UpToDate

1054565.hint: Consider the type of cancer and the presence of peritoneal implants in the diagnosis. This may influence the extent of surgical intervention needed.

663575.question: A 62-year-old woman presents to the trauma bay after sustaining a motor vehicle accident. An anteroposterior film of the pelvis is obtained in the trauma bay and is shown below. A pelvic binder is placed on the patient. She is slightly tachycardic. The focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) exam is negative. A CT abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast shows a questionable blush in the pelvis. What is the appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
answers: observation in the intensive care unit

explanation.BottomLine: Unstable pelvic fractures include disruption of the pelvic ring at two or more locations. Unstable pelvic fractures, such as open book pelvic fractures, produce bleeding and can be associated with other pelvic organ injuries. Angioembolization is the first-line treatment for traumatic pelvic bleeding.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient has an open book pelvic fracture or an anterior-posterior compression fracture (APC) according to the Young-Burgess classification system. It is recommended any patient over age 60 with an open book pelvic fracture undergo a pelvic angiogram with possible embolization per Eastern Association for the Surgery of Trauma (EAST) guidelines.

The combination of age > 60 and major pelvic fracture is highly associated with the need for angiography with embolization (odds ratio, 15) regardless of the patient's hemodynamic status. Indeed, 62% of patients older than 60 years requiring angiographic embolization had normal vital signs on hospital admission.

An open book fracture involves disruption of the pelvic ring at two or more locations resulting in dissociation of the right and left hemipelvis. This patient has pubis symphysis diastasis and disruption of the right sacroiliac joint as shown in the image below. 



Open book fracture. Black arrowhead = right SI joint disruption, blue arrowhead = symphysis pubis diastasis.


Physical exam findings include tenderness, laxity, and/or instability of the pelvis. Other pelvic organs at risk of injury following pelvic trauma include the bladder, urethra, and rectum. Diagnosis is typically made through a combination of physical exam and imaging including x-ray and CT scan. An open book pelvic fracture produces bleeding because of continued injury to small vessels secondary to pelvic instability and the increased volume of the pelvis.

answers_info.Explanation: An exploratory laparotomy is not warranted given a negative focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) exam and no suspicion of intra-abdominal injuries.

answers_info.Text: observation in the intensive care unit
answers_info.Explanation: Observation in the intensive care unit is not appropriate management given the unstable pelvic fracture.
An external fixator placement would perform the same role as a pelvic binder. A formal repair, once the patient is stabilized, would be a better option.
Serial complete blood counts are an appropriate approach in splenic and hepatic trauma while observing the patient in the ICU.

references.Name: Velhamos G. Pelvis. In: Moore EE, Feliciano DV, Mattox KL, eds. Trauma. 8th ed. New York: McGraw-Hill; 2017.

Culliname DC, Schiller HJ, Zielinski MD, et al. Eastern Association for the Surgery of Trauma practice management guidelines for hemorrhage in pelvic fracture: update and systematic review. J Trauma. 2011;71(6):1850-1868.
Image source: Wikimedia Commons

663575.hint: Consider the patient's age and the type of fracture indicated by the imaging findings. Think about which intervention is typically recommended for managing potential bleeding associated with pelvic injuries, especially in older patients.

815466.question: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a stab wound to the left flank. His vitals are stable but he complains of flank and abdominal pain. What is the most sensitive imaging modality to diagnose a bowel injury?
answers: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis
CT with IV and oral contrast
CT with IV, oral, and rectal contrast
815466.correct_answer: CT with IV, oral, and rectal contrast

explanation.BottomLine: In a trauma patient with penetrating flank injury, a CT with IV, oral and rectal contrast is the best choice to evaluate the visceral organs, stomach, duodenum and colon.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Patients with a stab wound to the flank, as seen here, are at risk of injury to visceral and hollow organs. The liver, spleen, and kidney can be commonly injured.

Management is based on the severity of injury to these organs. Flank injuries can also cause perforations in the colon, as it is retroperitoneal. A triple-contrast study allows for evaluation of the visceral organs, stomach, proximal small bowel, and colon.

answers_info.Explanation: Ultrasound can be used to perform a FAST exam on a trauma patient but its use is limited in colonic injuries.

answers_info.Text: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis
answers_info.Explanation: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis is not commonly used in trauma patients.
MRI of the pelvis is most commonly used to evaluate colorectal fistula disease. It is not commonly used in trauma patients.

answers_info.Text: CT with IV and oral contrast
answers_info.Explanation: Although CT with IV and oral contrast is reasonable choice to evaluate the visceral and proximal hollow organs, rectal contrast allows for better evaluation for colonic injuries.

answers_info.Text: CT with IV, oral, and rectal contrast

references.Name: Corcos A, Six C, Britt LD, et al. Chapter 37: Abdominal trauma. In: Peitzman AB, Yealy DM, Fabian TC, et al., eds. The Trauma Manual: Trauma and Acute Care Surgery. 5th ed. Wolters Kluwer; 2019.

815466.hint: Consider the imaging techniques that provide the most detailed view of internal injuries, especially those involving hollow organs. Think about modalities that might utilize different types of contrasts for optimal visualization.

960281.question: A 57-year-old man whose medications include albuterol for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and sitagliptin for type 2 diabetes undergoes a right upper lobectomy for lung cancer. On postoperative day 3, he develops atrial fibrillation with a pulse rate of 140/min. The patient is loaded with IV amiodarone, which is continued until being transitioned to oral maintenance doses that eventually convert his rhythm. His other medications during his hospitalization include subcutaneous enoxaparin and a continuous paracostal infusion of bupivacaine via a catheter. He presents for follow-up 2 months later and is found to have moderately elevated serum ALT and AST. Which of the patient's medications caused his laboratory abnormality?

explanation.BottomLine: Amiodarone can cause elevations in transaminases as well as clinically significant liver disease.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Amiodarone can cause elevations in transaminases as well as clinically significant liver disease, with AST and/or ALT elevations noted in 15–50% of patients on chronic therapy. Clinically apparent liver disease presenting with fatigue, nausea, weight loss, jaundice and, in rare circumstances, signs and symptoms of portal hypertension occurs in up to 1% of patients taking the drug. Amiodarone-induced hepatotoxicity occurs due to the inhibition of phospholipases, which causes a build-up of lipid-rich material in lysosomes and mitochondria and leads to organelle injury.
