Amiodarone can also directly damage a cell's lipid bilayers.  

Once a patient has been started on amiodarone, AST and ALT levels should be checked at baseline and every 6 months. If AST and/or ALT levels are found to be greater than twice the upper limit of normal or there is clinical evidence of liver failure (such as jaundice, ascites, or hepatomegaly), amiodarone should be discontinued. In the majority of cases, discontinuing the drug will reverse liver inflammation and dysfunction (although this may take months). However, in some cases, the liver damage is irreversible, and in these cases liver biopsy may be needed to determine the degree of damage and fibrosis.  

Medications Able to Cause Liver Dysfunction
Class Drug 
Antibiotics Ciprofloxacin, tetracycline, penicillins 
Antidepressants Fluoxetine
Antiepileptics Carbamazepine, phenytoin, valproic acid
Antifungals Ketoconazole
Antipsychotics Risperidone
Antirheumatics Methotrexate, azathioprine 
Antituberculosis drugs Isoniazid, pyrazinamide, rifampin
Antivirals Valacyclovir, ritonavir
Diabetes drugs Sulfonylureas, glipizide 
Herbal supplements Multiple supplements
Pain relievers NSAIDs, acetaminophen (high doses)
Recreational drugs Alcohol, cocaine
Statins Multiple drugs

answers_info.Explanation: Albuterol can cause anaphylaxis, paroxysmal bronchospasm, which can make wheezing and cough worse, and hypokalemia due to the shift of potassium into the cells.

Sitagliptin can cause anaphylaxis as well as acute skin reactions, such as Steven Johnson syndrome and bullous pemphigoid. Sitagliptin is also known to cause acute pancreatitis, hypoglycemia, and severe joint pain.

Enoxaparin can cause excess bleeding, particularly in the elderly and in patients with renal dysfunction. It has also been implicated in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, which presents with skin petechiae, low platelets, and evidence of thrombosis such as stroke, myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and acute limb ischemia.
Bupivacaine is associated with methemoglobinemia, which results in cyanosis and hypoxia. It can also cause hypotension, severe hyperthermia, and chondrolysis with inflammation of the joints.

references.Name: Björnsson HK, Björnsson ES. Drug-induced liver injury: pathogenesis, epidemiology, clinical features, and practical management. Eur J Intern Med. 2022;97:26-31.
Tsuda T, Tada H, Tanaka Y, et al. Amiodarone-induced reversible and irreversible hepatotoxicity: two case reports. J Med Case Rep. 2018;12(1):95.
LiverTox: Clinical and Research Information on Drug-Induced Liver Injury: Amiodarone: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

960281.hint: Consider which medication is known for causing liver enzyme elevations. Focus on the patient's medication regimen and look for the one associated with liver dysfunction.

1012489.question: A 27-year-old man was involved in a motor vehicle collision, crashing into a street lamp at 50 miles per hour. In the trauma bay, the patient is protecting his airway but is gasping for air and complaining of chest pain and shortness of breath. Physical exam findings include distended neck veins, a trachea that is deviated to the left, and decreased breath sounds on the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
answers: thoracostomy at the right fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line
1012489.correct_answer: thoracostomy at the right fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line

explanation.BottomLine: Tension pneumothorax is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by jugular venous distention, tracheal deviation contralateral to the side of injury, and absent/decreased ipsilateral breath sounds. The management is immediate decompression via needle or thoracostomy at the fifth intercostal space and midaxillary line without waiting for further diagnostic tests.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient most likely has tension pneumothorax due to blunt trauma from the impact of the steering wheel or airbag. Without waiting for further diagnostic studies (x-ray, eFAST, CT scan), the most appropriate next step is an immediate tube thoracostomy at the right fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. 

Tension pneumothorax results from an air leak from the lung into the chest wall, causing air to be pushed into the pleural space without a means of escape. The lung eventually collapses due to the buildup of air, putting tension on other organs in the mediastinum. As a result, the mediastinum is displaced to the opposite side of the injury (in this patient's case, to the left side) and causes tracheal deviation. The marked decrease of venous return due to this sift and compression can result in cardiogenic shock.

Once the diagnosis of tension pneumothorax is made, immediate treatment is indicated. Management options include needle decompression or finger thoracostomy followed by a chest tube. Either procedure is to be performed at approximately the fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line. Historical management algorithms advocated apical needle decompression at the midclavicular line, but this is no longer recommended due to high rates of malpositioning.

Tension pneumothorax as it appears on x-ray is shown in the figure below.

Characteristic Signs and Symptoms of a Tension Pneumothorax
  • Chest pain
  • Air hunger
  • Tachypnea
  • Respiratory distress
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury
  • Ipsilateral absence of breath sounds
  • Elevated hemithorax without respiratory movement
  • Jugular venous distention
  • Cyanosis (late finding)

Right-sided pneumothorax seen on an anteroposterior chest x-ray. Note the demarcation between the lung and the translucent pleural space filled with air (blue arrow).

answers_info.Explanation: The patient is protecting his airway for the moment and requires rapid treatment of the tension pneumothorax. Positive-pressure ventilation after intubation can potentially exacerbate a pneumothorax, resulting in a rapid decline in the patient’s respiratory status.

Left anterolateral thoracotomy is indicated for traumatic cardiac arrest that occurs in the trauma bay or just prior to arrival. It is not indicated in this patient presenting with tension pneumothorax.

Pericardial tamponade also presents with jugular vein distention, but in this patient with tracheal deviation and unilateral decreased breath sounds, tension pneumothorax is higher on the differential. Pericardial tamponade classically presents with equal breath sounds bilaterally. Additionally, following the ABCs of trauma, breathing issues (such as tension pneumothorax) should be addressed before evaluating for circulatory issues such as pericardial tamponade.

answers_info.Text: thoracostomy at the right fifth intercostal space at the midaxillary line

answers_info.Explanation: Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, not a radiographic diagnosis. Treatment should not be delayed to confirm by way of imaging (x-ray, extended FAST, CT, etc).

references.Name: Management of spontaneous and secondary pneumothorax. In: Cameron JL, Cameron AM, eds. Current Surgical Therapy. 14th ed. Elsevier; 2023.
Chapter 4: Thoracic trauma. In: Advanced Trauma Life Support Student Course Manual. 10th ed. American College of Surgeons; 2018:63-81.

1012489.hint: Consider the classic signs of tension pneumothorax and focus on the immediate intervention required to relieve pressure in the thoracic cavity.

813551.question: A 24-year-old woman is 5 weeks postpartum and lactating. She presents with cellulitis, erythema, and induration of her right breast. She undergoes antibiotic therapy without significant improvement. She continues to breastfeed and applies warm compresses, as well. An US performed demonstrates a 2.8-cm hypoechoic fluid collection of her right breast without other concerning abnormalities in the remainder of her breast tissue (see below). Which of the following is the next best step in management?
answers: punch biopsy of persistent cellulitis to rule out inflammatory breast cancer
admit the patient for IV antibiotic therapy
surgical incision and debridement of abscess
percutaneous US-guided aspiration with an 18-gauge needle
813551.correct_answer: percutaneous US-guided aspiration with an 18-gauge needle

explanation.BottomLine: Mastitis in lactating women can be treated with antibiotic therapy for 10–14 days, warm compresses, and continued breast emptying, including breastfeeding. If mastitis does not seem to improve clinically after this initial line of therapy, then a soft tissue US is required to evaluate for an underlying fluid collection.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Mastitis associated with breastfeeding is usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus and is common in the initial 4–6 weeks of breastfeeding, similar to the patient's story. The ducts are poorly drained, and bacteria proliferate, causing cellulitis as described as pain, erythema, and swelling. The first line of treatment is antibiotic therapy, to continue breastfeeding to help empty the poorly drained ducts, and apply warm or cold compresses as well for symptomatic relief.

After an adequate antibiotic trial of 10–14 days, an underlying abscess must be ruled out with US if infection persists. Because this patient had minimal improvement after conservative therapy with antibiotics, warm compresses, and continued breastfeeding, an US was performed to assess for an underlying abscess.  

If found, an aspiration attempt is performed prior to surgical incision and drainage. Percutaneous US-guided aspiration with an 18-gauge needle is appropriate as this needle size allows for adequate aspiration in most cases. In the case of thicker and viscous material, a 14-gauge needle may be necessary.


White arrow pointing to a 2.8-cm hypoechoic breast abscess.

answers_info.Explanation: Antibiotic therapy with continued breast emptying has been shown to resolve symptoms of mastitis, decrease recurrence rate, and decrease the risk of abscess development. However, after an adequate antibiotic trial of 10–14 days, an underlying abscess needs to be ruled out if the infection has not cleared.

answers_info.Text: punch biopsy of persistent cellulitis to rule out inflammatory breast cancer
answers_info.Explanation: A soft tissue US ruling out an underlying abscess would need to be performed and ruled out prior to considering more rare differential diagnoses such as inflammatory breast cancer. If an underlying mass is not visualized and there are persistent cellulitic changes of the breast, a punch biopsy then can be obtained to rule out inflammatory breast cancer.

answers_info.Text: admit the patient for IV antibiotic therapy
answers_info.Explanation: It is unnecessary to admit for IV antibiotic therapy at this time. An US to assess for an underlying fluid collection is necessary to address the etiology of persistent infection. Percutaneous US-guided aspiration should be considered first-line therapy for abscesses < 5 cm, followed by incision and drainage if recurrence occurs. The second attempt of percutaneous needle aspiration can be attempted as well before a surgical incisional and drainage is performed.

answers_info.Text: surgical incision and debridement of abscess
answers_info.Explanation: Although success has been reported with oral antistaphylococcal antibiotics and serial aspiration, surgical excision may be required for infected or obstructed ducts. It provides a lower rate of recurrence for nonpuerperal abscess and mastitis, as well.

answers_info.Text: percutaneous US-guided aspiration with an 18-gauge needle

references.Name: Moseley TW, Stanley A, Wei W, et al. Impact on clinical management of after-hours emergent or urgent breast ultrasonography in patients with clinically suspected breast abscesses. Diagnostics (Basel). 2018;8(1):17.
Kang YD, Kim YM. Comparison of needle aspiration and vacuum-assisted biopsy in the ultrasound-guided drainage of lactational breast abscesses. Ultrasonography. 2016;35(2):148-152.
Image source:
US image of hypoechoic breast abscess: Medpix

813551.hint: Consider the implications of a persistent infection despite initial treatment. Think about the next step that would directly address a potential complication noted in the ultrasound findings.

462943.question:
A 2-year-old male is brought to the office with complaints of watery diarrhea and a palpable mass on his right flank. A workup finds the child to have an elevated blood pressure and metanephrines in his urine.

Which of the following markers is consistent with an unfavorable prognosis in this child?

explanation.BottomLine: NSE, N-myc, and elevated LDH all confer a poor prognosis in children with neuroblastoma.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: This child is presenting with a neuroblastoma, which is the most common type of solid organ tumor in the pediatric population. Children often present with a palpable flank mass, and may have symptoms such as diarrhea, hypertension, or ataxia. Work-up will reveal an elevation in catecholamines and metanephrines, and is easily diagnosed by CT scan or MRI. A poor prognosis is associated with age greater than 1-year-old, and elevations in neuron specific enolase (NSE), LDH, and N-myc amplification. Tumors that are hyperdiploid will have more DNA within the tumor cells which make them more susceptible to chemotherapy and portends a favorable prognosis.

answers_info.Explanation: Age greater than 1 is associated with poor prognosis.
Elevated neuron specific enolase is associated with poor prognosis.
An elevated LDH level is associated with poor prognosis.
Tumors that are hyperdiploid will have more DNA within the tumor cells which make them more susceptible to chemotherapy and portends a favorable prognosis.

references.Name: Pediatric Surgery. In Townsend C et al., eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 20th Ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2017.

462943.hint: Consider markers associated with neuroblastoma prognosis, especially those that elevate or amplify during disease progression.

903708.question: An 18-year-old man presents to the emergency department with 25% full-thickness burns to the chest, abdomen, and bilateral thighs sustained by a fall into a bonfire at a college party. He is found to be groaning with some nonspecific arm movements when his burned clothes are removed. He does not open his eyes, but he is found to have singed eyebrows and eyelashes. His vital signs are as follows: pulse rate is 115/min, blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 90%. Which of the following is the best next step in the treatment of this patient?
answers: insert 2 large-bore IVs and initiate vasopressor therapy to maintain perfusion
perform fiberoptic evaluation for inhalation and airway injury
initiate burn resuscitation with crystalloids, titrating to urine output of 1.5 mL/kg/hr
insert central venous catheter for vascular access

explanation.BottomLine: Follow the ABCs (airway, breathing, circulation) of resuscitation for burn patients, just as in trauma patients.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The initial management of burn patients is exactly the same as it is for trauma patients. Every resuscitation should begin with the ABCs. Following a linear algorithm lowers the likelihood of missing a life-threatening injury. First, the patient’s airway (A) should be evaluated. If the patient’s airway appears to be uninjured, the evaluation can proceed to (B) for breathing. After assessing the patient’s respiratory efforts, attention is turned to (C) for circulation. In reality, these steps may all occur almost simultaneously, but for testing purposes, make sure to answer in the order of ABC. 

This patient displays a Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) < 9 and should be intubated for airway protection.

answers_info.Text: insert 2 large-bore IVs and initiate vasopressor therapy to maintain perfusion
answers_info.Explanation: Patients with significant burn injuries require large amounts of fluid resuscitation. Early establishment of large-bore peripheral IV access is important.

answers_info.Text: perform fiberoptic evaluation for inhalation and airway injury
answers_info.Explanation: Evaluation for evidence of airway injury is important. Not all patients who present with singed facial hair or nasopharyngeal soot have inhalation burn injury and require immediate intubation. If this patient had a GCS > 8 without other indications for intubation, evaluation for airway injury with a fiberoptic scope would be reasonable.

answers_info.Text: initiate burn resuscitation with crystalloids, titrating to urine output of 1.5 mL/kg/hr
answers_info.Explanation: Burn resuscitation should be performed by titrating fluids to a urine output of 0.5–1 mL/kg/hr, not 1.5 mL/kg/hr. Airway management always comes first. In practice, significant burn patients (eg, > 20% total body surface area [TBSA] burn) can be resuscitated using a fixed rate of crystalloid (eg, lactated Ringers at 500 mL/hr) as calculated using the Parkland (4 mL/kg/% TBSA of total volume in the first 24 hr) or modified Brooke formula (2 mL/kg/% TBSA of total volume in the first 24 hr). The hourly rate of IV fluid is then titrated up or down based on urine output.

answers_info.Text: insert central venous catheter for vascular access
answers_info.Explanation: A central line may be needed for the administration of resuscitative products, but it is not always needed. This patient requires airway protection first, according to the ABCs of trauma.

references.Name: Chapter 20: Burns. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:484-505.
Suman A, Owen J. Update on the management of burns in paediatrics. BJA Educ. 2020;20(3):103-110.

Olgers TJ, Dijkstra RS, Drost-de Klerck AM, Ter Maaten JC. The ABCDE primary assessment in the emergency department in medically ill patients: an observational pilot study. Neth J Med. 2017;75(3):106-111.

903708.hint: Consider the patient's airway status carefully, especially with the signs of possible inhalation injury due to the bonfire. What action would you take to ensure his airway is protected?

837453.question:
A 50-year-old woman presents to the hospital with several days of epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and jaundice. On examination, she has epigastric tenderness without rebound. She also has had persistent dry eyes and mouth and dental caries for the past year. Abdominal US does not demonstrate cholelithiasis. Laboratory results and an MRCP image are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis, and next step in management?

Laboratory Results
Hemoglobin 12.9 gm/dl
WBC count 10.6 x 103 cells/μL
Serum lipase  209 U/L
Serum amylase  130 U/L
Total bilirubin  10.6 mg/dL
(direct and indirect fractions) 8 mg/dL and 2.6 mg/dL
Aspartate aminotransferase  110 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase 131 U/L
Alkaline phosphatase 389 U/L
Hepatitis A, B, and C negative
IgG4 level 765 mg/dl

explanation.BottomLine: Autoimmune pancreatitis may mimic pancreatic cancer. Hallmark findings are elevated IgG4 levels, associated autoimmune diseases, such as Sjogren syndrome, long or multiple strictures of the main pancreatic duct, and characteristic histological findings. Initial management is with ERCP/endoscopic US, followed by steroid therapy.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient most likely suffers from autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) given her history of persistent dry eyes/mouth and dental caries (Sjogren syndrome), and evidence of pancreatitis based on elevated lipase and abdominal pain. Her elevated IgG levels and a typical "sausage-like” appearance of the pancreas on MRCP further support the diagnosis. 

The elevated bilirubin levels are secondary to narrowing of the intrapancreatic portions of the common bile duct, a common finding in AIP, which will improve significantly with ERCP dilatation, sphincterotomy, and stent placement.


MRCP demonstrates diffuse enlargement of the pancreas and effacement of the lobular contour of the pancreas (red arrow), which are typical findings in autoimmune pancreatitis, and are rarely seen in pancreatic cancer.

Autoimmune pancreatitis is a rare disease with a much lower incidence than pancreatic cancer. There are 2 types of autoimmune pancreatitis. Type 1 is much more common (> 80%) associated with elevated serum IgG4 levels and has extrapancreatic manifestations, whereas type 2 is not. Treatment is biliary decompression and exclusion of pancreatic cancer by ERCP/endoscopic US, followed by steroid therapy.

answers_info.Explanation: Band-like strictures, beading, or prune-tree appearance is most often found on MRCP or ERCP in primary sclerosing cholangitis, not dilated pancreatic duct.
Pancreatic adenocarcinoma often presents as painless jaundice. Pancreatic enzymes and IgG4 levels are usually not elevated.
Gallstone pancreatitis would demonstrate a filling defect (gallstone) or choledocholithiasis on MRCP. Also, the patient lacks gallstones on abdominal US.
Prior to steroid therapy, the patient requires an ERCP/endoscopic US to relieve obstructive jaundice, visualize the pancreatic ducts, and exclude pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

references.Name: Allaparthi S, Sageer M, Sterling MJ. Deciphering autoimmune pancreatitis, a great mimicker: case report and review of the literature. Case Rep Gastrointest Med. 2015;2015:924532.

Shimosegawa T, Chari ST, Frulloni L, et al. International Association of Pancreatology. International consensus diagnostic criteria for autoimmune pancreatitis: guidelines of the International Association of Pancreatology. Pancreas. 2011;40(3):352-8.
Autoimmune pancreatitis: UpToDate
Image source:
MRCP images showing sausage-like pancreas: Case Rep Gastrointest Med

837453.hint: Consider the patient's symptoms, particularly the association between dry eyes and mouth, as they may indicate a potential underlying autoimmune condition. Also, pay close attention to the laboratory findings, especially the elevated IgG4 levels.

834595.question: An 80-kg burn patient (BMI 28 kg/m2) with second-degree burns covering 30% of his body surface area is admitted to the ICU. He has an ileus and a nasogastric tube that is draining 500 mL per day. He is started on maintenance fluids. Which of the following correctly lists his daily caloric, sodium, potassium, and fluid requirements?
answers: 2000 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2900 mL fluid
2800 kcal, 80 mEq sodium, 160 mEq potassium, and 2900 mL
2800 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2900 mL
2800 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2400 mL
2000 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2400 mL
834595.correct_answer: 2800 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2900 mL

explanation.BottomLine: The nutritional requirements of a patient are important in the management of ICU patients and in constructing total parenteral nutrition. The daily caloric requirement is increased to approximately 35 kcal/kg for burn patients. Each patient requires 2 mEq/kg sodium and 1 mEq/kg potassium daily. Finally, when determining the fluid requirements of an individual, one must be sure to address additional losses (eg, nasogastric tube drainage).
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Each patient has certain nutritional requirements that are weight-based. This is useful in patients on total parenteral nutrition in order to appropriately formulate infusions. For patients with a BMI < 30 kg/m2, the actual body weight may be used. If the BMI is > 30 kg/m2, an adjusted weight may be used to avoid overfeeding. 

The daily caloric requirement for an unstressed individual is approximately 25 kcal/kg. However, if a person has undergone trauma, a burn, or surgery, they have an increase in their metabolic demand because their body is in a catabolic state. In burn patients, the estimated daily caloric requirement is 35 kcal/kg. This patient's daily caloric requirement would be 2800 kcal (35 kcal/kg x 80 kg). Protein requirements are 1.5–2 g/kg.

Each patient requires sodium and potassium daily. Humans require 2 mEq/kg of sodium daily and 1 mEq/kg of potassium daily. This patient would require 160 mEq sodium (2 mEq/kg x 80 kg) and 80 mEq potassium (1 mEq/kg x 80 kg).

Finally, humans require a certain amount of fluid every day. This requirement must be augmented when there are additional losses (eg, nasogastric tube drainage). The daily fluid requirement for humans is 30 mL/kg. This patient requires 2900 mL of fluid daily: (30 mL/kg x 80 kg) + 500 mL nasogastric tube drainage.

Below is a table summarizing various nutritional requirements:

Nutritional Element Daily Requirement
Caloric 25 kcal/kg (35 kcal/kg in stressed patients)
Fluid 30 mL/kg + any additional unexpected losses
Sodium 2 mEq/kg
Potassium 1 mEq/kg
Calcium 0.1 mEq/kg
Magnesium 0.1 mEq/kg
Phosphate 0.1 mmol/kg

834595.modifier: Caloric, Sodium, Potassium, And Fluid Requirements

answers_info.Text: 2000 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2900 mL fluid
answers_info.Explanation: 2000 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2900 mL fluid does not take into account the added metabolic burden in a burn patient's increasing daily caloric requirements.

answers_info.Text: 2800 kcal, 80 mEq sodium, 160 mEq potassium, and 2900 mL
answers_info.Explanation: 2800 kcal, 80 mEq sodium, 160 mEq potassium, and 2900 mL fluid inverts the daily requirements of sodium and potassium. A patient requires 2 mEq/kg of sodium and 1 mEq/kg of potassium daily.

answers_info.Text: 2800 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2900 mL
2800 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2400 mL
answers_info.Explanation: 2800 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2400 mL fluid neglects the added fluid loss of the nasogastric tube drainage.

answers_info.Text: 2000 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2400 mL
answers_info.Explanation: 2000 kcal, 160 mEq sodium, 80 mEq potassium, and 2400 mL fluid does not take into account the added metabolic burden of a burn patient. In addition, it neglects the added fluid loss of the nasogastric tube drainage.

references.Name: Smith SG, Schreiber MA. Chapter 4: Shock, electrolytes and fluid. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:44-94.
Clark A, Imran J, Madni T, Wolf SE. Nutrition and metabolism in burn patients. Burns Trauma. 2017;5:11.

Choban P, Dickerson R, Malone A, Worthington P, Compher C; A.S.P.E.N. Clinical guidelines nutrition support of hospitalized adult patients with obesity. JPEN J Parenter Enteral Nutr. 2013;37(6):714-744.

834595.hint: Remember that caloric needs increase significantly in burn patients. Calculate approximately 35 kcal/kg based on the patient's weight. Also, consider the additional losses from the nasogastric tube when calculating fluid requirements.

910103.question: A 72-year-old man is admitted to the surgical floor following a motor vehicle collision in which he sustained a weight-bearing as tolerated LC1 pelvic fracture and an intraperitoneal bladder injury that was surgically repaired. On postoperative day 1, the resident asks the nurse to ambulate the patient. The nurse does not agree with the resident and is hesitant to ambulate a patient with an indwelling catheter. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
answers: Allow the patient to remain on bedrest
Mobilize the patient to a chair as a compromise, but do not ambulate the patient until his urinary catheter is removed
Encourage the nurse to ambulate the patient despite the presence of a urinary catheter, and if the nurse is unable to do it safely, order a physical therapy consult
Ambulate the patient only once daily
910103.correct_answer: Encourage the nurse to ambulate the patient despite the presence of a urinary catheter, and if the nurse is unable to do it safely, order a physical therapy consult

explanation.BottomLine: Early mobilization (within 24 hours of admission) leads to decreased hospital length of stay, fewer discharges to rehabilitation facilities, and lower rates of complications that include pneumonia, skin breakdown, venous thromboembolism, falls, and delirium. A multidisciplinary approach, including nursing and physical therapy, should be adopted in elderly patients to ensure adequate mobilization.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Ambulation should occur early in the postoperative period to prevent the poor outcomes associated with bed rest and immobility. Postsurgical patients often have many barriers to mobility, including IVs, urinary catheters, drains, and pain. These should not prevent attempts at ambulation. Bed rest and lack of mobility combine to hasten physical deconditioning and muscle weakness.

Immobility is associated with an increased risk for falls, delirium, skin breakdown, and venous thromboembolic disease, as well as atelectasis, pneumonia, loss of functional independence, and prolonged hospital stay. Nursing staff should attempt to get patients out of the bed to a chair at least twice daily. When possible, patients should also be encouraged to walk. Patients who have difficulty ambulating on their own or who pose significant fall risk may need supervision by trained staff (physical therapy).

910103.modifier: Get Patient Out Of Bed And Start PT

answers_info.Text: Allow the patient to remain on bedrest
answers_info.Explanation: Immobilization leads to skeletal muscle atrophy within 72 hours in healthy adults. Additionally, functional mobility begins to decline after only 2 days of hospitalization. Early mobilization is essential to prevent these complications and loss of function.

answers_info.Text: Mobilize the patient to a chair as a compromise, but do not ambulate the patient until his urinary catheter is removed
answers_info.Explanation: This patient will require urinary drainage for 7–10 days, and it would be inappropriate not to ambulate him for that time period. He may need additional assistance to ambulate with his catheter in place, which can be obtained with a physical therapy consult.

answers_info.Text: Encourage the nurse to ambulate the patient despite the presence of a urinary catheter, and if the nurse is unable to do it safely, order a physical therapy consult

answers_info.Explanation: This patient sustained a bladder injury, which requires urinary drainage for a prolonged period (duration varies between institutions but is commonly 7–10 days). While urinary catheters do serve as a barrier to mobility and every effort should be made to discontinue them as soon as possible, it is not appropriate for this patient.

answers_info.Text: Ambulate the patient only once daily
answers_info.Explanation: Each patient should aim to ambulate at least 3 times per day. This can be achieved with a combination of nursing assistance, physical therapy, members of the patient's family, or members of the care team.

references.Name: Surkan MJ, Gibson W. Interventions to mobilize elderly patients and reduce length of hospital stay. Can J Cardiol. 2018;34(7):881-888.

Mohanty S, Rosenthal RA, Russell MM, et al. Optimal perioperative management of the geriatric patient: a best practices guideline from the American College of Surgeons NSQIP and the American Geriatrics Society. J Am Coll Surg. 2016;222(5):930-947.
Prevention of venous thromboembolism in adult orthopedic surgical patients: UpToDate

categories: Geriatric Surgery and End of Life Care
Geriatric Surgery and End of Life Care

full_categories.Name: Geriatric Surgery and End of Life Care
Geriatric Surgery and End of Life Care

910103.hint: Consider the benefits of early mobilization for postoperative patients, particularly in preventing complications. Reflect on how the presence of an indwelling catheter may not need to inhibit all forms of movement.

459557.question:
A 52-year-old male presents to the clinic with engorged and tortuous veins of the bilateral lower extremities, with lower extremity heaviness in the evenings.  He states he is mostly on his feet at work as a construction site supervisor.  He is otherwise healthy with no other medical concerns.  Duplex ultrasound of the bilateral lower extremities reveals compressible veins throughout with reflux of the small saphenous veins and some varicosities of the perforating veins.  

What is the ultimate best treatment in management of this patient?
answers: Radiofrequency ablation of the small saphenous vein
Sclerotherapy of the perforating varicose veins
Increased exercise and standing for symptomatic relief
459557.correct_answer: Radiofrequency ablation of the small saphenous vein

explanation.BottomLine: When reflux of the saphenous veins (small or greater) are present in addition to varicose veins, the refluxing vein must be treated first or concurrently with the varicose veins to prevent recurrence or possibly prevent further procedures.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Although simple varicose veins can be conservatively treated with compression stockings, this patient must undergo saphenous vein ablation.  In the presence of a saphenous vein reflux, eliminating the saphenous vein may reduce the need for further treatment of small varicose veins.

answers_info.Text: Radiofrequency ablation of the small saphenous vein
Sclerotherapy of the perforating varicose veins
answers_info.Explanation: Though the cosmetic appearance may improve with sclerotherapy of the perforating varicose veins, the varicose vein may return without the treatment of refluxing small saphenous vein. Additionally, treating the refluxing vein first may reduce the need for treating other small varicose veins surrounding the refluxing vein.
Vein stripping is more invasive and not typically used to reflux of the small saphenous veins.

answers_info.Text: Increased exercise and standing for symptomatic relief
answers_info.Explanation: Increased exercise may benefit the patient in symptomatic relief, though prolonged standing will only worsen the patient's varicose veins.
Bedrest and leg elevation is not a treatment for varicose veins and saphenous vein reflux.

references.Name: UpToDate: Overview and management of lower extremity chronic venous disease
Stanley, James. Current Therapy in Vascular and Endovascular Surgery, 5th ed. Elsevier.

459557.hint: Consider the anatomy of the veins involved and how reflux may contribute to the symptoms. Think about which treatment option addresses the primary cause of the issue leading to varicosities.

827691.question: The police bring a 24-year-old male suspect with severe bilateral hand pain into the emergency department. The suspect was involved in a 4-hour police chase for suspected robbery when the police found him hiding in the bushes in the middle of a snowstorm. The outside temperature was -7°C (19°F). The suspect's hands are cyanotic and cold to touch with an absent capillary refill. The radial pulse is not palpable, but Doppler signals are present. What is the next most appropriate treatment?

explanation.BottomLine: Initial treatment for Grade I frostbite should be rapidly rewarming the frostbitten extremity in a circulating warm water bath.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The initial therapy for this patient's frostbite injury is moist reheating of the affected limbs using whirlpool baths at a temperature of 40-42°C (104-107.6°F). The patient will require adequate analgesics such as anti-inflammatory and opioid medications, as the process of active rewarming will be painful. 

Frostbite is a severe ischemic injury that occurs due to tissue vascular damage after sub-zero temperature tissue exposure. This is due to the formation of ice crystals in cellular spaces leading to extensive damage to the endothelium of blood vessels. Its classic symptoms include vasospasm, vasoconstriction, hemorrhage, and loss of blood supply to the affected site leading to ischemia-reperfusion injury.

Deep frostbite can result in necrosis and may need amputation of the affected tissue.

Different Degrees of Frostbite 
Grade I Grade II Grade III Grade IV
Superficial:
  • Erythema
  • Edema
  • Hyperemia
  • No blisters
  • No necrosis
 Blister formation:
  • Full-thickness skin 
  • Erythema
  • Substantial edema
  • Vesicles with clear fluid blisters
  • Desquamation and black eschar formed
 Tissue necrosis:
  • Full-thickness skin 
  • Full-thickness subcutaneous tissue
  • Hemorrhagic blisters
  • Skin necrosis
  • Blue-grey discoloration
 Gangrene:
  • Full-thickness skin and subcutaneous tissue,
  • Full-thickness muscle, tendon, and bone
  • Little edema
  • Initially mottled deep red
  • Dry, black, and mummified 

Hypothermia is classified as mild (> 32°C), moderate (28–32°C), and severe (< 28°C).

answers_info.Explanation: CT angiogram would be appropriate if there is a suspected embolic event causing digital necrosis. This is a young patient with no cardiac or vascular risk factors to predispose him to an embolic event. This patient is suffering from Grade I frostbite and needs to be treated with active rewarming using moist heat in the form of a warm bath.

When it is not possible to perform external rewarming or it is difficult to maintain the temperature correctly, internal rewarming techniques are used. Internal
rewarming can be noninvasive or invasive. The noninvasive techniques include the use of warm IV fluids heated to 43°C (109°F) in a microwave and administered through a microinfusion pump. Invasive techniques involve warm lavage of several body cavities including gastric, colonic, bladder, and thoracic lavage. Active external rewarming is the most appropriate initial step for this patient.

Frostbite is a thrombotic ischemic disorder as a result of cold-induced platelet dysfunction and disruption of coagulation cascade causing thrombus formation. The clot formation leads to severe vascular compromise, resulting in subsequent ischemia. However, it does not mean that patients should receive systemic anticoagulation. Some have reported benefits from intra-arterial tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) if:
  • No improvement after 15 to 20 minutes of active bath rewarming
  • Absent Doppler signals
  • Limited perfusion on 99mTc bone scan
  • Window within 24 hours of initial rewarming

This patient does not meet the criteria for intra-arterial tPA.

Papaverine is a direct-acting smooth muscle relaxant used primarily in the treatment of visceral spasms and vasospasm (especially those involving the intestines, heart, or brain). It is not the next most appropriate management in patients with Grade I frostbite.

references.Name: Joshi K, Goyary D, Mazumder B, et al. Frostbite: Current status and advancements in therapeutics. J Therm Biol. 2020;93:102716.

Gonzaga T, Jenabzadeh K, Anderson CP, et al. Use of intra-arterial thrombolytic therapy for acute treatment of frostbite in 62 patients with review of thrombolytic therapy in frostbite. J Burn Care Res. 2016;37(4):e323-e334.
Saemi AM, Johnson JM, Morris CS. Treatment of bilateral hand frostbite using transcatheter arterial thrombolysis after papaverine infusion. Cardiovasc Intervent Radiol. 2009;32(6):1280-3.

827691.hint: Consider the immediate effects of cold exposure on the body, particularly on extremities. Think about the best method to rewarm frostbitten hands efficiently and safely.

769992.question: A 25-year-old man has been on long-term parenteral nutrition for short gut syndrome. His long-term access is a tunneled central venous catheter. He complains of fever and malaise for the last few days and discharges from the central line insertion site. On physical examination, he is febrile, the tunneled line insertion site is warm, erythematous, and has purulent discharge. Swab shows gram-positive coagulase-negative cocci. What may be the most likely mechanism of bacterial resistance to antibiotics in this scenario?
answers: outer membrane that has a high lipid content
reducing the number of porin channels

explanation.BottomLine: The presence of a biofilm makes eradication of infection difficult, often necessitating removal of the line and prolonged antibiotic therapy.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This is a scenario of a young patient, dependent on long-term total parenteral nutrition via a tunneled line, presenting with features suggestive of line sepsis. The gram-positive coagulase-negative microorganism is most likely Staphylococcus epidermidis. It is usually a commensal bacteria of the normal human skin flora. It may become pathogenic in situations where there is underlying immunodeficiency, such as diabetes mellitus, chronic illness, and long-term steroid therapy.

Staphylococcus epidermidis infections are generally hospital-acquired and are a concern for people with long-standing lines or implants. They are particularly difficult to eradicate because of biofilm formation on prosthetic lines or implants, frequently necessitating line removal and prolonged antibiotic therapy. The presence of a biofilm makes eradication of infection difficult, often necessitating removal of the line and prolonged antibiotic therapy.


Staphylococcus aureus biofilm.

answers_info.Text: outer membrane that has a high lipid content
answers_info.Explanation: Mycobacteria have an outer membrane that has a high lipid content, and so hydrophobic drugs such as rifampicin and the fluoroquinolones have an easier access to the cell, but hydrophilic drugs have limited access.
Staphylococcus aureus produces a thickened cell wall, which makes it difficult for the drug to enter the cell and provides an intermediate resistance to vancomycin.

answers_info.Text: reducing the number of porin channels
answers_info.Explanation: Enterobacteriaceae are known to become resistant due to reducing the number of porin channels.

Production of beta-lactamase leads to the breakdown of the beta-lactam ring in penicillins, resulting in penicillin resistance. This is a common mechanism of antibiotic resistance in Escherichia coli species such as extended spectrum beta-lactamase-producing strains.

references.Name: Saydi JP, Aribindi V, Todd SR. Chapter 22: Surgical critical care. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:521-545.

Chapter 195: Staphylococcus epidermidis and other coagulase-negative staphylococci. In: Bennett JE, Dolin R, Blaser MJ, eds. Mandell, Douglas, and Bennett's Principles and Practice of Infectious Diseases. 9th ed. Elsevier; 2019.
Otto M. Staphylococcal biofilms. Microbiol Spectr. 2018;6(4):10.1128/microbiolspec.GPP3-0023-2018.
Image source:
Staphylococcus aureus biofilm: Wikipedia

769992.hint: Consider how bacteria can protect themselves in a medical setting, especially when associated with medical devices. Think about the structure formed around them that makes them harder to eliminate.

824631.question: A 42-year-old woman is being seen after a core needle biopsy of an abnormal mammogram finding. The biopsy is positive for a radial scar. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for this patient?
answers: observation, repeat diagnostic mammogram in 1 year
observation, repeat diagnostic mammogram in 6 months
lumpectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy

explanation.BottomLine: Radial scars should typically undergo excisional biopsy due to their risk of upstaging to a malignancy 25% of the time.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
A radial scar is considered a high-risk lesion that requires further investigation when found on imaging and biopsy. It can be associated with malignancy in up to 25% of cases on excisional biopsy.  

An argument can be made that if there is image-pathology concordance with a well-sampled radial scar with large-gauge core needle biopsy, the patient can undergo serial imaging to ensure stability—for example, if the original lesion is small or if the lesion is completely removed with the core needle biopsies. This is still a controversial topic in radial scar or complex sclerosing lesion management. 

The American Society of Breast Surgeons' consensus statement on the management of high-risk lesions is outlined in Table 1. 

Recommendations for Breast Lesions Identified on Core Needle Biopsy
Lesion Type Management
Atypical ductal/lobular hyperplasia Surgical excisional biopsy
Lobular carcinoma in situ  Excise or observation with clinical and imaging follow-up. Excision is recommended if pathology is discordant, there are limited samples, if another high-risk lesion is present, or if the patient proceeds with prophylactic surgery due to a high risk for breast cancer 
Pleomorphic
lobular carcinoma in situ  		 Excise as this is a higher-risk lesion
Fibroepithelial
lesions with concern for phyllodes; phyllodes tumors		 Surgical excisional biopsy
Fibroadenoma Excise if symptomatic or > 4 cm; clinical observation if asymptomatic and < 4 cm and demonstrated stability in size on serial imaging
Complex sclerosing lesion or radial scar Surgical excisional biopsy
Desmoid Wide local excision
Pseudoangiomatous stromal hyperplasia Clinical observation

answers_info.Text: observation, repeat diagnostic mammogram in 1 year
answers_info.Explanation: A radial scar can be associated with underlying malignancy up to 25% of the time on excisional biopsies. Because of this relatively high chance of upstaging to an invasive or in-situ ductal carcinoma, an excisional biopsy is typically warranted.

answers_info.Text: observation, repeat diagnostic mammogram in 6 months
answers_info.Explanation: This is the usual recommendation for likely benign lesions (BI-RADS 3) seen on mammography. This is not appropriate for biopsy-proven higher-risk lesions that can be upstaged. If biopsy was consistent for a fibroadenomatous tissue or pseudoangiomatous stromal hyperplasia, then a 6-month interval for follow-up to ensure stability would be appropriate.

Repeat biopsy is inappropriate, as the entirety of the sclerosing tissue should be removed for analysis. Repeat biopsies are appropriate if the initial biopsy tissue volume was inadequate for pathological analysis.

answers_info.Text: lumpectomy and sentinel lymph node biopsy
answers_info.Explanation: A radial scar is a high-risk breast lesion but not cancer. A lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy is most appropriate for invasive carcinomas.

references.Name: Hou Y, Hooda S, Li Z. Surgical excision outcome after radial scar without atypical proliferative lesion on breast core needle biopsy: a single institutional analysis. Ann Diagn Pathol. 2016;21:35-38.

Consensus guideline on concordance assessment of image-guided breast biopsies and management of borderline or high-risk lesions. The American Society of Breast Surgeons. November 2, 2016. Accessed August 8, 2021.

Douglas-Jones AG, Denson JL, Cox AC, Harries IB, Stevens G. Radial scar lesions of the breast diagnosed by needle core biopsy: analysis of cases containing occult malignancy. J Clin Pathol. 2007;60(3):295-298.

824631.hint: Consider the implications of a radial scar in the context of breast lesions. It may be associated with a significant risk of upstaging to malignancy, which should influence your choice of management.

908569.question: A patient with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma is undergoing a diagnostic laparoscopy. Staging for this type of cancer is based on lesion size and location which are critical factors in determining the T stage.

explanation.BottomLine: The T stage for malignant peritoneal mesothelioma is based on the peritoneal carcinomatosis index, which is calculated based on tumor location and size.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Malignant peritoneal mesothelioma (MPM), as in this patient, is a rare type of cancer with high morbidity and mortality due to its diffuse spread throughout the abdominal cavity. Although aggressive, MPM tends to remain confined to the abdominal cavity because of the limited hematogenous and lymphatic metastatic potential of the disease. Lymph node involvement is rare and, because of this, MPM does not fit well into traditional TNM (tumor, node, metastasis) staging. 

A novel staging for MPM was introduced based on the extent of peritoneal disease burden (T), intra-abdominal nodal metastasis (N), and extra-abdominal metastasis (M). The T stage is determined by calculating the peritoneal carcinomatosis index (PCI), which is based on lesion size and location. This staging system allows for better prognostic stratification.


 Malignant peritoneal mesothelioma.

answers_info.Explanation: Lesion size, not depth, is a component of calculating PCI for the T staging of MPM.
Lesion location, not mitotic rate, is a component of calculating PCI for the T staging of MPM.
Lymph node involvement accounts for the N staging of MPM, not the T stage.
Blood neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio level is a prognostic indicator for MPM but is not a contributor to the T stage.

references.Name: Yin W, Zheng G, Yang K, Song H, Liang Y. Analysis of prognostic factors of patients with malignant peritoneal mesothelioma. World J Surg Oncol. 2018;16(1):44.
Kim J, Bhagwandin S, Labow DM. Malignant peritoneal mesothelioma: a review. Ann Transl Med. 2017;5(11):236.

additional_image_sources.Name: Malignant peritoneal mesothelioma: Case Rep Emerg Med

908569.hint: Consider the elements that contribute to the T stage of malignant peritoneal mesothelioma; focus on aspects that relate to the tumor's characteristics in the abdominal cavity.

705562.question: A newborn infant develops projectile bilious vomiting soon after birth without abdominal distention on exam. Abdominal radiography shows a "double-bubble" sign, with both bubbles appearing to the right of the midline.  After resuscitation, the most appropriate next step in management includes
answers: Laparoscopic appendectomy and duodenocolonic dissociation (LADD) procedure

explanation.BottomLine: The most definitive form of treatment for duodenal atresia is surgical correction. The best procedure is an end-to-side or side-to-side duodenoduodenostomy.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Bilious (greenish-yellowish) projectile vomiting, abdominal distention, and a "double-bubble" sign are most suggestive of duodenal atresia (DA). The most definitive form of treatment is surgical correction. Surgery is typically performed once the neonate has been stabilized (e.g., metabolic and electrolyte abnormalities) and other conditions have been excluded (eg, volvulus). The best (and safest procedure) is an end-to-side or side-to-side duodenoduodenostomy.

answers_info.Explanation: No medical therapies exist for the definitive treatment of duodenal atresia.
Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics (eg, ampicillin and gentamicin) can be done postoperatively to avoid infection. It is not helpful preoperatively.

answers_info.Text: Laparoscopic appendectomy and duodenocolonic dissociation (LADD) procedure
answers_info.Explanation: The laparoscopic appendectomy and duodenocolic dissociation (LADD) procedure is used for malrotation where part of the bowel is adherent to the duodenum (hence, duodenocolonic dissociation). While the procedure is typically performed laparoscopically, an open approach is commonly undertaken as well. The Ladd procedure (not to be confused with the LADD procedure) for malrotation can be performed laparoscopically in the absence of volvulus or bowel ischemia, particularly in the older child or adult. It has been suggested that the laparoscopic approach may be associated with a higher recurrence rate, because of fewer adhesions after surgery. However, there have been no prospective studies to compare laparoscopic and open correction of malrotation, and the limited evidence from observational studies does not indicate that recurrence is more likely after laparoscopic repair.

Gastrojejunostomy is unnecessary in this case and the more appropriate operation is side-to-side duodenoduodenostomy. Furthermore, in neonates and in children GJ is not indicated for due to the mobility of their duodena in comparison to adults.

references.Name: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice.  Chapter 49: Small Intestine. 20th Edition.  2017.
Coran. Pediatric Surgery. Chapter 81: Duodenal Atresia and Stenosis -- Annular Pancreas. 2012
Intestinal Malrotation in Children

705562.hint: Consider the implications of the double-bubble sign in infants, as it is indicative of a specific anatomical issue that necessitates surgical intervention.

431005.question:
You are preparing to perform a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. You begin by placing the veress needle at the umbilicus and successfully establish a pneumoperitoneum.

What direction should you direct your trocar?
answers: Directly perpendicular to the anterior abdominal wall
Whichever direction that is easiest to penetrate the fascia
431005.correct_answer: Directly perpendicular to the anterior abdominal wall

explanation.BottomLine: Placement of your first, blind trocar should be perpendicular to the abdominal wall and directed away from the sacral promontory and away from the abdominal vessels.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Abdominal access with a veress needle is a typical method of establishing pneumoperotineum along with open technique (Hasson).  A safe principle of placing the first trocar includes entering perpendicular to the abdominal wall and directing the trocar away from the great vessels (i.e. aorta) and away from the sacral promontory. Holding the abdominal wall or over-inflating are different techniques to create more space between intra-abdominal organs and the abdominal wall. A visual entry port also decreases chances of vascular or bowel injury for initial trocar placement.  The remainder of the trocars that are placed can be directed under camera visualization also perpendicularly to prevent skiving and allow better range of movement.

answers_info.Explanation: This space is extraperitoneal. It is located posterior to the pubic symphysis and anterior to the urinary bladder. Directing your trocar towards this location blindly can injury major abdominal vessels or bladder.

answers_info.Text: Directly perpendicular to the anterior abdominal wall

answers_info.Explanation: Aiming the initial trocar at an angle will cause skiving and loss of range of movement of the trocar.
This is an unsafe direction with major abdominal vessels and abdominal viscera in an enclosed space.

answers_info.Text: Whichever direction that is easiest to penetrate the fascia
answers_info.Explanation: Indiscriminate placement of the first blind trocar is unsafe. The fascia at the umbilicus is the thinnest and should be easiest to penetrate. If the patient has had previous abdominal surgeries, then an alternate site such as the left upper quadrant should be accessed.

references.Name: Spight DH, Hunter JG, Jobe BA. Minimally Invasive Surgery, Robotics, Natural Orifice Transluminal Endoscopic Surgery, and Single-Incision Laparoscopic Surgery. In: Brunicardi F, Andersen DK, Billiar TR, Dunn DL, Hunter JG, Matthews JB, Pollock RE. eds. Schwartz's Principles of Surgery, 10e. New York, NY: McGraw-Hill; 2014.
Pryor, Aurora, Bates, Andrew T. "Abdominal access techniques used in laparoscopic surgery" UpToDate. May 8, 2018.

431005.hint: Consider the safety principles of trocar placement. Think about how the abdominal wall is positioned in relation to both the surgery and the major vessels.

827633.question: A 3-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with a bulge in the right groin. It occurred 2 hours ago and has not gone away. On examination, an inguinal hernia that appears to contain bowel is noted. What is the most appropriate course of action?
answers: reduction at bedside, then follow up as an outpatient for surgery after he is 1 year old
reduction at bedside, then immediate operative repair
reduction at bedside, followed by 24–48 hours of observation, then operative repair
observation and surgery if condition worsens
827633.correct_answer: reduction at bedside, followed by 24–48 hours of observation, then operative repair

explanation.BottomLine: All inguinal hernias in children need to be repaired. Attempts should be made to reduce the hernia, so a period of observation can allow the edema to decrease before operative repair is undertaken. Operative repair is high ligation of the hernia sac.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Inguinal hernias (IH) in children are more common in males and always need to be repaired when diagnosed. In children with incarcerated IH containing bowel, as seen here, attempts must be made to reduce the hernia, unless there is clinical evidence of peritonitis. This may require IV sedation and careful monitoring. If the reduction is successful, the child is admitted and observed for 24 to 48 hours.

The IH repair is done after the period of observation to allow for tissue edema to subside. On the other hand, if the IH cannot be reduced, the child is promptly taken to the OR for an inguinal exploration. If an intestinal resection is required, it can usually be done through the opened hernia sac before IH repair.


Clinical image (left) demonstrating an inguinoscrotal swelling due to an indirect inguinal hernia with a bowel loop herniating into the scrotum as illustrated in the schematic diagram (right).

827633.mainTopic: Inguinal Hernia - Management In Infants, Surgery

answers_info.Text: reduction at bedside, then follow up as an outpatient for surgery after he is 1 year old
answers_info.Explanation: Operative repair should be scheduled within 24–48 hours as the risk of incarceration and bowel strangulation is significant.

answers_info.Text: reduction at bedside, then immediate operative repair
answers_info.Explanation: Operative repair should be delayed 24–48 hours to allow for dissipation of tissue edema.

answers_info.Text: reduction at bedside, followed by 24–48 hours of observation, then operative repair
observation and surgery if condition worsens
answers_info.Explanation: An attempt at reduction should be made. Extended observation may lead to bowel ischemia.
Operative repair should be delayed 24–48 hours, if the hernia is able to be reduced, to allow for dissipation of tissue edema.

references.Name: Chung D. Chapter 67: Pediatric surgery. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:1844-1882.
Inguinal hernia in children: UpToDate
Image source:
Inguinal hernia: IntechOpen

827633.hint: Consider what must be done immediately to address a hernia containing bowel and how long the patient should be monitored before definitive surgery.

672922.question: A 74-year-old man is scheduled to undergo gastrectomy for severe ulcer disease. After induction of general anesthesia using succinylcholine and isoflurane, severe hypertension and cardiac dysrhythmias are noted. In addition to dantrolene, the treatment should include
answers: administer potassium to stabilize cardiac membrane

explanation.BottomLine: Malignant hyperthermia is a serious but rare consequence of anesthesia and should be recognized quickly and responded to swiftly with the administration of dantrolene. Acidosis is corrected by the administration of bicarbonate.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Malignant hyperthermia is a rare life-threatening condition that is usually triggered by exposure to certain drugs used for general anesthesia—specifically the volatile anesthetic agents and succinylcholine, a neuromuscular blocking agent. In susceptible individuals, these drugs can induce a drastic and uncontrolled increase in oxidative metabolism in skeletal muscle, which overwhelms the body's capacity to supply oxygen, remove carbon dioxide, and regulate body temperature, eventually leading to circulatory collapse and death if not immediately treated.

The current treatment of choice is the IV administration of dantrolene, the only known antidote, discontinuation of triggering agents, and supportive therapy directed at correcting hyperthermia, acidosis, and organ dysfunction. Treatment must be instituted rapidly on clinical suspicion of the onset of malignant hyperthermia. Hyperthermia is corrected with cooling blankets, acetaminophen, and ice packs. Acidosis, as in this case, is corrected by the administration of bicarbonate.

Dantrolene is a muscle relaxant that appears to work directly on the ryanodine receptor to prevent the release of calcium. After the widespread introduction of treatment with dantrolene, the mortality of malignant hyperthermia fell from 80% in the 1960s to less than 5%.

answers_info.Explanation: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing type of neuromuscular blocking agent and no specific reversal agent is currently approved for succinylcholine. The immediate steps after suspecting malignant hyperthermia are discontinuing inhalational anesthetic agents and succinylcholine, completely changing the anesthesia circuit, and administering dantrolene sodium.
Continuing the operation would not be wise and would result in unwanted morbidity or mortality.

answers_info.Text: administer potassium to stabilize cardiac membrane
answers_info.Explanation: Malignant hyperthermia causes the release of potassium from the intracellular compartment, leading to hyperkalemia, and administering potassium is therefore not the right step.
Hyperventilation, and not hypoventilation, to remove excess carbon dioxide and increase oxygen supply is recommended.

references.Name: Riazi S, Kraeva N, Hopkins PM. Updated guide for the management of malignant hyperthermia. Can J Anaesth. 2018;65(6):709-721.

Neumayer L, Ghalyaie N. Chapter 10: Principles of preoperative and operative surgery. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 20th ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2017:201-240.

672922.hint: Consider the impact of acidosis in this scenario. How would administering a bicarbonate solution help in counteracting the physiological effects observed?

824469.question: A 27-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with COVID-19. Her oxygenation status deteriorates, and she is intubated. She becomes hypoxemic to 57% despite maximum ventilator support. Cardiovascular surgery is emergently consulted for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation cannulation. There are several residents and young attendings on the team. After cannulation, the patient begins hemorrhaging from the cannulation site and quickly expires. What would have been most helpful at preventing this complication?
answers: fast-tracking discharges to open up hospital beds
immediate administration of IV steroids and remdesivir
restricting extracorporeal membrane oxygenation cannulation to senior providers

explanation.BottomLine: Simulation training can reduce complications, especially in critical or emergent surgical situations, by allowing surgical team members to practice and develop the technical as well as non-technical skills needed for these scenarios.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
In this scenario, a young and healthy patient quickly deteriorated in a medical emergency. Due to the emergent nature of her condition, treatment protocols occurred quickly and urgently. Unfortunately, this resulted in a preventable complication. Such complications can often be avoided (or their frequency reduced) through simulation training.

Simulation has become a mainstay in medical education, with improved outcomes and a shorter time required for intervention. In scenarios like respiratory decline needing extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) cannulation, simulation is incredibly important. Creating a safe environment for learners to develop good routines and habits can help prevent complications when faced with a real clinical scenario.

Key Crisis Management Principles and Behaviors
Decision-making and cognition Teamwork and resource management
Know the environment Exercise leadership and followership
Anticipate and plan Call for help early
Use all available information, cross-check Communicate effectively
Prevent or manage fixation errors Distribute the workload
Use cognitive aids Mobilize all available resources for optimum management

answers_info.Text: fast-tracking discharges to open up hospital beds
answers_info.Explanation: Although the patient should ideally be admitted to a hospital bed, the post-cannulation complication would likely still occur. The location of cannulation should not make a difference, as it is often urgent and should be prepared to be performed anywhere.

answers_info.Text: immediate administration of IV steroids and remdesivir
answers_info.Explanation: Although IV steroids and remdesivir are mainstays of treatment for COVID-19, it would not have reduced the likelihood of the complication that resulted in this scenario.
Inhaled erythropoietin is an important component of COVID-19 treatment but would not help prevent the post-cannulation complication.

answers_info.Text: restricting extracorporeal membrane oxygenation cannulation to senior providers
answers_info.Explanation: Teams often consist of providers of varying levels of expertise. Having a team of only senior providers is not feasible and prevents trainees from learning.

references.Name: Meling TR, Meling TR. The impact of surgical simulation on patient outcomes: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Neurosurg Rev. 2021;44(2):843-854.
Sin SWC, Ng PY, Ngai WCW, Lai PCK, Mok AYT, Chan RWK. Simulation training for crises during venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation. J Thorac Dis. 2019;11(5):2144-2152.

824469.hint: Consider how training and experience may influence outcomes in high-stakes medical procedures, particularly regarding technical and team skills.

953118.question: A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care doctor 2 weeks after several episodes of hematemesis. He was on an international business trip during these episodes and did not seek care. His bowel movements have been slightly darker but otherwise unremarkable. He has known cirrhosis from alcohol use, with no recent follow-up due to his busy work schedule. He continues to drink alcohol. The patient is hemodynamically stable and has not had hematemesis since the initial episodes 2 weeks ago. He denies any other complaints. He would like to know if he is likely to have a bleeding episode again and if anything can be done to prevent them. Which of the following is the best modality to evaluate the etiology of the patient's hematemesis?

explanation.BottomLine: EGD is the best modality for the evaluation and treatment of esophageal varices.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Esophageal varices are a known consequence of liver disease. In this patient, who has cirrhosis with no recent follow-up, esophageal varices are the etiology of hematemesis in approximately 50% of cases. However, his episodes of hematemesis could also have been caused by nonvariceal sources, such as peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, or a Mallory-Weiss tear, especially considering that the bleeding was self limited. 

EGD is the gold standard and first-line methodology for the diagnosis and management of esophageal varices. It is also useful in evaluating nonvariceal sources of bleeding. Early evaluation is critical in many cases because uncontrolled variceal bleeding can lead to catastrophic hemodynamic collapse. Up to 90% of esophageal varices are successfully controlled with endoscopic management such as banding, clipping, and epinephrine injection. Sometimes, 2 or 3 endoscopic interventions are needed within 24 hours.

Approximately 70% of patients with esophageal varices will have another bleed within 2 months. Even in the post acute setting, if nonbleeding varices are visualized, they should be banded. The patient should also be placed on proton pump inhibitors and/or sucralfate therapy. EGD may be repeated every 10-14 days until all esophageal varices have been eradicated.

answers_info.Explanation: CT with oral contrast is not a sensitive test for esophageal varices. Findings may suggest distal esophageal thickening; however, several other conditions such as hiatal hernias, esophagitis, and Mallory-Weiss tears may mimic the findings.

Capsule endoscopy may visualize esophageal varices and other causes of upper GI bleeding; however, it is not possible to perform interventions using this modality. EGD allows both diagnosis and immediate intervention. Capsule endoscopy is better used to evaluate for other sources if EGD is negative for abnormal findings.

Spleno-portal index is of historic significance in evaluating esophageal varices. It was previously described to be the most sensitive test; however, it has been surpassed by EGD as the gold standard. Additionally, it is not possible to intervene using the spleno-portal index. Therefore, it is not the best modality for evaluation.
Lateral chest x-ray provides no information on esophageal varices or other causes of upper GI bleeding. It may provide information regarding suspected esophageal perforation.

references.Name: Chapter 47. Acute Gastrointestinal Hemorrhage. In: Townsend C, Beauchamp RD, Evers BM, Mattox KL, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:1150-1166.
Kamboj AK, Hoversten P, Leggett CL. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding: etiologies and management. Mayo Clin Proc. 2019;94(4):697-703.

Antil, N, Sureka B, Mittal MK, et al. Hepatic venous waveform, splenoportal and damping index in liver cirrhosis: correlation with child pugh's score and oesophageal varices. J Clin Diagn Res. 2016;10(2):TC01-5.
Colli A, Gana JC, Turner D, et al. Capsule endoscopy for the diagnosis of oesophageal varices in people with chronic liver disease or portal vein thrombosis. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2014;10.

953118.hint: Consider the primary condition affecting this patient and the common procedures used to assess complications associated with liver disease, especially ones that also allow for intervention.

1058123.question: A 40-year-old male farmer presents to the surgery clinic with a dark skin lesion over his left arm that has recently become ulcerated. A punch biopsy of the lesion is performed, revealing a malignant cutaneous melanoma with 0.8-mm Breslow depth. The remainder of his skin exam is unremarkable, and he has no evidence of axillary lymphadenopathy on examination. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
answers: wide local excision with 1 cm margins
wide local excision with 2 cm margins
wide local excision with 1 cm margins and a sentinel lymph node biopsy
perform a PET/CT scan of the chest, abdomen, pelvis, and an MRI brain before surgical excision
1058123.correct_answer: wide local excision with 1 cm margins and a sentinel lymph node biopsy

explanation.BottomLine: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is indicated in clinically non-palpable lymph nodes in melanomas with a Breslow depth of > 1.0 mm and in melanomas with a depth of 0.8 - 1.0 mm with high-risk features for lymphatic metastasis, including primary tumor ulceration, high mitotic rate (≥ 2/mm<sup>2</sup>), primary tumor lymphovascular invasion, age ≤ 42, and head/neck location.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Melanomas that have not metastasized beyond regional lymph nodes are treated with wide local excision. The Breslow depth (depth of the tumor into the skin and subcutaneous tissue) determines the margins of the excision. This patient is ≤ age 42 and his primary tumor has a Breslow depth of 0.8 mm and is ulcerated. Ulceration is associated with a higher risk for regional nodal metastasis. Therefore, this patient's melanoma should be managed with wide local excision with 1 cm margins and a sentinel lymph node biopsy.

Sentinel lymph node biopsies are used to evaluate whether the melanoma has spread to regional lymph nodes. A sentinel lymph node biopsy is indicated in clinically non-palpable lymph nodes in melanomas with a Breslow depth of > 1.0 mm. In melanomas with a Breslow depth between 0.8 and 1.0 mm, sentinel lymph node biopsy is suggested based on the presence of any additional risk factors:
  • Primary tumor ulceration
  • High mitotic rate (≥ 2/mm2)
  • Primary tumor lymphovascular invasion
  • Age ≤ 42 years
  • Head/neck location
Breslow Depth of Melanoma and Corresponding Surgical Margins of Wide Local Excision
Breslow Depth of Tumor (Thickness) (mm) Wide Local Excision Margin (cm)
In situ 0.5
< 1  1 
1–2  1–2 
> 2 2

answers_info.Explanation: Mohs micrographic surgery is not a standard treatment for melanoma except in highly specialized centers and for cosmetically sensitive lesions such as on the face.

answers_info.Text: wide local excision with 1 cm margins
answers_info.Explanation: Wide local excision with 1 cm margins would be appropriate for a lesion with a Breslow depth of 0.8 mm if the patient did not have ulceration of his lesion. With the presence of ulceration, the patient should undergo a sentinel lymph node biopsy because of the increased risk of lymphatic spread.

answers_info.Text: wide local excision with 2 cm margins
answers_info.Explanation: A melanoma with a Breslow depth of > 1 mm (not < 1 mm) is excised with 2 cm margins.

answers_info.Text: wide local excision with 1 cm margins and a sentinel lymph node biopsy
perform a PET/CT scan of the chest, abdomen, pelvis, and an MRI brain before surgical excision
answers_info.Explanation: A staging workup with a PET/CT of the torso and an MRI brain is only indicated in advanced stage III melanoma with clinically palpable lymph nodes or in melanoma where the patient's symptoms are suggestive of metastatic spread.

references.Name: Chapter 31: Melanoma and cutaneous malignancies. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier, 2022:705-733.

Wong SL, Faries MB, Kennedy EB, et al. Sentinel lymph node biopsy and management of regional lymph nodes in melanoma: American Society of Clinical Oncology and Society of Surgical Oncology clinical practice guideline update. Ann Surg Oncol. 2018;25(2):356-377.
NCCN Guidelines® Melanoma: Cutaneous Version 3.2023 — October 27, 2023
Evaluation and management of regional nodes in primary cutaneous melanoma - Uptodate

1058123.hint: Consider the characteristics of the melanoma. The Breslow depth is a key factor in determining the next steps. Additionally, the presence of ulceration and the patient's age may suggest an increased risk for regional metastasis, thus consider what surgical approach would be appropriate.

648826.question: A 45-year-old man involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision is taken to the operating room for a positive focused assessment with sonography for trauma (FAST) exam and persistent hypotension. A liver laceration is repaired. Upon further exploration, a grade II pancreatic body and tail hematoma is noted. No active bleeding is present. Initial surgical management entails which of the following?

explanation.BottomLine: Grade II pancreatic injuries discovered intraoperatively can be safely managed with wide drainage. Grade II injuries seen on imaging can be managed nonoperatively, but main duct disruption must be excluded.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Pancreatic injuries are graded based on the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Pancreas Organ Injury Scale, which classifies injury based on location and the presence of main pancreatic duct disruption.

Grade II injuries include hematomas that encompass more than one portion of the pancreas and lacerations < 50% the total circumference. The majority of grade II injuries can be safely treated with wide drainage and hemostasis control. Excessive debridement or attempts at repair can cause injury to the main duct.

Grade I and II injuries seen on imaging can be managed nonoperatively, but main duct disruption must be excluded.

answers_info.Explanation: Debridement of the hematoma may cause injury to the main pancreatic duct.
Distal pancreatectomy is reserved for grade III injuries in which distal transection or parenchymal injury is accompanied by ductal injury.
Pancreaticoduodenectomy is reserved for devastating injuries to the head of the pancreas.
Even minor pancreatic hematomas or lacerations can leak pancreatic enzymes, causing damage to surrounding structures and prolonged ileus. Therefore, drains should be placed.

references.Name: Biffl WL. Chapter 32: Duodenum and pancreas. In: Moore EE, ed. Trauma. 8th ed. New York: McGraw-Hill; 2017.

648826.hint: Consider the management approach for grade II pancreatic injuries. What is the common procedure to facilitate drainage without excessive surgical intervention?

855499.question: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath. CT scan of the chest shows a large right-side pleural effusion. Thoracentesis is performed. Biochemical analysis of the fluid shows a pleural fluid-to-serum protein ratio > 0.5 and a pleural fluid-to-serum LDH ratio > 0.6. Which of the following is the most likely cause of pleural effusion in this patient?

explanation.BottomLine: Common causes of exudative effusion are pneumonia, malignancy, infection, and chylothorax.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The etiology of pleural effusion is classified as either transudate or exudate, based on the chemical composition of the fluid. They have different causes which makes them clinically significant. An effusion is considered exudative if 1 of the following findings is present:
  1. A pleural fluid–to–serum protein ratio > 0.5
  2. A pleural fluid–to–serum LDH ratio > 0.6
  3. A pleural fluid LDH concentration > two-thirds of the upper limit of the serum reference range.
Some of the common causes of exudate effusion are pneumonia, malignancy, infection, and chylothorax.

In broad terms, transudate fluid results from an imbalance in oncotic pressure (tries to keep the fluid in) and hydrostatic pressure (tries to push the fluid out) across the capillary membrane, while exudate effusion results from an insult to the capillary membrane itself causing the "capillary leak." The insult can be inflammatory, traumatic, or neoplastic.

Common Causes of Pleural Effusions
Transudative Exudative
  • Cirrhosis
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Autoimmune (sarcoidosis)
  • Chylothorax
  • Infections (empyema, pneumonia, tuberculosis)
  • Malignancy
  • Pancreatitis

answers_info.Explanation: Congestive heart failure causes increased pooling of blood in the lungs. This leads to increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure and causes more fluid to leak out in the interstitium. There is no inflammation at the capillary level, so the fluid that leaks out is protein-poor, or transudate. Heart failure is actually the most common cause of transudate pleural effusion.

Pleural effusion in liver cirrhosis is seen due to decreased serum albumin, thereby decreasing the oncotic pressure. It can manifest as hepatic hydrothorax in around 5-6% of patients with end-stage liver disease. It is defined as a pleural effusion in a patient with portal hypertension and no cardiopulmonary disease. It results from the movement of ascitic fluid from the peritoneal cavity into the pleural space through diaphragmatic defects.
Nephrotic syndrome causes serum hypoalbuminemia and decreases oncotic pressure resulting in more fluid leaking out in the interstitium. It can manifest as pleural effusion.

Chronic renal failure causes a chronic hypervolemic state with electrolyte abnormalities, causing increased hydrostatic pressure. It causes more fluid to leak out in the interstitium and can manifest as pleural effusion.
