answers_info.Explanation: PRAD1 oncogene is overexpressed in 20–40% of parathyroid adenomas, but the gene testing is not required prior to adenoma resection.

answers_info.Text: bilateral neck dissection and adenoma removal
answers_info.Explanation: Bilateral neck dissection is not required for adenoma.

A 3 1/2 gland parathyroidectomy is usually done in cases of hyperplasia, which is present in 15% of the patients with hyperparathyroidism. Of the patients with hyperparathyroidism, 80% commonly have single parathyroid adenoma.

answers_info.Text: total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation into the forearm
answers_info.Explanation: Similar to 3 1/2 gland parathyroidectomy, total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation into the forearm is usually done in cases of hyperplasia which is present in 15% of the patients with hyperparathyroidism.

references.Name: The Parathyroid Glands. In Townsend C et al., eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 20th Ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2017.

462935.hint: Consider what imaging studies are typically conducted before surgery for conditions related to high PTH and calcium levels. This could help in identifying any abnormalities in the parathyroid glands prior to surgical intervention.

801872.question: Which of the following genes is responsible for the most common genetic alteration in pancreatic cancer?

explanation.BottomLine: Activating point mutations in the KRAS oncogene are the most common genetic alteration in pancreatic cancer.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Multiple combinations of genetic mutations are commonly found in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas, which can be divided into three broad categories, summarized in the table below.

Genetic Abnormalities in Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma
Genetic Abnormality Gene Involved % PDAC with the Mutated Gene
Activation of oncogenes: constitutive activation and loss of regulation of mitogen-activated protein kinase cell signal transduction KRAS >95% in invasive PDAC, 36% of PanIN-1 cases, 44% of PanIN-2 cases, and 87% of PanIN-3 cases
Inactivation of tumor suppressor genes p16/CDKN2A ~90% of invasive PDAC
TP53 ~75-80% of invasive PDAC
SMAD4/DPC4 20-30% of PanIN-3 and localized cancers, whereas ~50-70% of widely metastatic tumors show loss of DPC4
Inactivation of genome maintenance genes mutL homolog 1 (MLH1), mutS homolog 2 (MSH2), and mutS homolog 6 (MSH6) ~2-4% of invasive PDAC
PanIN = pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia, PDAC = pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.


Illustration © TrueLearn, LLC

801872.mainTopic: Pancreatic Cancer - Most Common Genetic Alteration

answers_info.Explanation: The DPC4 gene is inactive in about 50-75% of pancreatic cancers.
The function of p53 is inactivated in about 75-80% of all pancreatic cancers.

Familial pancreatic cancer tends to aggregate in families and mutations in certain genes when inherited predispose to pancreatic cancer. As many as 20% of patients with pancreatic cancer have germline mutations in these cancer predisposition genes; however, sporadic pancreatic cancer, which harbors the somatic mutations discussed on the top, is still the most common form of pancreatic cancer.

The germline mutations in the following genes predispose to pancreatic cancer:
  • BRCA2: increases the risk of pancreatic cancer 3- to 10-fold, is present in ~15-20% of all familial pancreatic cancers.
  • PALB2: increases the risk of pancreatic cancer 15-fold, is present in ~3-5% of all familial pancreatic cancers.
  • STK11: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, is present in ~4% of all familial pancreatic cancers.
  • ATM: increases the risk of pancreatic cancer 8- to 9-fold, is present in ~3% of all familial pancreatic cancers.
  • Lynch syndrome.
Disorders of DNA mismatch-repair genes are present in ~2-4% of pancreatic cancers.

references.Name: Dudeja V, Christein JD, Jensen EH, Vickers SM. Chapter 55: Exocrine pancreas. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 20th ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2017:1520-1555.

Nakeeb A, House MG, Lillemoe KD. Chapter 55: Neoplasms of the exocrine pancreas. In: Mulholland MW, ed. Greenfield's Surgery: Scientific Principles and Practice. 6th ed. Philadelphia: Wolters Kluwer; 2016:879-898.
Molecular Pathogenesis of Exocrine Pancreatic Cancer on UpToDate

801872.hint: Consider which gene is known to be frequently mutated in pancreatic cancer and note that it is involved in oncogenic activation.

620865.question: A 35-year-old woman was involved in a motor vehicle accident. The emergency responder reports that her right knee was dislocated at the scene and that he has reduced it. On your assessment, the bilateral lower extremities are warm and well perfused without gross deformity. Motor function, sensation, and distal pulses are also intact bilaterally. What is the next step in the work-up of this patient for a possible vascular injury?
answers: obtain x-rays of the lower extremities

explanation.BottomLine: The first steps with any suspected vascular injury related to blunt trauma without hard signs to mandate immediate operative intervention are a thorough vascular exam and obtaining an ankle-brachial index (ABI).
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
In the absence of hard signs of vascular injury, the first step in the work-up of possible vascular injury is thorough vascular examination and obtaining an ankle-brachial index (ABI). 

The following table summarizes the preferred management based on examination and ABI findings.

Management of Vascular Injury Following Lower Extremity Blunt Trauma
Examination and ABI Management
Distal pulse present with well-perfused limb, ABI >0.9 Observation
Asymmetry in distal pulse or normal physical exam, ABI <0.9 Angiogram 
Distal pulse absent or hard signs of vascular injury (distal ischemia, active hemorrhage, pulsatile bleeding, or expanding hematoma) Operating room

answers_info.Explanation: Vascular surgery consultation is premature in this patient that does not have an established vascular injury.

answers_info.Text: obtain x-rays of the lower extremities
answers_info.Explanation: Plain films will not aid in the diagnosis of a vascular injury but may be ordered if there are signs of bony instability.

A CT angiogram should be obtained if there is a high suspicion for a vascular injury, such as in the setting of asymmetric distal pulses or if the ABI is <0.9, but is not the next best step in this patient.
An orthopedic consult may be indicated to assess for ligamentous injury following knee dislocation but is not the next best step in this patient.

references.Name: Sise MJ, Brown CVR, Champion HC. Chapter 63: Vascular trauma. In: Townsend C, Beauchamp RD, Evers BM, et al, eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 20th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2017:1808-1826.

Smith RM. Chapter 28: The principles of orthopedic surgery for trauma. In: Mulholland MW, Lillemoe K, Doherty G, eds. Greenfield's Surgery: Scientific Principles and Practice. 6th ed. New York: Wolters
Kluwer; 2016:444-456.

620865.hint: Consider the next step in managing vascular injury in a patient with a stable examination. You should look for methods to assess vascular status without immediate signs of injury.

1052516.question: A 55-year-old woman presents for a screening colonoscopy. After intubation of the terminal ileum, the endoscopist begins to withdraw the scope. A 5-mm sessile polyp is visualized in the lumen of the descending colon, and the decision is made to proceed with polyp excision. Which of the following techniques would be best in this situation with regards to completeness of excision?
answers: Piecemeal resection with standard cold forceps
Polyp brought to the 6 o'clock position, polyp and surrounding margin are ensnared, and firm downward pressure is used during resection as cautery is applied
Polyp brought to the 6 o'clock position, polyp and surrounding margin are ensnared and tented away from the mucosa for resection as cautery is applied
Polyp brought to the 6 o'clock position, polyp and surrounding margin are ensnared, and firm downward pressure is used during resection
1052516.correct_answer: Polyp brought to the 6 o'clock position, polyp and surrounding margin are ensnared, and firm downward pressure is used during resection

explanation.BottomLine: When performing a cold snare polypectomy, the polyp is brought to the 6 o'clock position and ensnared with a margin of healthy tissue. Firm downward pressure is used for the transection.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
There are multiple methods for removing a polyp during colonoscopy.  These include use of biopsy forceps via either hot or cold technique as well as use of snare polypectomy via either hot or cold technique.  Based on the most recent recommendations of the European Society of Gastrointestinal Endoscopy (ESGE), for sessile polyps 1-5 mm cold snare polypectomy is recommended and for sessile polyps 6-9 mm cold snare polypectomy is suggested.  This is because cold snare polypectomy has been shown in multiple studies to have fewer incomplete polyp resections with an improved safety profile in sessile polyps.  Studies have shown the rate of incomplete resection to be 3-6% in cold snare polypectomies and 6-10% in hot snare polypectomies for polyps 1-9 mm in size.  In a few studies comparing hot snare and cold snare polypectomies, even bleeding was less common in cold snare polypectomies.     

For cold snare polypectomy, the best method for resection is the 6 o'clock positioning of the polyp and downward pressure during resection. This is also called the push and close technique. It is important to ensnare a margin of healthy tissue to ensure complete resection of the polyp.  The patient above has a 5 mm sessile polyp so the most ideal way to proceed is with a cold snare polypectomy.  

For sessile lesions larger than 9 mm hot snare polypectomy or endoscopic mucosal resection can be used depending on the size.  Pedunculated polyps should be resected via hot snare technique based on ESGE recommendations.  Tenting of the mucosa is used when performing a hot snare polypectomy to avoid damage to the underlying tissue.


Comparison of cold versus hot snare polypectomy are shown in the table below.
  Cold Snare Polypectomy Hot Snare Polypectomy
Lesion positioning 6 o'clock 6 o'clock
Extent of biopsy Includes lesion and margin of 
normal tissue		 Only incorporates lesion
Snare pressure Firm downward pressure Lesion tented away from the
surface
Transection speed Varies, but important to ensure 
proper seating of target lesion		 Rapid to avoid deep thermal
injury

answers_info.Text: Piecemeal resection with standard cold forceps
answers_info.Explanation: Biopsy forceps polypectomy should generally be avoided unless the lesion is 1-3 mm and is in a position which would be hard to excise via snare polypectomy.  Standard forceps polypectomy can lead to incomplete resection in up to 25% of cases.  Piecemeal polypectomy invariably leads to incomplete excision and should be avoided if at all possible.

Polyp excision with jumbo forceps mildly decreases the rate of incomplete excision compared to standard forceps polypectomy but the rate is still around 20%.  Additionally, hot forceps polypectomy increases the risk of thermal damage to the bowel wall and should generally be avoided.

answers_info.Text: Polyp brought to the 6 o'clock position, polyp and surrounding margin are ensnared, and firm downward pressure is used during resection as cautery is applied
answers_info.Explanation: Firm downward pressure should never be applied while using cautery otherwise one will cauterize through the bowel wall and cause a thermal injury.  Whenever cautery is applied for a snare polypectomy, the mucosa and lesion should be tented upwards to avoid bowel wall thermal injury.

answers_info.Text: Polyp brought to the 6 o'clock position, polyp and surrounding margin are ensnared and tented away from the mucosa for resection as cautery is applied
answers_info.Explanation: Six o'clock is the proper position of the polyp, but the polyp and surrounding mucosa must be ensnared with downward pressure being used when performing cold snare polypectomy. This answer choice describes the technique for performing a hot snare polypectomy.  Hot snare polypectomy is no longer recommended for sessile lesions 1-9 mm as cold snare polypectomy has a better safety profile and lower rates of incomplete resection (3-6% incomplete resection in cold snare polypectomy vs 6-10% incomplete resection in hot snare polypectomy).  Hot snare polypectomy is still recommended in sessile polyps 10-19 mm and for pedunculated polyps, neither of which this patient has.

answers_info.Text: Polyp brought to the 6 o'clock position, polyp and surrounding margin are ensnared, and firm downward pressure is used during resection

references.Name: Bourke MJ. Top tips for cold snare polypectomy (with video). Gastrointest Endosc. 2022;95(6):1226-1232.

Ferlitsch, Monika; et al.  "Colorectal polypectomy and endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR): European Society of Gastrointestinal Endoscopy (ESGE) Clinical Guideline".  European Society of Gastrointestinal Endoscopy.  Endoscopy 2017; 49(03): 270-297.  Accessed 15 December 2023.
Standard polypectomy techniques: choosing the right technique: ASGE Joint Panel

1052516.hint: Consider the recommended position for the polyp during excision and the technique that ensures a margin of healthy tissue is included for complete resection.

453757.question:
A 71-year-old male with a history of diabetes presents to the emergency room with a left foot ulcer.  The ulcer has been present for two weeks and has some mild purulent discharge and erythema.  He has palpable femoral pulses but only monophasic pedal signals.  There are no signs of acute ischemia.  

The next BEST step in management for this patient is:
answers: Duplex ultrasound of the left leg

explanation.BottomLine: The first diagnostic step in the evaluation of a diabetic foot wound is a plain radiograph.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Diabetic foot ulcers are one of the most common causes for hospitalization.  Over 50% of diabetic foot ulcers will become infected.  Risk factors for an ulcer infection include neuropathy, peripheral vascular disease, presence for over 30 days, and history of trauma.  The first step in management of these patients is to rule out an aggressive infection or osteomyelitis with a plain radiograph.  The presence of air on the
X-ray suggest a necrotizing infection that requires immediate surgical intervention.  Bony abnormalities can be seen on radiographic images which can diagnose osteomyelitis and will alter the treatment algorithm.  These patients will need multi-disciplinary care to optimize the healing potential of wound, including nutrition, diabetes management, need for revascularization, and bacteriology.

answers_info.Explanation: Superficial cultures may not capture all of the bacteria present in the wound.
Angiography and duplex can be useful in the vascular assessment but are not the first step in evaluation.
Deep tissue biopsies are best performed after the wound has been cleaned and debrided.

answers_info.Text: Duplex ultrasound of the left leg
answers_info.Explanation: Angiography and duplex can be useful in the vascular assessment but are not the first step in evaluation.

453757.hint: Consider the common first step in evaluating a foot ulcer, especially in diabetic patients, which often involves imaging to assess for underlying conditions.

720298.question: Of the following congenital heart defects, which is considered a non-cyanotic heart defect?
answers: pulmonary atresia with an intact ventricular septum

explanation.BottomLine: The cyanotic congenital heart defects include Tetralogy of Fallot, transposition of the great vessels, pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum, pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect, and valvular pulmonic stenosis.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Cyanotic heart defects are a group or type of congenital heart defects (CHDs). The patient appears cyanotic due to deoxygenated blood bypassing the lungs and entering the systemic circulation. They can be caused by right-to-left or bidirectional shunting, or malposition of the great arteries.

Cyanotic heart defects, which account for approximately 25% of all CHDs, include the following:
  • Tetralogy of Fallot 
  • Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection 
  • Hypoplastic left heart syndrome 
  • Transposition of the great arteries 
  • Truncus arteriosus (persistent) 
  • Tricuspid atresia 
  • Interrupted aortic arch 
  • Pulmonary atresia 
  • Pulmonary stenosis 
  • Eisenmenger syndrome (reversal of shunt due to pulmonary hypertension)
  • Patent ductus arteriosus (may cause cyanosis in late stage)
Non-cyanotic heart defects are more common because of their higher survival rate. In these, the shunt is initially from left (oxygenated) to right (non-oxygenated) and include the following:
  • Atrial septal defect
  • Ventricular septal defect 
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Double outlet left/right ventricle

answers_info.Text: pulmonary atresia with an intact ventricular septum
answers_info.Explanation: Pulmonary atresia is a cyanotic heart defect.
Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic heart defect.
Transposition of the great vessels is a cyanotic heart defect.
Valvular pulmonic stenosis is a cyanotic heart defect.

references.Name: Well A, Fraser CD. Chapter 59: Congenital heart disease. In Townsend CM, Beauchamp RD, Evers BM, Mattox KL, eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:1641-1678.

720298.hint: Think about the types of congenital heart defects. Non-cyanotic heart defects often involve a left-to-right shunt, where oxygenated blood mixes with non-oxygenated blood. Which option represents this characteristic?

770894.question: A 25 year-old-man sustains a gunshot wound to the abdomen. He undergoes an emergency exploratory laparotomy and is found to have an extensive laceration to the liver surface. Despite packing, there is still evidence of extensive bleeding. A Pringle maneuver is attempted to help identify the source of the bleeding. What is the correct orientation of structures in the hepatoduodenal ligament?
answers: bile duct lateral, hepatic artery medial, portal vein posterior
bile duct medial, hepatic artery lateral, portal vein posterior
portal vein lateral, hepatic artery medial, bile duct posterior
portal vein medial, hepatic artery lateral, bile duct posterior
bile duct lateral, portal vein medial, hepatic artery posterior
770894.correct_answer: bile duct lateral, hepatic artery medial, portal vein posterior

explanation.BottomLine: The hepatic artery and portal system both supply the liver with blood but in very different quantities. The portal vein provides 70% of the blood supply to the liver. The hepatic artery provides 30% of the blood supply.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The hepatoduodenal ligament is the portion of the lesser omentum extending between the porta hepatis of the liver and the superior part of the duodenum. Running inside it are the following structures collectively known as the portal triad:
  • Hepatic artery proper (medial)
  • Portal vein (posterior)
  • Common bile duct (lateral)

 


Hepatoduodenal contents with the correct orientation of its structures.

The liver has a dual blood supply from the hepatic artery and portal vein. Approximately 30% of the hepatic blood flow is from the hepatic artery, a branch of the celiac artery. The remainder is from the hepatic portal vein, which drains the GI tract. Because of the difference in oxygen content, they each provide 50% of oxygen delivered to the liver. The hepatic drainage is by way of the hepatic veins, which empties into the inferior vena cava.

Manual compression of the hepatoduodenal ligament during surgery is known as the Pringle maneuver. If the Pringle maneuver reduces the hemorrhage, the source of bleeding is the portal system or the hepatic arterial system, and not the hepatic veins.


Pringle maneuver clamping across the hepatoduodenal structures.

770894.modifier: Provided By Hepatic Artery And Portal Vein

answers_info.Text: bile duct lateral, hepatic artery medial, portal vein posterior
bile duct medial, hepatic artery lateral, portal vein posterior
answers_info.Explanation:
Bile duct medial, hepatic artery lateral, portal vein posterior would be the correct answer if the patient has situs inversus totalis, a congenital condition that involves complete transposition (right to left reversal) of the thoracic and abdominal organs.

The correct orientation for hepatoduodenal structures:
  • Hepatic artery proper (medial)
  • Common bile duct (lateral)
  • Portal vein (posterior)

Coronal contrast-enhanced CT of the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis. CT shows situs inversus totalis, including dextrocardia, right-sided gastric bubble, and reversed spleen and liver.

answers_info.Text: portal vein lateral, hepatic artery medial, bile duct posterior
answers_info.Explanation:
The portal vein is always the most posterior structure in the hepatoduodenal ligament. Behind the portal vein lies the foramen of Winslow. In human anatomy, the foramen of Winslow ( also known as epiploic foramen) is the passage into the lesser sac.


The black arrow shows the entry to the omental foramen (foramen of Winslow, marked white).

The correct orientation for hepatoduodenal structures:
  • Hepatic artery proper (medial)
  • Common bile duct (lateral)
  • Portal vein (posterior)

answers_info.Text: portal vein medial, hepatic artery lateral, bile duct posterior
answers_info.Explanation:
The portal vein is always the most posterior structure in the hepatoduodenal ligament. A mnemonic use for structures of Hepatoduodenal Ligament is DAVE (Arranged in order from anterior to posterior):
  • D uct (common bile)
  • A rtery (hepatic)
  • V ein (portal)
  • E piploic foramen

answers_info.Text: bile duct lateral, portal vein medial, hepatic artery posterior
answers_info.Explanation:
The hepatic artery does not lie posterior to the portal vein.

The correct orientation for hepatoduodenal structures:
  • Hepatic artery proper (medial)
  • Common bile duct (lateral)
  • Portal vein (posterior)

references.Name: Dudeja V, Ferrantella A, Fong Y. Chapter 54: Liver. In: Townsend C, Beauchamp RD, Evers BM, Mattox KL, eds. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:1425-1488.
Image sources:
Hepatoduodenal ligament: Wikimedia Commons
Situs inversus totalis: World J Gastroenterol
Foramen of Winslow: Wikimedia Commons

770894.hint: Remember the typical orientation of the structures in the hepatoduodenal ligament is important when identifying the source of bleeding. Try to visualize or recall the position of the common bile duct, hepatic artery, and portal vein in relation to each other.

449697.question:
A 62-year-old man with a palpable thyroid mass and a palpable cervical lymph node presents to his primary care physician who recommends biopsy. Pathology shows the nodule is comprised of almost entirely of Hürthle cells.

What is the BEST treatment for this patient’s thyroid disease?
answers: Complete thyroidectomy and modified radical neck dissection
449697.correct_answer: Complete thyroidectomy and modified radical neck dissection

explanation.BottomLine: Treatment for a Hürthle cell carcinoma is complete thyroidectomy and modified radical neck dissection in patients with clinically positive lymphadenopathy.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Malignant Hürthle cell neoplasms account for approximately 5% of thyroid carcinomas. Hürthle cells can frequently be seen on FNA, but a nodule that contains almost entirely Hürthle cells raises concern for Hürthle cell cancer. They are less common, occur in an older population, and are more likely to have lymph node or distant metastasis when compared to papillary and follicular carcinoma. Although Hürthle cell neoplasms are of follicular cell origin, very few Hürthle cell neoplasms will take up radioiodine, therefore, complete surgical resection is especially important in this disease. Total thyroidectomy may often be combined with central compartment lymphadenectomy and modified radical neck dissection if lymph node involvement is evident.

449697.modifier: Complete Thyroidectomy C Modified Neck Dissection

answers_info.Explanation: Surgery is the first line therapy for Hürthle cell carcinoma.
Subtotal thyroidectomy is not indicated for patients with invasive Hürthle cell carcinoma.

answers_info.Text: Complete thyroidectomy and modified radical neck dissection

answers_info.Explanation: Complete thyroidectomy is the standard of care for patients without palpable lymphadenopathy.
Observation is incorrect and could lead to patient morbidity or mortality.

references.Name: Greenfield's Surgery: Scientific Principles and Practice, Chapter 77: Thyroid Gland, Electronic Publication.

449697.hint: Consider the implications of the thyroid nodule being made up almost entirely of Hürthle cells, especially in the context of cervical lymphadenopathy. Surgical intervention is common in these scenarios - think about the extent and type of surgery needed when lymph nodes are involved.

463389.question:
A 2-year-old male has recently undergone surgical resection for hepatoblastoma.

Which of the following is correct regarding this disease?
answers: Most patients are 3 years and older
Elevated Alpha-fetoprotein is seen in only 10% of patients
Most patients have early stage disease at time of diagnosis
Hepatoblastoma is strongly associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and hemihypertrophy
Obstructive jaundice is the most common presentation
463389.correct_answer: Hepatoblastoma is strongly associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and hemihypertrophy

explanation.BottomLine: Hepatoblastoma is strongly associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and hemihypertrophy.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Hepatoblastoma (HB) is the most common primary malignant tumor of the liver in children. HB is strongly associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and hemihypertrophy. Hemihypertrophy is associated with an increased risk of other tumors such as Wilms tumor. In addition to Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome, HB is associated with a number of other genetic syndromes, including Li-Fraumeni syndrome, familial adenomatous polyposis, and trisomy 18. The strength of association between Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome has resulted in some experts to recommend that children with Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome be screened for HB with abdominal ultrasound and alpha-fetoprotein.

answers_info.Text: Most patients are 3 years and older
answers_info.Explanation: Hepatoblastoma affects young children between 6 months and 3 years old.

answers_info.Text: Elevated Alpha-fetoprotein is seen in only 10% of patients
answers_info.Explanation: Elevated alpha-fetoprotein is observed in more than 90% of children with hepatoblastoma. Alpha-fetoprotein is used as serum tumor marker for postoperative surveillance.

answers_info.Text: Most patients have early stage disease at time of diagnosis
answers_info.Explanation: Most children with hepatoblastoma present with unresectable disease.

answers_info.Text: Hepatoblastoma is strongly associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and hemihypertrophy
Obstructive jaundice is the most common presentation
answers_info.Explanation: Hepatoblastomas typically present as an asymptomatic abdominal mass or less commonly with symptoms of GI obstruction from the mass effect. Obstructive jaundice is unusual.

references.Name: Pediatric Abdomen. In: Mulholland MW et al., eds. Greenfield's Surgery: Scientific Principles & Practice. 6th Ed. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; 2016.

463389.hint: Consider the common associations seen in children with hepatoblastoma. Look for clues about genetic syndromes that may be connected.

895174.question: A 56-year-old man with a history of mitral valve prolapse is in the recovery room after excision of a buccal lesion under local anesthesia using benzocaine. On examination, he is conscious, alert, and breathing spontaneously but appears cyanotic. His oxygen saturation, as read by the pulse oximeter, is 85%. He is started on supplemental oxygen with no changes. An arterial blood gas is drawn, which shows normal PaO2 and PaCo2. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

explanation.BottomLine: Methemoglobinemia should be suspected in patients with cyanosis and low oxygen saturation without significant cardiopulmonary dysfunction, especially when there is a history of recent use of drugs that are known to cause methemoglobinemia. Basic treatment includes removal of the agent responsible for the disorder, administration of oxygen, and observation.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
In this scenario, a patient who had an oral lesion excised under local anesthesia with benzocaine appears cyanotic in the post anesthesia care unit. He is not breathless despite the pulse oximeter showing saturation of 85% and his arterial blood gas assessment is normal.

The most likely cause for the cyanosis and the low pulse oximeter reading in this scenario is benzocaine-induced methemoglobinemia.

Methemoglobin is the oxidized version of hemoglobin, which does not permit binding of O2 and results in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve. These changes result in decreased O2 delivery to tissues. Increased levels of methemoglobin in the blood can be secondary to congenital changes or exposure to several chemical agents including drugs.

When the concentration of methemoglobin in the blood is above 1.5%, the patient develops cyanosis, the main characteristic of this disorder. One should suspect the diagnosis in patients with cyanosis and low saturation without significant cardiopulmonary dysfunction, especially when there is a history of recent use of drugs that cause methemoglobinemia. Co-oximetry is the definitive method used to confirm the diagnosis as routine pulse oximetry cannot specifically detect methemoglobin.

Treatment should be based on whether the syndrome is acute or chronic as well as the severity of symptoms. Blood levels of methemoglobin are important, especially in acute cases. Basic treatment includes removal of the agent responsible for the disorder, administration of oxygen, and observation. Severe cases, and those with cardiac/pulmonary comorbidities, should be treated with the specific antidote, methylene blue. Ventilatory and/or cardiovascular support may be required for severe cases.

Drugs Causing Methemoglobinemia 
Antibiotics 
  • Trimethoprim
  • Sulphonamide
  • Dapsone
Local anesthetics
  • Benzocaine
  • Prilocaine
Dyes
  • Aniline dyes
Other
  • Nitrites
  • Bromates
  • Chlorates


Cyanosis secondary to methemoglobinemia.

answers_info.Explanation: Intubation is not necessary, as the patient is asymptomatic, without respiratory distress, and has normal arterial blood gas analysis.

There is no indication for urgent percutaneous tracheostomy in a patient who is asymptomatic without respiratory distress. Even in the setting of severe symptoms mandating ventilatory support, endotracheal intubation would be the preferred approach.
CT chest would not add any additional information in this scenario, where the patient has likely developed methemoglobinemia secondary to benzocaine use.

Naloxone is the reversal agent for opioid overdose. While respiratory depression and subsequent cyanosis may be seen, this patient is described as being alert and breathing spontaneously. The most likely diagnosis, in this circumstance, is methemoglobinemia and of the options listed, treatment with methylene blue is the next best step.

references.Name: Jayapal A, Rosario DC, Sanchez J, et al. Benzocaine-induced methaemoglobinaemia in an adolescent with sepsis. BMJ Case Rep. 2022;15(2):e248013.
Tan YA, Ng KC, Cheo SW, et al. A case of dapsone-induced methaemoglobinaemia. Clin Med (Lond). 2020;20(5):519-521.
Methemoglobinemia - UpToDate

895174.hint: Consider the patient's history with local anesthetics, and remember that certain drugs can cause abnormal hemoglobin forms leading to low oxygen saturation without respiratory distress.

356445.question:
A patient with a history of a hiatal hernia is found to have a gastric polyp on a routine screening endoscopy.  The polyp is 2 cm in size and sessile.  A biopsy is taken and the frozen pathology describes a tubulovillous adenoma with no evidence of invasive cancer.  

The next BEST step in treatment is:
answers: Follow the patient with serial endoscopies every 6 months
Start IV antibiotics and a PPI

explanation.BottomLine: Sessile gastric polyps greater than 2cm should be formally resected.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Adenomatous gastric polyps should all be excised due to an increased risk of gastric cancer.  The risk for developing cancer is lowest with tubular polyps and highest with villous polyps. The majority of these polyps can be removed endoscopically as long as there are negative margins and there is no evidence of invasive cancer.  Due to the higher risk of invasive cancer with incomplete margins, sessile polyps that are greater than 2cm in size are better removed with a formal resection.

answers_info.Text: Follow the patient with serial endoscopies every 6 months
answers_info.Explanation: All polyps should be excised either endoscopically or with a formal resection depending on its characteristics.
Endoscopic excision is contraindicated if sessile and greater than 2cm.

answers_info.Text: Start IV antibiotics and a PPI
answers_info.Explanation: Treatment of H.pylori can cause regression of some gastric polyps but excision should still be performed.
Formal resection is the best treatment for sessile polyps over 2cm.
Adenomatous gastric polyps mandate some form of intervention due to the increased risk of cancer.

references.Name: Townsend, Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 18th Edition, Chapter 47, Electronic publication.

356445.hint: Consider the characteristics of the polyp, particularly its size and type. Think about the risks associated with sessile gastric polyps and what steps are typically recommended for management.

816980.question: Which of the following represents a likely outcome of pancreatic necrosis?
answers: Necrosis in 30% of gland consistent with infection in 5% of patients
Necrosis in 50% of gland consistent with infection in 15% of patients
Necrosis in 70% of gland consistent with infection in 46% of patients
816980.correct_answer: Necrosis in 70% of gland consistent with infection in 46% of patients

explanation.BottomLine: The main complication of pancreatic necrosis is infection. The risk is directly related to the amount of necrosis.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Pancreatic necrosis is the presence of nonviable pancreatic parenchyma or peripancreatic fat; it can be manifested as a focal area or diffuse involvement of the gland. Contrast-enhanced CT is the most reliable technique to diagnose pancreatic necrosis. It is typically seen as areas of low attenuation (< 40 to 50 HU) after the IV injection of contrast material. Normal parenchyma usually has a density of 100 to 150 HU. Up to 20% of patients with AP develop pancreatic necrosis. It is important to identify and to provide proper treatment of this complication because most patients who develop multiorgan failure have necrotizing pancreatitis; pancreatic necrosis has been documented in up to 80% of the autopsies of patients who died after an episode of AP.

The main complication of pancreatic necrosis is infection. The risk is directly related to the amount of necrosis; in patients with pancreatic necrosis involving less than 30% of the gland, the risk of infection is 22%. The risk is 37% for patients with pancreatic necrosis that involves 30% to 50% of the gland and up to 46% if more than 70% of the gland is affected. This complication is associated with bacterial translocation usually involving enteric flora, such as gram-negative rods (e.g., Escherichia coli, Klebsiella, and Pseudomonas spp.) and Enterococcus spp.


Infected pancreatic necrosis should be suspected in patients with prolonged fever, elevated white blood cell count, or progressive clinical deterioration. Evidence of air within the pancreatic necrosis seen on a CT scan confirms the diagnosis but is a rare finding. If infected necrosis is suspected, fine-needle aspiration (FNA) may be performed if the diagnosis is equivocal; from the aspirate, a positive Gram stain or culture establishes the diagnosis. Although positive cultures are confirmatory, a review has demonstrated that despite negative preoperative cultures, 42% of patients with so-called persistent unwellness will have infected necrosis.


Currently, an endoscopic drainage with a large-bore stent and possible endoscopic débridement with or without percutaneous drainage may avoid open operations in some patients. If the endoscopic management fails, an open operation will usually be more straightforward and the results improved. When either route is taken, physiologic and nutritional support of the patient will have a large impact on outcome.

answers_info.Explanation: Necrosis in 70% of gland consistent with infection in 46% of patients

answers_info.Text: Necrosis in 30% of gland consistent with infection in 5% of patients
answers_info.Explanation: Necrosis in 70% of gland consistent with infection in 46% of patients

answers_info.Text: Necrosis in 50% of gland consistent with infection in 15% of patients
answers_info.Explanation: Necrosis in 70% of gland consistent with infection in 46% of patients

answers_info.Text: Necrosis in 70% of gland consistent with infection in 46% of patients

answers_info.Explanation: Necrosis in 70% of gland consistent with infection in 46% of patients

references.Name: Sabiston, D. C., & Townsend, C. M. (2012). Sabiston textbook of surgery: the biological basis of modern surgical practice. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier Saunders.

816980.hint: Consider the relationship between the extent of necrosis and the likelihood of infection. Focus on how the percentage of necrosis corresponds to the statistical data provided in the choices.

492588.question: The two main sources of energy in short-term fasting (< 3 days) are:

explanation.BottomLine: The two main sources of energy in a short-term fast are carbohydrates and protein.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: In a short-term fast (< 3 days), the main sources of energy are carbohydrates and protein. In an average 70 kg person at rest, there are approximately 13 days of protein available versus 78 days of fat. There are only 0.4 days of glycogen available. Ketones are a form of energy that become important in prolonged starvation, as they quickly become the only fuel source for the brain.

492588.mainTopic: Sources Of Energy In Short-term Fasting

answers_info.Explanation: Protein is used in the short-term. Fat is used in long-term starvation for energy.
Ketones are used by the brain as a fuel source in long-term starvation. Protein is broken down for short-term use.
Fat is converted to ketones for our brain to use as energy in long-term starvation.
Carbohydrates is correct. Fat however is mobilized for long-term starvation.

references.Name: Surgery: Basic Science and Clinical Evidence, 2nd Edition, Chapter 5: Substrate Metabolism.

492588.hint: Consider what the body primarily utilizes for energy shortly after a meal versus during a time of fasting. Focus on the types of macronutrients that are quickly accessible to the body.

861584.question: A 45-year-old woman with alcohol abuse presents with severe abdominal pain. A CT scan demonstrates pancreatitis with ascites, as well as the formation of a large pseudocyst. The patient is admitted and started on IV fluids which are titrated up to 300 cc/hour for low blood pressure and oliguria. The next morning, the patient's urine output is noted to be 10 cc/hr, and vitals are pulse rate 115 /min, blood pressure 97/70 mm Hg, respiratory rate 28 /min, oxygen saturation is 86% on 6L nasal cannula. Physical examination is notable for an increasingly distended and tense abdomen. The patient is intubated for respiratory failure. Bladder pressure is checked and is 22 mm Hg. Which of the following is consistent with her presentation?
answers: increased cellular production of adenosine triphosphate

explanation.BottomLine: Abdominal compartment syndrome is caused by any event that produces intra-abdominal hypertension leading to multiorgan dysfunction syndrome. Cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and neurological abnormalities occur, and the classic findings include elevated peak inspiratory pressures and renal failure.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient likely has abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) from third-spacing of her IV fluids due to the inflammatory cytokines released in response to her pancreatitis.

Sustained intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) can lead to ACS, which may manifest with the following physiological changes:
  1. Increased intracranial pressure (> 15 mm Hg)
  2. Impaired oxygenation with elevated peak inspiratory pressures (> 40 cmH2O) secondary to decreased lung and chest wall compliance
  3. Cardiac failure as a result of decreased preload and diastolic dysfunction, along with elevated intrathoracic pressure, creates right ventricular impairment and increased afterload that is resistant to volume loading
  4. Oliguric renal failure from direct effects on the renal parenchymal and renal veins, as well as indirectly, secondary to decreased cardiac output with increased systemic vascular resistance (> 1,500 dynes/seconds/cm-5)
  5. GI ischemia due to decreased splanchnic perfusion
  6. Abdominal wall musculocutaneous ischemia, potentially resulting in surgical wound complications
The cardiovascular system is affected by decreased venous return to the heart due to compression of the inferior vena cava by high pressure in the peritoneal space. This increased pressure also increases systemic vascular resistance as a whole as a compensatory mechanism. The combination of decreased venous return and increased afterload leads to a precipitous decrease in cardiac output, adding to the ischemia. Normal systemic vascular resistance ranges from 700-1500 dynes/seconds/cm-5.



CVP = central venous pressure, IAP = intra-abdominal pressure, UOP = urine output.
Illustration © TrueLearn, LLC

answers_info.Explanation: Intracranial pressure (ICP) is normally 7-15 mm Hg at rest, for a supine adult. Increased intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) causes a significant rise in ICP. An increase in intrathoracic pressure causes a functional obstruction to cerebral venous outflow resulting in increased intracranial pressure. Thus, ACS would result in ICP.

Peak airway pressure is the highest level of pressure applied to the lungs during inhalation. Impaired oxygenation with elevated peak inspiratory pressures usually close to 40 cmH<sub>2</sub>O is observed in ACS, secondary to decreased lung and chest wall compliance.

The normal range for cardiac index is 2.5-4 L/min/m<sup>2</sup>. ACS results in cardiac failure as a result of decreased preload and diastolic dysfunction along with elevated intrathoracic pressure, creating right ventricular impairment and increased afterload that is recalcitrant to volume loading.

answers_info.Text: increased cellular production of adenosine triphosphate
answers_info.Explanation: The positive feedback role of increased IAP leading to IAH and the development of ACS results in hypoxia that is associated with three crucial sequelae: 1) release of cytokines; 2) formation of oxygen free radicals; 3) decreased cellular production of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). Insufficient oxygen delivery to the tissues limits the production of ATP, and this decreased availability of ATP impairs energy-dependent cellular activities.

references.Name: Hartwell JL, Zarzaur BL. Abdominal compartment syndrome and management of the open abdomen. In: Cameron JL, Cameron AM, eds. Current Surgical Therapy. 13th ed. Elsevier; 2020:1246-1250.
De Laet IE, Malbrain MLNG, De Waele JJ. A clinician's guide to management of intra-abdominal hypertension and abdominal compartment syndrome in critically ill patients. Crit Care. 2020;24(1):97.
Walker J, Criddle L. Pathophysiology and management of abdominal compartment syndrome. Am J Crit Care. 2003;12(4):367-371.
Citerio G, Vascotto E, Villa F, et al. Induced abdominal compartment syndrome increases intracranial pressure in neurotrauma patients: a prospective study. Crit Care Med. 2001;29(7):1466-71.

861584.hint: Consider how the patient's condition affects her vascular resistance and cardiac output. Look for values that indicate a response to elevated intra-abdominal pressure.

655808.question: A 42-year-old woman with a previous history of right superior parathyroid adenoma removal 15 years ago now presents with a 1-cm left thyroid nodule. The workup with fine-needle aspiration shows follicular cells. A decision is made to proceed with diagnostic thyroid lobectomy. What test is recommended before proceeding with surgery?
answers: CT angiogram of the head and neck

explanation.BottomLine: In a patient with a previous neck surgery, indirect laryngoscopy should be performed to ensure the bilateral vocal cords are functional.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Vocal fold paresis is a severe complication after surgery for thyroid or parathyroid pathology. During dissection, it is important to avoid injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Despite meticulous care in most thyroid and parathyroid surgeries to protect the nerve, studies have shown that there is an increased risk of vocal cord paresis with redo thyroid or parathyroid surgery.

Unilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve results in dysphonia/hoarseness; bilateral injury can result in a more severe complication of respiratory distress, sometimes requiring reintubation or tracheostomy. It is therefore recommended to perform indirect laryngoscopy prior to redo thyroid or parathyroid surgery.

answers_info.Text: CT angiogram of the head and neck
answers_info.Explanation: CT angiogram of the head and neck can be useful in preoperative planning for vascular surgeries of the neck, such as for carotid endarterectomy or carotid body tumor resection. Indirect laryngoscopy in this patient is quite important given concerns for vocal cord paresis.
MRI of the neck is not the modality for screening for vocal fold paresis.

There are several imaging characteristics associated with vocal cord paresis on CT scan. These include laryngeal ventricle widening, aryepiglottic fold thickening and medial deviation, and piriform sinus dilatation. However, indirect laryngoscopy is the preferred modality for preoperative evaluation in this setting.
Echocardiogram is not indicated in this patient without cardiac risk factors, nor is it helpful in the diagnosis of vocal fold paresis.

references.Name: Heikkinen M, Mäkinen K, Penttilä E, et al. Incidence, risk factors, and natural outcome of vocal fold paresis in 920 thyroid operations with routine pre- and postoperative laryngoscopic evaluation. World J Surg. 2019;43(9):2228-2234.
Dankbaar JW, Pameijer FA. Vocal cord paralysis: anatomy, imaging and pathology. Insights Imaging. 2014;5(6):743-751.

655808.hint: Consider the implications of a previous neck surgery on vocal cord functionality, as this can be crucial during a subsequent surgery.

957012.question: A 55-year-old man 5 days status post ventral hernia repair is being evaluated at his bedside. His pulse rate is 105/min, respiratory rate is 34/min, blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 95% on 2 L nasal cannula. The patient has severe abdominal pain and guarding, and there is a purulent leak from the wound. Chest x-ray is clear. Arterial blood gas shows pH 7.35, PaO2 is 75 mm Hg, and PaCO2 is 30 mm Hg. Glucose is 220 mg/dL. WBC count is 15,000/μL, hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, hematocrit is 40%, platelet count is 80 x 109/L, creatinine is 1.5 mg/dL, and blood urea nitrogen is 40 mg/dL. Regarding the diagnosis and management of sepsis, which of the following statements is true?
answers: Sepsis severity is defined by the presence of a systemic inflammatory response syndrome and a source of infection
Empiric antibiotic therapy should be started as soon as possible, even before any diagnostic workup
Blood cortisol should be checked prior to administering a stress steroid challenge of steroids
Markers of organ damage are more important than WBC count in the management of sepsis
Serum procalcitonin should not be used to tailor duration of antimicrobial therapy
957012.correct_answer: Markers of organ damage are more important than WBC count in the management of sepsis

explanation.BottomLine: Sepsis is a syndrome that encompasses an exaggerated response to an infection. Rather than the systemic inflammatory response syndrome criteria, the Sequential (Sepsis-related) Organ Failure Assessment score and its modified version, the quick Sequential (Sepsis-related) Organ Failure Assessment, are used for early assessment and goal-directed therapy.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Sepsis is a term that has evolved throughout the years and involves varying degrees of severity that range from simple infection with bacteremia to sepsis and septic shock. Previously, the diagnosis involved the systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) criteria, which included changes in pulse rate, temperature, respiratory rate, and WBC count.

In the Sepsis 3 guidelines, this definition has fallen out of favor, and now the more commonly used system is the Sequential (Sepsis-related) Organ Failure Assesment (SOFA) score. Its quick version (qSOFA) includes tachypnea, altered mentation, and systolic hypotension, all of which help to identify sepsis. The regular version evaluates markers for respiratory, cardiac, hepatic, coagulation, neurological, and renal systems to predict mortality of sepsis.

Treatment of sepsis includes source evaluation and control, early initiation of fluids and antibiotic therapy, systemic support and serial follow-up of the clinical condition, and watching for signs of a worsening condition.

answers_info.Text: Sepsis severity is defined by the presence of a systemic inflammatory response syndrome and a source of infection
answers_info.Explanation: The new definition of sepsis varies among different societies; however, it usually involves the presence of an infection with an exaggerated host response causing organ dysfunction. The SIRS criteria have fallen out of favor in recent years due to the fact that a large proportion of patients can have the clinical criteria without having a documented infection.

answers_info.Text: Empiric antibiotic therapy should be started as soon as possible, even before any diagnostic workup
answers_info.Explanation: According to the more recent Surviving Sepsis Guidelines, it is recommended to obtain routine microbiological cultures before starting antimicrobials.

answers_info.Text: Blood cortisol should be checked prior to administering a stress steroid challenge of steroids
answers_info.Explanation: The measurement of cortisol in sepsis has fallen out of favor because it can be extremely variable. A stress dose of steroids is recommended in patients with vasopressor refractory septic shock.

answers_info.Text: Markers of organ damage are more important than WBC count in the management of sepsis
Serum procalcitonin should not be used to tailor duration of antimicrobial therapy
answers_info.Explanation: In the Surviving Sepsis Guidelines, procalcitonin levels are recommended to support shortening the duration of antimicrobial therapy in patients with sepsis.

references.Name: Rhodes A, Evans LE, Alhazzani W, et al. Surviving Sepsis Campaign: international guidelines for management of sepsis and septic shock: 2016. Intensive Care Med. 2017;43(3):304-377.

Annane D, Pastores SM, Rochwerg B, et al. Guidelines for the Diagnosis and Management of Critical Illness-Related Corticosteroid Insufficiency (CIRCI) in Critically Ill Patients (Part I): Society of Critical Care Medicine (SCCM) and European Society of Intensive Care Medicine (ESICM) 2017. Crit Care Med. 2017;45(12):2078-2088.

957012.hint: Consider focusing on whether markers indicating organ damage and dysfunction have been evaluated thoroughly, as these details might be more critical than standard blood count metrics in managing sepsis.

720251.question: A 67-year-old smoker was found to have a large, right-sided Pancoast tumor of squamous cell histology. Which of the following statements is most correct as it pertains to Pancoast tumors?
answers: Standard treatment for localized tumors is chemoradiation followed by resection
Patients most commonly present with symptoms of facial/upper extremity swelling
Squamous cell carcinoma accounts for 40% of all lung cancers
Squamous cell lung cancer is associated with an antidiuretic hormone-related paraneoplastic syndrome
720251.correct_answer: Standard treatment for localized tumors is chemoradiation followed by resection

explanation.BottomLine: Pancoast tumors are lung cancers that invade the structures of the thoracic inlet and, thus, pose unique challenges surrounding their management. Standard treatment for localized tumors is concurrent chemoradiation followed by resection.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Pancoast tumors are lung cancers that invade the structures of the thoracic inlet (ie, first rib, brachial plexus, subclavian vessels, upper thoracic vertebrae, sympathetic chain) and most commonly present with shoulder or arm pain. They can, occasionally, present with Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) or superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome (facial/upper extremity swelling due to mass effect on SVC). 

Standard treatment for localized tumors is concurrent chemoradiation followed by resection, based on the results of several phase II trials that demonstrated improved resection rates and lower recurrence rates compared to preoperative radiation therapy alone. The chemotherapy regimen typically involves a platinum-based regimen (ie, cisplatin and etoposide) coupled with 45 Gy of radiation therapy. Resection should involve a lobectomy and all involved structures. The outcomes of neoadjuvant chemoradiation and surgery have found a 90% R0-resection rate and a 50% complete pathologic response rate. The average 5-year survival is approximately 55%. 

Of note, the term "Pancoast tumor" strictly applies to its location and should be kept separate from its histology. Squamous cell lung cancers comprise approximately 22% of all lung cancers and are associated with a parathyroid hormone (PTH)-related paraneoplastic syndrome. 


Coronal contrast-enhanced CT of the neck and chest demonstrating a large multiloculated mass.

answers_info.Text: Standard treatment for localized tumors is chemoradiation followed by resection
Patients most commonly present with symptoms of facial/upper extremity swelling
answers_info.Explanation: Patients with Pancoast tumors most commonly present with shoulder or arm pain. Although SVC syndrome is one possible presentation, it is less common.

answers_info.Text: Squamous cell carcinoma accounts for 40% of all lung cancers
answers_info.Explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma together ("non-small cell lung cancers") account for 80% of all lung cancers. Squamous cell carcinoma itself accounts for approximately 22% of lung cancers.

answers_info.Text: Squamous cell lung cancer is associated with an antidiuretic hormone-related paraneoplastic syndrome
answers_info.Explanation: Squamous cell carcinomas are associated with PTH-related peptides. Antidiuretic hormone paraneoplastic syndrome is associated with small cell carcinomas. The most common is adrenocorticotropic hormone paraneoplastic syndrome of small cell carcinomas.
Resection alone is insufficient treatment of Pancoast tumors. Standard treatment for localized tumors is concurrent chemoradiation followed by resection.

references.Name: Chiang A, Detterbeck FC, Stewart T, Decker RH, Tanoue L. Chapter 48: Non-small-cell lung cancer. In: DeVita VT, Lawrence S, Rosenberg SA, eds. Cancer: Principles & Practice of Oncology. 11th ed. Wolters Kluwer; 2019.
Image source: J Med Case Rep

720251.hint: Consider how Pancoast tumors uniquely present and are treated. Recall the standard management protocols for localized lung tumors and think about the typical approaches in oncological treatment.

575899.question: A 49-year-old woman is undergoing laparoscopic liver resection for heptocellular carcinoma of the right lobe of the liver. Which of the following is correct regarding the indications for laparoscopic liver resection?
answers: The indications for laparoscopic resection are completely different from those for open resection
Laparoscopic resection is ideal for tumors < 5 cm located in segments 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6
Benign asymptomatic liver lesions are currently the most common indications for laparoscopic liver resection
Laparoscopic resection reduces morbidity and mortality when performed in patients with decompensated cirrhosis
There is no learning curve associated with laparoscopic liver resections
575899.correct_answer: Laparoscopic resection is ideal for tumors < 5 cm located in segments 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6

explanation.BottomLine: Laparoscopic liver resection is ideal for tumors < 5 cm located in segments 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Laparoscopic liver resections (LLRs) are safe when performed by experienced surgeons. They are generally non-anatomical and currently constitute about 20%–80% of liver resections. The 3 most common approaches to performing LLR are pure laparoscopy, hand-assisted laparoscopy, and hybrid technique. LLRs are ideal for tumors < 5 cm located in segments 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6.

575899.modifier: Ideal For Tumors <5cm Located In Certain Segments

answers_info.Text: The indications for laparoscopic resection are completely different from those for open resection
answers_info.Explanation: The indications for laparoscopic and open liver resections are the same.

answers_info.Text: Laparoscopic resection is ideal for tumors < 5 cm located in segments 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6
Benign asymptomatic liver lesions are currently the most common indications for laparoscopic liver resection
answers_info.Explanation: Benign liver tumors are not currently viewed as an accepted indication for laparoscopic liver resection. Benign lesions of the liver should be resected laparoscopically only if they are symptomatic or when malignancy cannot be excluded.

answers_info.Text: Laparoscopic resection reduces morbidity and mortality when performed in patients with decompensated cirrhosis
answers_info.Explanation: Laparoscopic resection (as in open surgery) should be avoided in patients with decompensated cirrhosis (except in liver transplant) due to unacceptably high morbidity and mortality.

answers_info.Text: There is no learning curve associated with laparoscopic liver resections
answers_info.Explanation: There is a learning curve associated with laparoscopic liver resection and therefore this procedure should be only performed by highly experienced surgeons.

references.Name: Hunter JG, Fischer LE. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy, intraoperative cholangiography, and common bile duct exploration. In: Fischer JE, ed. Fischer's Mastery of Surgery. 7th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Wolters Kluwer; 2019.

575899.hint: Consider the size and location of tumors when evaluating laparoscopic resection indications. What is typically ideal for larger tumors?

678612.question: A 78 year-old man presents with severe pain in the right lower extremity. He has a history of atrial fibrillation but had stopped taking his coumadin for an anticipated surgical procedure. On physical exam, the patient has warm thigh and knee but cold foot. There is no motor loss but there is sensory loss to toes. The femoral and popliteal pulses are palpable but distal pulses are absent. Where is the likely location of the emboli?
answers: emboli to distal peroneal and tibial artery

explanation.BottomLine: Patients with atrial fibrillation off of anticoagulation therapy are at high risk for the development of atrial thrombi which can become an embolus. Acute limb ischemia is a potential threat if anticoagulation fails. Knowing the physical findings for acute limb ischemia is crucial to proper diagnosis and determination of the level of obstruction as it will determine surgical approach.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Patients with atrial fibrillation are at high risk for development of atrial thrombi which can become an embolus. If the embolus travels to the lower extremity, acute limb ischemia can develop. Most patients have two legs and comparison of the physical exam findings of the two extremities can help identify the discrepancies. Understanding the arterial anatomy is key to the diagnosis of the likely location of the embolus. Additionally, the embolus is more likely to become lodged in an area of bifurcation or trifurcation as there is a change in the caliber of the artery.

If the occlusion is at the level of the aortic bifurcation, the entire lower extremity should be affected with a loss of the femoral and distal pulses. If the occlusion is at the level of the iliac bifurcation, the buttock and upper thigh may be spared due to collateral circulation from the internal iliac artery but a loss of the femoral artery pulse is expected. If the occlusion is at the level of the femoral bifurcation, the thigh should be spared as the profunda is patent. If the occlusion is at the level of the popliteal trifurcation, the upper leg may be spared due to collateral circulation from the genicular artery but there will be a lack of all distal pedal pulses. In acute limb ischemia, unlike chronic limb ischemia, there is not enough time for the development of new compensatory collateral circulation around the obstruction.

678612.modifier: Level Of Occlusion Is At Popliteal Trifurcation

answers_info.Explanation: If the occlusion is at the level of the aortic bifurcation, the entire lower extremity should be affected with a loss of the femoral pulse.

If the occlusion is at the level of the femoral bifurcation, the thigh should be spared as the profunda is patent. This will give a similar physical finding to that of obstruction of the popliteal trifurcation but a loss of the popliteal pulse would be expected.
If the occlusion is at the level of the iliac bifurcation, a loss of femoral and distal pulses is expected with the entire majority of the extremity being affected.

answers_info.Text: emboli to distal peroneal and tibial artery
answers_info.Explanation: Although, a shower of small emboli is possible, it is highly unlikely in a patient who has not had a recent intravascular procure.

references.Name: Seegmiller C and Cogbill T. Chapter 188: The Management of Peripheral Arterial Thromboembolism. In: Cameron J and Cameron A. Current Surgical Therapy. 13th ed. Philadelphia: Elsevier; 2019: 1013-1017.

678612.hint: Consider how the history of atrial fibrillation and the patient's symptoms relate to the potential locations where an embolus could lodge. Pay attention to the physical exam findings and remember that changes in arterial caliber, such as bifurcations and trifurcations, are key locations for obstruction.

887263.question: A 73-year-old healthy man with no past medical history presents with dysphagia. He undergoes esophagogastroduodenoscopy, which reveals a mass in the lower third of the esophagus that is biopsied and evaluated with endoscopic US. The biopsy is consistent with esophageal adenocarcinoma. The endoscopic US reveals a tumor invading the submucosa but not penetrating the muscularis propria. Which of the following would most likely preclude the above patient from undergoing endoscopic mucosal resection?
answers: involvement of tumor to SM3 level of submucosa
normal mediastinal lymph nodes seen on imaging
887263.correct_answer: involvement of tumor to SM3 level of submucosa

explanation.BottomLine: Endoscopic mucosal resection is the preferred method of resection for Tis (limited to the epithelium) and T1a (has not penetrated through the muscularis mucosa into the submucosa).
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
The wall of the esophagus tract has 4 main layers. The mucosa is the first layer of bowel wall and consists of epithelium, basement membrane, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosa (in order of superficial to deep). The submucosa is the second layer of bowel wall and is divided into thirds, such that the upper third is SM1, the middle third is SM2, and the lower third is SM3. The muscularis propria is the third layer of the bowel wall, and the adventitia is the fourth layer. Unlike the remainder of the GI tract, the esophagus does not have an outer serosal layer.  

Endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR) is particularly useful for low-stage esophageal cancers as they can be managed without need for esophagectomy. This is the preferred method of resection for Tis (limited to the epithelium) and T1a (has not penetrated through the muscularis mucosa into the submucosa) esophageal cancers as the risk of nodal metastasis is negligible (< 2%). The operative mortality is 2% after an esophagectomy; therefore, the risk-benefit analysis is favorable for EMR in stage T1a tumors. 

Stage T1b tumors (infiltrates into submucosa but does not penetrate muscularis propria), as in the above patient, have a widely varying range of nodal involvement (from a few percent to up to 60%). Therefore, in order to decide on esophagectomy vs EMR for these patients, the tumor characteristics have to be examined. 

Good candidates for EMR for T1b tumors are those with tumors < 2 cm, well to moderately differentiated tumors, lack of lymphovascular invasion around the tumor, tumor limited to SM1 level of submucosa, and no enlarged lymph nodes seen on staging imaging. Involvement of SM3 submucosa level would increase the likelihood of lymph node involvement, which would make esophagectomy in an otherwise fit surgical candidate the superior method of resection. T1b lesions that are larger, moderately to poorly differentiated, have lymphovascular invasion, or have enlarged lymph nodes on staging workup should undergo esophagectomy if otherwise fit for surgery.

answers_info.Explanation: Good candidates for EMR for T1b tumors are those with tumors < 2 cm, well to moderately differentiated tumors, lack of lymphovascular invasion around the tumor, tumor limited to SM1 level of submucosa, and no enlarged lymph nodes seen on staging imaging.

Good candidates for EMR for T1b tumors are those with tumors < 2 cm, well to moderately differentiated tumors, lack of lymphovascular invasion around the tumor, tumor limited to SM1 level of submucosa, and no enlarged lymph nodes seen on staging imaging.

Good candidates for EMR for T1b tumors are those with tumors < 2 cm, well to moderately differentiated tumors, lack of lymphovascular invasion around the tumor, tumor limited to SM1 level of submucosa, and no enlarged lymph nodes seen on staging imaging.

answers_info.Text: involvement of tumor to SM3 level of submucosa
normal mediastinal lymph nodes seen on imaging
answers_info.Explanation: Good candidates for EMR for T1b tumors are those with tumors < 2 cm, well to moderately differentiated tumors, lack of lymphovascular invasion around the tumor, tumor limited to SM1 level of submucosa, and no enlarged lymph nodes seen on staging imaging.

references.Name: Rajaram R, Spicer JD, Dhupar R, et al. Chapter 42: Esophagus. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:1014-1055.
Filicori F, Swanstrom LL. Management of esophageal cancer. In: Cameron JL. Cameron AM, eds. Current Surgical Therapy. 13th ed. Elsevier; 2020:53-63.

887263.hint: Consider the implications of the tumor's depth of invasion into the submucosa. Specifically, think about how different levels within the submucosa can influence treatment options.

969067.question: While performing a late afternoon laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the attending physician expresses his frustration that the patient was delayed in pre-op. Due to repeated pre-op delays with patients all day, this patient's case started 3 hours late. The resident working with him has noticed a pattern of preoperative delays at their institution and begins a quality improvement project to decrease the amount of time patients spend in pre-op. He starts with a value stream map to identify the steps of pre-op that take the longest or add the least value to a surgeon's aim to start procedures on time. He then holds 2 rapid process improvement workshops with the pre-op staff and other stakeholders to make changes to their institution's processes. Over the next 6 months, the value stream map is revisited, and another rapid process improvement workshop is held with staff to fine-tune their changes. The end result is a 20% reduction in late starts to cases, with the expectation that with continued revisiting, the late start percentage will continue to fall. Which of the following best describes the quality improvement methodology being used?

explanation.BottomLine: The lean process may be used to reduce waste through value stream mapping and continuous re-analysis of the process.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Quality improvement (QI) projects are an essential part of health care, as they allow physicians to ensure the efficient delivery of high-quality care and services to patients. There are a number of methodologies for quality improvement processes, but the most frequently used are the Lean and Six Sigma methodologies. 
Lean focuses on waste reduction by using tools such as the value stream map, which allows each step of a process to be visualized in a flow chart along with its associated value to the stakeholder. When a step adds little value to a stakeholder, it becomes a focus for the reduction of its resource consumption. For instance, if it was discovered that one step of the preoperative process required a nurse to walk halfway across the hospital to the only printer on the floor, the quality improvement project team could focus on this step, which adds little value to the surgeon and contributes to delays. 

One tenet of lean process methodology is the expectation that outcomes will continue to improve with continual lean methodology. The quality improvement team revisits the process repeatedly and looks for opportunities to further fine-tune the value stream map. Rapid process improvement events are held to gather input from those most familiar with the process and brainstorm solutions. 

The Six Sigma process often works in conjunction with the Lean process in both manufacturing and health care settings. Six Sigma is characterized by the Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, Control model of improvement and centers around the aim to eliminate process errors. Lean Six Sigma is a quality improvement discipline that has gained popularity in the health care industry by combining the Lean and Six Sigma methodologies to obtain a synergy of both error and waste reduction.

answers_info.Explanation: Six Sigma is another commonly used quality improvement methodology, but it focuses mostly on error/waste reduction through the Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, Control model.

Benchmarking refers to determining what other institutions are doing to improve quality. It can be a powerful tool for a physician to employ in defining control measures for a quality improvement project. For instance, if another similar institution has already overhauled its preoperative process, its measures may be used as benchmarks for success. Benchmarking was not referenced in this question.

A root cause analysis is employed to examine facts surrounding an undesired outcome. Blame is deferred from any individual and, instead, process measures are improved to change the effects of the identified root causes. This question is not describing the systematic analysis of the facts surrounding an undesired outcome.

The Swiss cheese model refers to the concept that a number of barriers are erected to prevent an undesired outcome, such that multiple different holes must align before the outcome occurs. For instance, a wrong medication may be given if the nurse overrides the flag in the computer system, does not read the correct patient's name to confirm it was the ordered drug, and also does not scan the patient's bracelet when she arrives at the bedside to administer the drug. This question is not referring to an error that resulted from a series of failures to prevent the outcome.

references.Name: Schroll R, Paramesh A, Guidry C, Zelhart M, Killackey M, Levy S. A structured quality improvement educational curriculum increases surgical resident involvement in QI processes. J Surg Educ. 2020;77(6):e183-e186.
Clarke MJ, Steffens FL, Mallory GW, et al. Quality improvement into resident education: structured curriculum, evaluation, and quality improvement projects. World Neurosurg. 2019;126:e1112-e1120.

969067.hint: Consider the focus on waste reduction and the tools used, such as the value stream map, that help in identifying inefficient steps in a process. This methodology emphasizes continuous improvement.

874129.question:
A young woman presents as trauma after sustaining a gunshot wound to the right upper quadrant. Her airway is intact and she has bilateral breath sounds. She is tachycardic to 120 and her blood pressure is 85/60. Her GCS is 14 due to confusion. A single GSW entering her right upper quadrant is identified on the primary survey and an x-ray demonstrates a retained missile. While examining her abdomen, a continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion pump is found on her left lower abdomen. The patient requires emergent surgery given the concern for intraabdominal injury and hemorrhage. 

What is the best next step for managing this patient's insulin requirement?
answers: Continue patient's subcutaneous insulin infusion pump
Stop subcutaneous infusion, check patient's blood sugar every hour throughout the case and give short-acting insulin on a sliding scale
Stop subcutaneous infusion, give a dose of glipizide
Stop subcutaneous infusion, give single dose of long-acting insulin
Stop subcutaneous infusion, start an intravenous insulin infusion
874129.correct_answer: Stop subcutaneous infusion, start an intravenous insulin infusion

explanation.BottomLine: Patients with insulin-dependent diabetes who use a continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion pump should be transitioned to an intravenous insulin infusion in the event of emergent or longer surgical procedures. IV insulin infusions should be accompanied by frequent (at least every hour) glucose checks.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Surgical stress results in a complex cascade of events that result in relative insulin resistance and increased glucose production. Hyperglycemia in the perioperative period has been associated with increased risk of infectious, pulmonary, and cardiac complications. For these reasons, optimal glucose control is imperative before, during, and after surgical intervention. 

This patient, with a continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion, requires emergent surgery. Patients with insulin pumps who are undergoing emergent or long and complex surgeries require the transition to intravenous insulin infusion while in the operating room. While receiving IV insulin, frequent glucose is mandatory and should be performed at least every hour. 


For shorter, elective procedures, insulin pumps can be programmed to the basal infusion rate and reprogrammed to regular settings once a diet has been resumed.

874129.modifier: Decision To Convert The Pump To IV Insulin

answers_info.Text: Continue patient's subcutaneous insulin infusion pump
answers_info.Explanation: Due to this patient's need for emergent surgery, she requires the transition to an IV insulin infusion. Discontinuation of a patient's subcutaneous insulin pump is also indicated if they are undergoing procedures likely to cause significant ileus or who will be NPO for more than one meal.

answers_info.Text: Stop subcutaneous infusion, check patient's blood sugar every hour throughout the case and give short-acting insulin on a sliding scale
answers_info.Explanation: This patient should have her insulin pump stopped, however, she should be transitioned to an IV infusion and not a sliding scale. Sliding scale insulin administration may result in significant glucose level fluctuations despite frequent glucose checks.

answers_info.Text: Stop subcutaneous infusion, give a dose of glipizide
answers_info.Explanation: This patient has insulin-dependent diabetes, thus oral medications would not be appropriate. In addition, it is recommended that patients treated with oral diabetes medications stop their oral medications the morning of surgery.

answers_info.Text: Stop subcutaneous infusion, give single dose of long-acting insulin
answers_info.Explanation: A single dose of long-acting insulin would not provide adequate glycemic control for this patient. Due to the effects that trauma, anesthesia, and the stress of surgery have on glucose homeostasis, a single dose of long-acting insulin does not allow for adjustment based on the patient's varying insulin requirements.

answers_info.Text: Stop subcutaneous infusion, start an intravenous insulin infusion

references.Name: Zaydfudim V, Hu Y, Adams R. Principles of Preoperative and Operative Surgery. In: Townsend C, Beauchamp R, Evers B, Mattox K, ed. Sabiston: Textbook Of Surgery: The Biological Basis Of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. St. Louis: Elsevier; 2022:204.
Leung V, Ragbir-Toolsie K. Perioperative Management of Patients with Diabetes. Health Serv Insights. 2017;10:117863291773507. doi:10.1177/1178632917735075

Partridge H, Perkins B, Mathieu S, Nicholls A, Adeniji K. Clinical recommendations in the management of the patient with type 1 diabetes on insulin pump therapy in the perioperative period: a primer for the anaesthetist. Br J Anaesth. 2016;116(1):18-26. doi:10.1093/bja/aev347

874129.hint: Consider how surgical stress impacts insulin requirements and why transitioning to an intravenous method may be necessary for patients with insulin pumps during surgery.

364455.question:
A 55-year-old woman who underwent abdominoperineal resection for rectal cancer 3 years ago developed a parastomal hernia.

Which of the following can decrease the incidence of this complication?Consider aspects like surgical placement, especially regarding muscle involvement, as they may impact the incidence of complications.
answers: Making the fascial opening too large
Placement of the stoma in an incision
Placement of the stoma through the rectus muscle
364455.correct_answer: Placement of the stoma through the rectus muscle

explanation.BottomLine: Stomas should be placed through the rectus sheath for additional muscular support and fascial openings should be of the appropriate size for the portion of exteriorized bowel.  The prophylactic use of mesh may be considered for those patients requiring a permanent stoma and extraperitoneal tunneling of the bowel may also be considered.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Parastomal hernia is considered a major challenge following stoma creation.
