This complication is so frequent that most surgeons do not classify this as a complication until it becomes necessary to surgically repair the hernia. Parastomal hernia prevention is the best method of treatment. Stomas should be placed through the rectus sheath for additional muscular support, fascial openings should be of the appropriate size for the portion of exteriorized bowel, prophylactic use of mesh may be considered for those patients requiring a permanent stoma, and extraperitoneal tunneling of the bowel may also be considered.

364455.modifier: Placement Of The Stoma Through The Rectus Muscle

answers_info.Text: Making the fascial opening too large
answers_info.Explanation: Parastomal hernias are associated with poor site selection or technical errors such as making the fascial opening too large or placing a stoma in an incision.

answers_info.Text: Placement of the stoma in an incision
answers_info.Explanation: Placing stoma through an incision increases risk for parastomal hernia.

answers_info.Text: Placement of the stoma through the rectus muscle

answers_info.Explanation: Aperture size has been reported to be an independent predictor of parastomal hernia. In fact, it has been estimated that for every additional millimeter increase in aperture size there was a 10% increase in risk of developing a parastomal hernia.
Several studies have demonstrated lower incidence of parastomal hernias when mesh is placed prophylactically at the time of stoma creation.

references.Name: The ASCRS Textbook of Colon and Rectal Surgery, 2e. Chapter 13. Intestinal Stoma.
Scientific American Surgery. Chapter 527. Repair of Ventral Abdominal Wall Hernias.

364455.hint: Think about how different placement techniques might provide additional support for the stoma and reduce the likelihood of complications associated with stoma creation.

677768.question: A 57-year-old man presents to the office after undergoing Mohs resection of an 8-mm diameter basal cell carcinoma of the left inferior eyelid. The wound extends down to the muscle. The wound is covered with a full-thickness skin graft harvested from the left upper eyelid. An advantage of full-thickness skin graft compared to a split-thickness skin graft that makes it a better choice for reconstructing this defect is
answers:
Full-thickness grafts spare the dermis, limiting
donor site morbidity
Full-thickness grafts have less propensity for secondary wound contracture because the graft contains the entire dermis and epidermis

Full-thickness skin grafts create a donor site
defect that can be closed primarily

Full-thickness grafts can cover a larger surface
area than a split-thickness skin graft, making it possible to harvest a smaller
full-thickness graft to cover a defect
Full-thickness grafts have lower risk of hematoma and seroma formation
677768.correct_answer: Full-thickness grafts have less propensity for secondary wound contracture because the graft contains the entire dermis and epidermis

explanation.BottomLine: Full-thickness skin grafts have less propensity for secondary wound contracture and contain the entire dermis and epidermis.
explanation.ExplanationHeader: Full-thickness skin grafts (FTSG) and split-thickness skin grafts (STSG) have many similarities. However, there are some important differences. Namely, FTSG are used to cover joints and facial structures that would have an unacceptable appearance or limited function if STSG were used to cover these defects. FTSG are less prone to secondary contracture of the graft as the wound heals. This is because they contain the entire dermis and provide full-thickness epidermal and dermal coverage of the wound bed. It is worth noting that FTSG cannot be meshed to increase the surface area they can cover.

677768.modifier: Less Propensity For Secondary Wound Contraction

answers_info.Text:
Full-thickness grafts spare the dermis, limiting
donor site morbidity
answers_info.Explanation: FTSG harvest the epidermis and entire dermis. Hence, they are known as FTSG.

answers_info.Text: Full-thickness grafts have less propensity for secondary wound contracture because the graft contains the entire dermis and epidermis

Full-thickness skin grafts create a donor site
defect that can be closed primarily
answers_info.Explanation: Harvesting an FTSG may or may not create a secondary defect that can be closed primarily. This should be considered during the planning of the reconstruction but will depend on the structures exposed and the goals of the operation.

answers_info.Text:
Full-thickness grafts can cover a larger surface
area than a split-thickness skin graft, making it possible to harvest a smaller
full-thickness graft to cover a defect
answers_info.Explanation: FTSG have a greater amount of elastin in them due to containing the entire dermis, which causes the graft to exhibit more primary contracture immediately after harvest compared to STSG. FTSG are also unable to be meshed to increase the surface area the graft may cover. Because of this, a given STSG can cover a larger area than an identically sized FTSG can.

answers_info.Text: Full-thickness grafts have lower risk of hematoma and seroma formation
answers_info.Explanation: The lack of interstices in FTSG increase the risk of hematoma and seroma formation. If seromas or hematomas develop, graft take may be reduced.

references.Name: Taylor EM, Chun YS. Chapter 43: Plastic & reconstructive surgery. In: Doherty GM, ed. Current Diagnosis & Treatment: Surgery. 15th ed. McGraw-Hill; 2020.
Sun BK, Siprashvili Z, Khavari PA. Advances in skin grafting and treatment of cutaneous wounds. Science. 2014;346(6212):941-945.
Hallock GG, Morris SF. Skin grafts and local flaps. Plast Reconstr Surg. 2011;127(1):5e-22e.

677768.hint: Consider the differences between full-thickness and split-thickness grafts, particularly regarding their composition and effects on healing. Think about how the presence of both the dermis and epidermis in the graft might influence post-operative outcomes, such as wound contracture.

1009228.question: A 51-year-old woman is presenting with a mass that has been slowly enlarging, located anterior to her left ear and extending to the angle of her mandible. MRI images are obtained (see images below), and a fine-needle aspiration biopsy is performed, showing myoepithelial and epithelial cells in varying arrangements within a background of stromal tissue. Which of the following statements is the most accurate regarding the appropriate surgical management of this patients pathology?
answers: this pathology requires removal of the entire parotid gland and the facial nerve
the appropriate operative approach for this patient's pathology is also indicated in those with acute sialadenitis
the modified Blair incision is the most commonly used operative approach to manage this patient's pathology
neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is required prior to surgical intervention for this patient's pathology
the greater auricular nerve should be identified intraoperatively and always preserved when managing this pathology
1009228.correct_answer: the modified Blair incision is the most commonly used operative approach to manage this patient's pathology

explanation.BottomLine: The modified Blair incision is the most common incision used in the performance of a parotidectomy (the management of parotid gland tumors).
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient presents with a mass that has been slowly enlarging and is located anterior to her left ear and extends to the angle of her mandible. 

Most salivary gland tumors arise in the parotid, and most are benign, the most common of which is a pleiomorphic adenoma, which appears pathologically on biopsy as stromal tissue as well as groups of epithelial and myoepithelial cells in varying states of organization. Surgical removal of the parotid gland (ie, parotidectomy) is the treatment of choice for parotid gland tumors.

Parotidectomy can be conservative (does not fully dissect the facial nerve), superficial (dissection of the superficial lobe along all branches of the facial nerve), or total (removal of both superficial and deep parotid lobes). A superficial parotidectomy is sufficient management of benign parotid tumors.

The modified Blair incision is the most common incision used in performing a parotidectomy. It typically starts in the preauricular skin and extends around the lobule over the mastoid tip. The incision is then gently curved over the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle down to the neck skin crease.

MRI demonstrating a solid mass in the left parotid gland.

answers_info.Text: this pathology requires removal of the entire parotid gland and the facial nerve
answers_info.Explanation: The facial nerve's main trunk is located about 1 cm inferior to the tragal pointer (triangular extension of the external auditory canal that points toward the facial nerve). The facial nerve is typically 6–8 mm below the tympanomastoid suture line at the level of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. The removal of the entire parotid gland (ie, deep and superficial lobes) with dissection of the facial nerve is required for malignant lesions of the parotid gland (most commonly being a mucoepidermoid carcinoma). Removal of the facial nerve is only required if the tumor involves the nerve trunk itself.

answers_info.Text: the appropriate operative approach for this patient's pathology is also indicated in those with acute sialadenitis
answers_info.Explanation: Parotidectomy is appropriate in managing patients with chronic sialolithiasis (ie, stones within salivary gland ducts) and rarely for chronic sialadenitis (ie, inflammation of the salivary gland). Acute sialadenitis involves the administration of antibiotics and the performance of sialendoscopy in cases of the presence of sialolithiasis.

answers_info.Text: the modified Blair incision is the most commonly used operative approach to manage this patient's pathology
neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is required prior to surgical intervention for this patient's pathology
answers_info.Explanation: Neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is typically required in cases of high-grade tumors or locally advanced lesions (to achieve surgical resection). If perineural invasion is present, radiotherapy is often required.

answers_info.Text: the greater auricular nerve should be identified intraoperatively and always preserved when managing this pathology
answers_info.Explanation: To mobilize the tail of the gland from the SCM muscle, the greater auricular nerve and posterior facial nerve are often sacrificed if necessary. These nerves are primarily sensory nerves and are not vital structures.

references.Name: Lee YC, Liao WC, Yang SW, et al. Systematic review and meta-analysis of modified facelift incision versus modified Blair incision in parotidectomy. Sci Rep. 2021;11(1):24106.
Chapter 22: Anatomy of the parotid gland, submandibular triangle, and floor of the mouth. In: Fischer JE, ed. Fischer's Mastery of Surgery. 7th ed. Wolters Kluwer; 2018.
Parotidectomy: UpToDate

additional_image_sources.Name: Mass lesion in left parotid gland: Case Rep Otolaryngol

1009228.hint: Consider which surgical approaches are commonly used for masses in the parotid gland, particularly in cases suggesting benign pathology. Think about the typical incision used in these procedures.

779550.question: A 25-year-old paraplegic man presents to the surgical outpatient clinic for his decubitus ulcer (pictured below). He suffered a gunshot 4 years ago, leaving him paraplegic. He doesn't have any signs of systemic or local infection or any comorbidities. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

explanation.BottomLine: Successful reconstruction of pressure-induced injuries is the padding of pressure points with full-thickness, well-vascularized skin, and tension-free closure. Thus, locoregional flaps incorporating fascia and/or muscle with its overlying skin are the gold standard techniques for this purpose.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This patient's decubitus ulcer is stage 3 decubitus ulcer (defined as full-thickness tissue loss where subcutaneous fat may be visible and destruction extends into the muscle with or without infection), requiring surgical wound closure. Fundamental to the successful reconstruction of pressure-induced injuries is the padding of pressure points with full-thickness, well-vascularized skin, and tension-free closure. 

As a general rule, simple local flaps are used if possible. Regional flaps or distant flaps are used if local options are not available. Large fasciocutaneous V-to-Y advancements (see image below) are the first-line option for sacral decubitus ulcers to reduce tension on closure and also to allow for readvancement in the case of recurrence. Also, this technique allows filling up the residual dead space seen post-debridement of devitalized tissue from the sore. Finally, the adequate blood supply of the graft, which is the superior and inferior gluteal artery perforator, helps combat infection and promotes healing, and skin coverage acts as a cushion and prevents recurrence.


Postoperative image of the patient after undergoing two musculocutaneous advancement flaps for his sacral defect.

answers_info.Explanation: Z-plasty is rarely needed for the acute management of open wounds. Its primary indications are to improve contour, release scar contracture, relieve skin tension, and mobilize tissue for reconstructive surgery.
Negative pressure wound therapy and other conservative measure are reserved for stage 1 and 2 decubitus ulcers.

The rhomboid flap is basically a parallelogram with opposing angles of 120° and 60°. Thus, four individual flap choices are theoretically possible for any defect. However, the most suitable one is determined by skin laxity in the donor area and the surgeon’s preference. This technique is used frequently on the face. Also, due to the large size of the defect, a single rhomboid hexagonal flap would be inadequate to cover the defect.
Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous flaps are used for breast reconstruction, not decubitus ulcers.

references.Name: Duci SB, Arifi HM, Selmani ME, et al. Surgical treatment of 55 patients with pressure ulcers at the Department of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery Kosovo during the period 2000–2010: a retrospective study. Plast Surg Int. 2013;2013:129692.
Overview of flaps for soft tissue reconstruction: UpToDate
Surgical management of pressure-induced skin and soft tissue injuries: UpToDate
Image source:
Sacral wound closure: Plast Surg Int

779550.hint: Consider the types of flaps suitable for full-thickness wounds, especially those that help reduce tension and provide adequate blood supply. Think about options that are utilized for sacral decubitus ulcers specifically.

1047566.question: A 53-year-old man undergoes a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis for nausea and vomiting after returning from an overseas trip. The CT demonstrates findings consistent with gastroenteritis and a 1-cm mass on the distal ileum. After the resolution of his gastroenteritis, he undergoes a diagnostic laparoscopy, whereby a 1-cm Meckel diverticulum with a soft, narrow base and no palpable abnormality is found at the distal ileum. No other lesions are found. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
answers: perform a segmental small bowel resection
terminate the procedure and perform a Meckel scan
terminate the procedure and manage expectantly
1047566.correct_answer: terminate the procedure and manage expectantly

explanation.BottomLine: For adults ≥ 50 years of age diagnosed with an incidental Meckel diverticulum during abdominal exploration, resection is only indicated when there is a palpable abnormality within the diverticulum because of the increased morbidity/mortality risk associated with surgery.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
This 53-year-old patient is incidentally diagnosed with a Meckel diverticulum, a congenital anomaly that typically presents at the age of 2 years and is typically located 2 feet from the ileocecal valve. 

Meckel diverticulum is a true diverticulum, including all layers of the intestinal wall, occurring in < 2% of the population, and 2% of them are symptomatic. Two types of ectopic mucosa (gastric and pancreatic) may be found and almost always occur on the antimesenteric border. 

Patients in this age group with incidentally diagnosed Meckel diverticulum with no palpable abnormality do not need resection because of higher surgical morbidity and mortality rates. Abnormalities include ectopic or indurated tissue and ulcerations, all of which can bleed.

Management of Incidental Meckel Diverticulum Based on Age and Sex

Group

Management

All children (≤ 18 years)

 Surgical resection (higher risk of diverticulum-related complications compared with adults
Male adults < 50 years Surgical resection (higher risk of diverticulum-related complications compared with females)
Female adults < 50 years Resection only for diverticulum > 2 cm, associated fibrous band, or palpable abnormality
All adults ≥ 50 years Resection only when there is a palpable abnormality


Surgical specimen taken from a patient with Meckel diverticulum.

answers_info.Explanation: Diverticulectomy should only be performed for incidental diverticulum without associated abnormality diagnosed in children and men < 50 years due to the increased risk of diverticulum-related complications.

answers_info.Text: perform a segmental small bowel resection
answers_info.Explanation: Resection is not indicated in this 53-year-old patient with an incidentally found diverticulum without palpable abnormality.

answers_info.Text: terminate the procedure and perform a Meckel scan
answers_info.Explanation: Unless symptomatic (ie, bleeding), a Meckel scan would not be indicated for incidentally found Meckel diverticulum.

answers_info.Text: terminate the procedure and manage expectantly

answers_info.Explanation: For diverticula that are too close to the ileocecal junction and require removal by bowel resection, an ileocecectomy would be appropriate.

references.Name: Lindeman RJ, Søreide K. The many faces of Meckel's diverticulum: update on management in incidental and symptomatic patients. Curr Gastroenterol Rep. 2020;22(1):3.
Adjunctive procedures in intestinal surgery. In: Fischer JE, ed. Fischer's Mastery of Surgery. 7th ed. Wolters Kluwer; 2019.
Meckel's diverticulum: UpToDate

1047566.hint: Consider the age of the patient and the nature of the findings regarding the Meckel diverticulum. Think about what is typically recommended for incidental findings in older adults, especially when there are no palpable abnormalities.

1049759.question: An 85-year-old man presents with intermittent abdominal and scrotal pain. A CT of the abdomen is performed (see image below). The patient consents to an open herniorrhaphy. While sewing the inferior edge of the synthetic mesh, a great deal of dark blood is noted to be filling the wound. What structure has likely been injured?

explanation.BottomLine: The inferior aspect of synthetic mesh is sewn to the shelving edge of the inguinal ligament in an open inguinal hernia repair. Care must be taken to avoid the iliac vessels.
explanation.ExplanationHeader:
Understanding the anatomy of the inguinal canal is vital to performing a safe, technically solid repair. The inguinal canal is bordered by the inguinal/lacunar ligament inferiorly, the conjoint tendon (combined insertion of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique) superiorly/cephalad, the aponeurosis of the external oblique anteriorly/superficially, and a combination of the external oblique aponeurosis and musculoaponeurotic extensions of the internal oblique and transversalis muscle aponeuroses posteriorly/"floor".  


Abdominal CT showing right inguinal hernia with an extended sac (arrow).

In a standard Lichtenstein repair, the inguinal floor is reconstructed using a synthetic mesh. The inferior edge of this mesh is sewn to the shelving edge of the inguinal ligament. The medial edge is sewn to the aponeurotic tissue overlying the pubic tubercle. Superiorly, the mesh is secured to the transversus abdominis or conjoint tendon. Care should be taken not to sew inferior to the shelving edge as this anatomically approaches the external iliac vessels, which may lead to significant bleeding. This worrisome area is better visualized during a laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair at the inferior and medial region below Cooper's ligament.

answers_info.Explanation: The greater saphenous vein branches off the femoral vein well below the inguinal ligament.
Although this area is dangerously close to the external iliac artery, bright red, not dark, blood would be expected to be seen in the surgical field.
The femoral vessels are located below the inguinal ligament.
The internal iliac vein is located deep in the pelvis of the patient. The external iliac vein is in close vicinity with the shelving edge of the inguinal ligament.

references.Name: Poulose BK, Carbonell AM, Rosen MJ. Chapter 45: Hernias. In: Townsend CM, ed. Sabiston Textbook of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice. 21st ed. Elsevier; 2022:1105-1133.
Open surgical repair of inguinal and femoral hernia in adults: UpToDate
Image sources:
Abdominal CT showing right inguinal hernia with an extended sac: Wikimedia Commons
Tension-free Lichtenstein operation: Wikimedia Commons

1049759.hint: Think about the structures that are located near the inguinal ligament and could be at risk during a hernia repair. Focus on the blood characteristics mentioned in the scenario to identify which structure's injury would typically be associated with dark blood.
